Poured a honey, orange, hazy color with two fingers of off-white, frothy head. Sporadic foamy lacing on the sides of the glass. Great retention on the top all the way down. (Sight - 4.13)

Smelled potent juicy hops from the get go. Got Citra hops, tropical hops, juicy peaches, tangerine, nectarine, Ruby Red grapefruit , orange, floral hops, pine, mango juice, caramel, passion fruit, slight pineapple juice and faint wet Cascade hops. Pretty damn good on the nose. (Smell - 4.88)

Taste wasn¬ít quite as good as the nose, but still pretty great. Got tropical hops, passion fruit, grapefruit juice, mango, pineapple juice, Citra hops, nectarine, peaches, tangerine, caramel and astringent bitter finish. Felt like I could taste pulp it was so thick. A bit boozy late. (Taste - 4.63)

Medium body. Creamy texture. Average-to-lively carbonation. Abrupt, fruity, refreshing finish, but bitterness lasts for some time on the tongue after. (Feel - 4.50)

So glad I got a chance to try this one. One of the best IIPA¬ís I¬íve had. (Overall - 4.63)

4.64 100 A+

Shared can, so it was poured into glasses despite the warning. Cloudy yellow pour with a lasting creamy head. Floral/citrus aroma with a little pine, herbs, and cereal. Drinks very easy for 120 IBU. It¬ís perfectly balanced and the finish lasts forever. Bright hops, citrus, pine, a touch of herbs and yeast, even a little pepper at the end. A truly excellent beer.
Probably the best beer I have ever tasted. Tasted it very fresh in Burlington this summer when the brewers festival was on. Amazing aroma and taste.

What an amazing IPA! Thanks to Ignace and all the guys in De Hopduvel for making this happen! The aroma is resin and tropical. In the glass this looks like dense peach/nectarine juice. Taste is piney, bitter grapefruit and tropical fruit nuances are evident. Lives up to the hype.
3 weeks "old" from a trade. Aroma is amazing. Lacks the last -umph- you want in a beer like this.

Got this on trade. I know it says drink from the can, but I poured it slowly into a glass. Looks like grapefruit juice. Big resin, grapefruit, and tropical fruit aroma. Very tasty. Lots of grapefruit taste. Good bitter punch. So juicy. Hints of orange and other citrus taste. Totally amazing beer.
I gotta say all the hype about this beer is true. It has everything you would want from a double IPA,with a great clean finish.

It damn sure is the real deal. Deeply hoppy, with piney notes dominating under-currents of orange and lime zest. The pleasingly bitter finish is conspicuously free of heavy malt or sugar, which lets the hop flavors fade gradually and gives the beer a sip and savor pace.
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2014 Can at Gents Bierfestival. Pours cloudy orange. Nose is agrum, citrus, very hoppy. Taste is pretty balanced, but finished extremely bitter. Very refreshing, hopbomber.

Can. Pours a bright orange with a thin, white head. Aroma is super bright with big notes of orange citrus, pine, resin, and a bit of bread. Delicious. Taste is bitter but with enough backbone to handle it. Pine, resin, citrus, bread, and a long, bitter/resin aftertaste. Medium-full body with a medium carbonation. Fuller, resiny texture in the mouth with a soft carbonation. Overall awesome. Amazing noise with a great taste and mouth feel. Worth finding.

Pours a hazy orangey copper with a large creamy white head that sticks up the glass quite nicely! Aroma is citrus, tropical fruits, resin together with such a great balance. Flavour is citrus, tropical fruits, grapefruit, orange peel, resin, med-high bitterness(yet oh so smooth!), nice full mothfeel(likely from the hop resins), some deep British pale malty notes and a medium dry finish.

Huge citrus hop aroma. Hazy yellow appearance with a white head with excellent retention and lacing. Flavor is full of pleasant citrus flavors. Malt flavor is light and let's the hops shine. Hop bitterness is nice and smooth. Body is medium with medium carbonation. Truly an amazing ipa. Great citrus aroma and flavor with a smooth bitterness. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Fantastic beer. Have had it several times now, and it always blows my mind! It¬ís thick as cream, and every sip is better than the last one. Even the final sip... I love it!!

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2014 The first time I tried this beer, I didn¬ít get what the hype was about. Sure, it was a very good IPA, but I just didn¬ít get it. After the 2nd tasting, I am starting to get it. The key is to treat this beer as if it were a maltier brew, and let it warm to 50-55 F. This allows the flavors to really open up, and show what makes this such a great IPA. It is pretty bitter, but with loads of citrus and tropical fruit, and nice balance. It¬ís easy to forget just how high the IBU¬ís are on this one, because it is so smooth and drinkable. I have to admit, this beer lives up to the hype - or at least, it comes close enough for me.
Wow. Shared a can of this with a couple of friends. Very complex array of hop flavors without being overpowering.
Poured from a can it is a cloudy golden color with a white head the aroma is of grapefruit the taste is strong bitter citrus flavor and it resonates bitter on the tongue

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2016 473ml can served in a tulip glass (to take a look in its appearance) and also drunk from the can as suggested by the brewer. 
A: Pours a hazy yellow to orange to beige color forming a small think bubbled creamy head. Low retention and only few lingering lacings left in the glass. 
S: Hops bomb, of course. Refreshing and delicious. Strongly tropical fruity profile with strong notes of green mango. A bit lemony. Malts and some sweetness. 
T: Excellent taste. Again, of course, giving emphasis to the hops. But the malts profile is also very good. Pale malts, mainly, Maris Otter style, Slightly sweet upfront but with an overall, dry and crispy malt profile. Intensive hops bitterness, however, very well harmonized. Notes of citrus lemony hops. Green mango, tropical fruits. Light notes of brown sugar. 
M: Medium body and carbonation. Strong citrus hoppy aftertaste. 
O: Excellent drinkability. Perfect IIPA. 
[ BA Review @ 6/16/2013 ]

Location: Can shared by Pinsky at Dave¬ís Bachelor Party, 9/27/14, Rating #4000!


Aroma: It has a big hoppy aroma of grapefruit/tropical hops, pine, and a bit of caramel

Appearance: I drank this one straight from the can as the can instructs you to do

Flavor: The taste has lots of pine and tropical flavors, a little sweet, with a big hop bitterness

Palate: The body is medium-plus, it has a pretty smooth mouthfeel, and a clean, dry finish

Overall Impression: 
I was quite excited that I finally got to try/rate this. Thanks Pinksy! I¬ím very happy to enter this one as my 4k tick! I¬íd like to thank all the inablers who made this possible by sharing beer with me, buying me beer, or just not judging me for how much beer I drink (okay, that last one is really just for my wife). As for the beer, sometimes hype can go to far and the beer has no chance to live up to it. This is not one of those times. This is a world class beer! I¬íd love to get my hands on more of these.

Can at tasting. Big garlic hop flavor. Reminds me of "Wings of Armegeddon". Bright garlic, yeasty golden malt body. Its good, its tasty, its solid...but this is not life changing stuff...hardly line-worthy.

Very aromatic indeed. Very sweet, soft at first, with many fruits, brown sugar and a hint of cinnamon, but a massive hop-whallop (120 IBUs) takes over shortly. Smooth and creamy throughout, low carbonation. Not at the top for the style, but quite tasty and dangerously drinkable.
Can, sample. Didn¬ít take proper tasting notes. Overwhelming ipa, but very drinkable, mouthfeel is seriously pleasant. The sample was way too small though...

Pint can to snifter. Golden cloudy yellow. Fluffy head. Ridiculous piney hop aroma. Tastes surprisingly balanced and drinkable but with a never ending bitter finish that¬ís got me making faces. I¬ím not a hop head.

Can Jordan brought to Dave¬ís bachelor party, September 2014. One of the beers I¬íve always wanted to try and didn¬ít disappoint. What is most amazing is the palate, which is just the right amount of body. Enough bitterness but not overpowering for me, just really really good.

@Borefts 2014, Hotel room tasting, jammer dat we dit moesten delen ;). erg hoppig bier en behoorlijk bitter, maar dat was te verwachten. amber met witte kraag. enorm fruitig en hoppig aroma van grapefruit, citrus etc. smaken zijn heerlijk hoppig, zoetig, citrus fruiten komen er ook goed in terug net als een massa bitterheid, medium body, lage co2, maar dat kan omdat het blikje allicht wat langer open was.
Nothing to say that hasn't already been said, besides HF the best ipa out there

I prefer this beer two weeks after purchase when everything has melted together so nicely. It then reveals to be more peach and pine on the aroma. When young it is completely overwhelming but without being harsh. It is an incredibly easy to drink beer even with high abv and heavily hopped. I simply love it.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2017 "this is a seriously drinkable iipa. reminded me of fresh gubna in a way...more pine and spice here perhaps. you can tell the abv is high, but it¬ís oh so easy drinking. bright vibrant sticky hops and a nice malt backbone. VERY well done.
Recent batch lost to 4.1 Crusher head to head.  Go figure.
Hazy yellow pour. Aroma plants, pine, peaches, grapes. Tastes woody, yeast, pine, resin, minerals. Zesty palate. A fine brew.
Can shared. Pours yellow and clear. Massive hop smell. Taste of big hops...very bitter and dry. Good IPA but in my opinion not as good as Hopslam.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2015 Blind tasting, of Double IPAs & Single IPAs. 

List of Double IPAs, in prefered order: The Crusher, Heady Topper, Pliny The Elder, Deviant Dale¬ís 

List of Single IPAs, in prefered order: Focal Banger, Grapefruit Sculpin, Moralit√©/Blind Pig 

A ¬ñ Glowing hazy yellow with a thick head. 

S ¬ñ Very pungent piney, citrusy aroma. Pineapple, over ripe fruit, hop forward. 

T ¬ñ  Taste does not disappoint, again straight forward hops, no crystal malt, very dry. The amount of hop taste The Alchemist actually gets is very impressive.

M ¬ñ Mouthfeel fills your mouth, lively carbonation with an abrupt bitterness finish, quite oily

O ¬ñ The amount of hop taste The Alchemist actually gets is very impressive, the aroma, especially if you smell out of the can is very very intense, but the taste completely mimics it.

The definition of IPA. BITTER, citrus, floral, hoppy deliciousness. 

This is the only IPA I've had to date that beats my home brew. Wow. What an experience.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2016 Very nice, dank and piney aroma and taste. Very balanced between malt sweetness and hop bitterness. Only downside for me is the lack of some tropical fruit and the alcohol being just a bit too present.
Pinaple, citrus. Nice colour. Smoth. Thanx to Stephen at n√∏gne √∏ for sharing this one

Thanks to Steve for this thoughtful gift. Pours a bright, hazy golden in color with a medium, slowly settling, white head. The aroma is heavy, with plenty of grapefruit, orange, pineapple, peach, and floral hops. The taste is extremely bitter and hoppy, with a very dry finish. Pine and grapefruit are most prevalent here. Peach, pineapple, tangerine, and orange are found as well. There are touches of sweetness that compliment the beer instead of overpowering it. The aftertaste is a long lasting grapefruit flavor. Medium in body, a slick, slightly sticky texture, and lots of lively carbonation. Despite everything this is offering, I find this very easy to drink. Its delicious, refreshing, yet still packs a punch. This is one outstanding beer. It is among the best of this style that I¬íve ever had. It might be the best. I won¬ít be forgetting this one anytime soon.

From notes, 16 ounce can consumed on 5/18/2013 at ChurchKey. Hazy honey orange with two fingers of off-white head. Nice head retention and lacing. Aromas of grapefruit and other citrus fruit, tropical fruit, caramel, floral notes. Tastes of big grapefruit citrus, caramel, pine, resin. Medium body with a semi-dry and bitter finish. Medium carbonation. Great stuff.
Huge hoppy citrus arome from this clear orange highly carbonated brew. Taste of grass brapefruit and malt back bone. Dominated by fresh hop character. Great brew
Once again my Brother comes through. Poured from can into pint glass. Pours a light hazy orange color. Aroma is citrus, grapefruit, hops. This is a well balanced Hoppy beer.

Can - 473ml. Pours a hazy, light amber body with an average, lasting, white foamy head. Fresh, complex aroma for such a hoppy beer. It is obvouisly dominated by hops but malty, citrusy, and some subtle vanilla hints are noticeable. Its sharp hoppy taste carries citrusy, coriander, and piney notes. Ends with a long, strong bitter finish. Awesome DIPA and a perfect pick for my 3000th rating!

Got a 4-pack in a trade. Shared two with friends, drank two: one from a glass, one from the can. Can seemed to be more pungent, like it funneled the citrusy hop goodness into my mouth. Aroma is pure citrus grapefruit hops. Taste follows and expands. There¬ís malt here, but its just enough to balance out those hard hitting hops. Still this isn¬ít a bitter hop-bomb. Like Pliny (which I was fortunate enough to have side-by-side with this), this is incredibly well done, balanced, and drinkable, especially for 8%. I couldn¬ít decide if I liked Pliny or this more; they¬íre both perfect DIPAs and perfect beers to me. I know Heady is supposed to be hazy since that¬ís just the nature of their approach to brewing, but I deducted a point for appearance because Pliny easily outdoes it and looks absolutely marvelous in a glass. Overall a n incredible beer. Must-try.

Rating #1100. Fresh Can from trade with matt. Pours a hop hazy bright amber with a white head. Aroma is just hop-forward with peach, orange, ripe grapefruit, weak floral notes, mandarin, clementine, resin and some overall tropical notes. Behind this there is a typical DIPA malt presence - but not in a bad way. Taste is just crispy, bitter and refreshing. So drinkable! Resin, bitter citrusy hops, grapefruit, sweet orange, mandarin, weak resin, some weak malt which gives the beer some nice body and a nice balance. I would love to have this on a regular basis!

Can shared with Vestergaard and rasmusott. Boom! Pours hazy orange with a thin white head. Aromas of a sweeter grape, peach, some tropical pineapple, sweet ripe orange. Smooth malt profile. Taste is booming with peach, sweet orange, pineapple, slight pine, slight caramel malt, lots of resin. Some grassy hops but not a lot. Veryyy smooth.

Fairly fresh can. Pours hazy yellow-amber with a small white head. Aroma has sweet, tropical fruits, pineapple, lots of peach, pear, crispy hops, a bit of caramel malts and citrussy mandarin. Taste has a nice body with lots of peach, orange, grape fruit peel, a nice hoppy bitterness, some grassy and resin notes. Great balance between malty and hoppy sweetness and fruits, and the high bitterness. The bitterness is also carried very well by the fittingly full body. High carbonation. Great double IPA for sure!

Wow...Thanks to cfrancis for this one! What a wonderful double ipa. Smooth and delicious! Pours a hazy golden orange with a huge frothy and lacey white head. Aroma of caramel malts, resin, pine, grapefruit, citrus and orange peel with nothing standing out and nothing out of balance... Hops are ever so pleasant to the nose upon cracking the can. Taste is resin, grapefruit, pine, light spruce tips, caramel, sweet pale malts and an excellent smooth bitterness throughout that?s balanced perfectly with the sweet malts. Love this beer!
Well balanced, tremendous fresh hop flavor with peach and grapefruit. Full flavored and refreshing. Not too bitter. Some tropical and pine flavor as well. Unfiltered orange in appearance.
Can - Not much else I can say about this great DIPA that hasn¬ít already been said. From start to finish, it¬ís well balance between the malts and hops. It¬ís one of the best DIPA made today.

There is not much to say about this beer that has not already been said. It is an outstanding DIPAS.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can from unknown via Michael K. Can¬ít say much about color, it looks tan, or thereabouts. Aroma arch and a bit resinous, some bold citrus as well. Body is big and full, I am prepared for a total bitter finish, but it recedes nicely before leaving a lingering citric tang. Nice, but not quite worthy of the hype.

First class DIPA. Drank it from the can. Next time I will try to drink it out of a glass. Might be a marketing-gag? Anyway, aroma of grapefruit and tangerine, tropics, malty backbone. Almost perfect symbiosis of (not too) bitter and sweetness. Expensive in Europe, but worth spending bucks on it once in a while.

The pour (screw you can, I do what I want!) is hazy mango-orange body with a pillow of a tan head that sticks around as long as the beer lasts. Aroma is tropical fruits, orange, some yeast a little alcohol. Flavor is the same only a little bit better and with the addition of bitterness. Tropical fruit continues and is joined by pine. Sweet backing to round things out. Mouthfeel: Perfect. It¬ís thick and sticky without being too heavy. Just a hint of alcohol warmth and flavor toward the end of a sip. Carbonation feels very fine and refreshing. Totally agree with the hype, this is the best beer I¬íve ever had. BUT: quite a few brewers are catching up! I¬íve had a couple by my locals and others that are only a few steps and a few points behind. We¬íll see if this is still the best in 2015, 2016 and beyond. 

My opinion on a few controversies:
Can or glass: Definitely glass. When this was first canned I think haze was seen as a flaw when it came to IPAs, thus the brewer wanting you to drink from the can to not see it. In 2014 though all the best IPAs are hazy, so ain¬ít a problem.
Draft or can: Pretty much indistinguishable. On tap it¬ís served at the right temperature, but you can get the same effect by leaving it out of the fridge for a couple minutes before cracking it open.

Perfect fresh DIPA as you can get. Everything about this beer is great. Awesome aroma. Great flavor. Perfect amount of body and dry finish. Love it all around 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A great DIPA, although having tried it both ways, I find that I MUST pour into a glass to truly enjoy. I don¬ít quite understand the "DRINK FROM THE CAN" reasoning on the label, but I do agree with the description of this beer...
Not the biggest, or the most bitter (120 IBU???), but definitely "waves of hoppy goodness". The best Heady Topper I had this summer was on draft because I happened to be in Vermont at the right place at the right time!
Insanely drinkable. A session beer for hopaholics only.

Grapefruit from the first taste till the last drop in the 16 oz. can.
Very consistent brew, great quality. The fresher, the better.
2014.08 - gents bierfestival (uit blik) - geelkleurig troebel, wit schuim - neus : geurbom, bloemenhof, tropisch fruit - mond : fruitig, eindigt op een serieus bittere toets

Entered as my 900th rating (after 5.5 years on RateBeer). 16 ounce can given to me by my buddy Shem who apparently has a hook-up in the San Diego area for this particular beer (and which he has not yet revealed to me). Very happy to get my hands on this, the #4 rated DIPA in the world on RateBeer right now. But unfortunately, I am unsure how old this is and suspect that it might not be super fresh. POURS into glass a hazy yellow-gold hue with two fingers of off-white foam with great retention. AROMA of tangerine, peach, tropical fruit (passionfruit, mango), spicy hops, light pine, and some bready malts. FLAVOR of prickly hops with notes of pine, sweet grapefruit, honeysuckle, all with a nice balancing sweet honey maltiness. Somewhat light bodied for the 8% and not very bitter despite the 120 IBU¬ís (nice balanced with the solid malt backbone). Very happy to try this...would like to find a verifiable fresh can to try and see if the hops aromas and flavors are stronger. (1105, 900)

Pours... Well, doesn¬ít. I decided to follow the recommendation and drink from the can. Hard to get used to! Nose is hoppy and fruity, citrus, pine, and dank. Taste follows suit, with tropical fruit and citrus, pine resin, floral and floral against light sweet malt. Medium light body with very little alcohol presence and a sticky finish.

Well, damn. Ain¬ít that some shit! Next one I get my hands on is gonna have to go in a glass so I can evaluate appearance as well, but other than the inability to evaluate appearance, this is perfect DIPA. And since DIPA¬ís are pretty much my favourite style, I guess I officially have a new favourite beer ever.
Superbe IPA tr√®s houblonn√©e et fraiche. Drink from the can!! So drinkable it¬¥s scary!

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2016 One of the great hypes in modern American craft beer culture, hard to get because demand highly exceeds supply, but I managed to find a fresh can at a reasonable price and though I did taste this beer before, I am looking forward to rating it in a more contemplative manner.  Pours a warm, deep peach blonde colour, equally cloudy, under a creamy, dense, egg-white head with good retention.  Wonderful, lush and overwhelming IPA aroma of pink grapefruit flesh, (strong) pine resin, spruce needles, tangelo, orange juice, exotic flowers, mango, papaja, rose petals, vanilla, suze liqueur, freshly baked biscuit, nettle cheese, buttermilk (or in fact diacetyl, proving this can is indeed super fresh), wormwood, bitter honey and black olives; every whiff reveals new aromas, this is a bouquet I can sniff all day.  Crisp onset of exotic fruits, sour berries or even a refined lime acid touch, and a ton of citrus ¬ífra√Æcheur¬í, hugely quenching, with a soft but adequate carbonation and a lovely, rounded, bready malt sweetness underneath with yeasty accents playing along; the saltiness, which can become a bit bothersome to me in some American IPAs and DIPAs, remains firmly in place, restrained by the bitterness, as it ought to be .  The piney, citrussy, floral and strongly spicy hoppiness increases gradually towards the end, "wave after wave" as the text on the can says, exploding in the finish, with a mouth- and throat-coating ¬íoiliness¬í, resiny and infinitely long, assertive but still in perfect balance with the full and satisfying malt body.  This is packed with flavour to the last drop...  My last impression after swallowing is... well, a juicy hoppiness and maltiness which litterally makes my mouth water.  I do believe this belongs in the upper class of American DIPAs; whether it is worth the hype or not is up to the consumer to decide, I do think there are quite some comparable and more accessible examples around and I also recommend tasting this as fresh as possible (I also had a somewhat older can which had lost a whole lot of its flair), but this is clearly a masterpiece in its (New England sub-)style and a big treat to hopheads like me.  World class, made my mouth water even thinking about it two days later.

Danke an WillemsUrenkel. Geruch intensiv Maracuja und Grapefruit. Start s√º√ülich, Grapefruit. Mitte s√º√ü, Grapefruit, Maracuja, trockenbitter und perlend. Abgang sanft salzige T√∂ne, Grapefruit, Mandarine. Bitter und vollmundig auslaufend. Sehr gut!

Aroma of hops were smelled immediately when can was slightly cracked open. Grassy, earthy, floral aroma. Palate is full hops. Very fresh taste. Crisp, sharp, and leaves a long bitter palate. Overall very hoppy, good taste of grass, floral, and grapefruit. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy

From the can, poured an ounce off to see, hazy golden hue with pale white creamy head, very fragrant, sticky, earthy, more pine than grapefruit citrus with some sweetness, great balance of carmel malt, hops and carbonation, not to heavy, sweet or bitter, great at 8% therefore not overpowering, tastes like nectar, pretty amazing, I wish I had another, thanks AL
Smell is hoppy and a touch fruity, taste is high hops, finishes with slight buttery popcorn...too much hops for me though

Hazy orange copper with a small head.that leaves tons of thick lacing. The aroma is full of resinous pine, grapefruit, earthiness, and a bit of fruity esters. The flavor is fruitier than the aroma leads on, with strong bitterness on the finish. Really good.

Awesome beer. Freshness is undeniable. Hops on hops. This beer is so drinkable it's dangerous.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can

Hazy hay color with aromas of citrus and light malt. Tastes of resin, citrus and grapefruit. I¬íll never get fed of this beer. You can drink anytime with no problem.

rating #55
SImply the best DIPA I have ever tasted. The moment you open the can your are bombarded with hops and citrus. This beer tatstes heavenly. Lives up to the hype
There isn¬ít much about this beer that hasn;t been said, its amazing loads of hop flavors without being too dry or too bitter. Very drinkable double IPA

Hazed yellow pour with creamy white head and lace. Aroma is large citrus hops and caramel malt. Flavor is semi sweet malt start with resiny hops and then a grapefruit zesty citrus bitter kicks in. Medium body with good carbonation. lives up to the hype thanks Phil

Can, tfs JulienHuxley! Murky golden orange colour, white head. Aroma of citrus, grass, some pine, crisp malts, light floral. Flavour is light malty, crisp, citrus, grass, light floral hops, hint of pone, firm bitter grassy finish. Light to medium-bodied. Highly sessionable for an 8% beer. But not the worlds most amazing DIPA IMO.

Can thx to Julien @ Julien¬ís neighbour is a metalhead according to Rob-tasting, small sample. Can was 5 weeks old, so way too old for the beerbros. Slight hazy golden color, short head. Aroma of grapefruit, pine, citrus, resin, tropical fruit. Quite fruity actually, love it. Taste is mostly bitter, but with a decent biscuity and cookie caramelly backbone. Good balance, great DIPA.

16 oz can - pours a vibrant orangey gold . Big grapefruit nose . Sweet citrus with some mild pine , very balanced . Outstanding !!!!!!

-- via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Seriously one of the best American IPA¬ís I have ever had. More out there for sure, but this one simply takes the cake. I don¬ít like writing ¬íbout beer unless I am making a beer menu at work. You guys decide if you like it

Can courtesy of Kermis. Poured a hazy light amber with a thin whispy white head. The aroma is light citrus hop, pine needle. The flavour is medium bitter with a woody resin, light spice pepper palate. Medium bodied with average carbonation and a lingering bitter super light toothpaste bitter finish.

Unexpected bonus share by Kermis. Poured milky yellow/orange with a small off white head. Aroma of medium sweet citrus and soft malt. Medium body, flavour is sweet orange and moderately malty. Bittersweet finish.

Thanks to suttree for sharing a big can of this one. Dirty orange and hazy with a lasting film of cream. Big nose of resin and grapefruit with some caramel holding it up. Taste is the same rich goodness. Light-medium body has medium carbonation and a good balance.

On tap at Blackback Pub in Waterbury, VT. 
Pours a somewhat peachy brown, quite hazy, with a billowy, white head that dissipates to thin film within a minute or two. Sticky, clumpy lacing. 
Nose is a bouquet of fruit and citrus notes nearly masking the malts. Grapefruit and orange zest come through strong with peach and apricot hints. Taste is bitter, but a surprisingly mild bitterness. Especially for a Double IPA, I expected it to be more harsh, but this is quite delicately balanced. Medium to full bodied; carbonation is quite lively. Excellent brew!

Incredible grapefruit flavor without being overpowering. Was much more drinkable than I expected.

Can. Pours cloudy orange with a white head. Aroma is pine apple, grapefruti, pine, mango, resin, biscuit, grass. Taste is sweet ripe fruit, medium smooth pine and grassy bitterness, finish is rounded lasting bitterness with a mid sweet biscuit and fruity sweetness. Smooth oily texture, medium bodied.

Looks like orange juice with white head and lace. Floral and orange hoppy aroma with hints of spicy grass. Fruity bready orange sweetness. Surprisingly mild medium bitterness. Nicely attenuated medium light body with great super fine carbo. Excellent. Best beer in the world? Not so sure.

Great, massive DIPA. Pineapple scented, cloudy, hugely drinkable (for an 8% beer). From can & poured into glass. 5 days after distributor dropped off. #fresh

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours a hazy orange with a complex hop aroma of citrus, grapefruit, pine, and tangerine. The flavor is stellar with an amazing blend of sweet fruit and medium bitterness throughout. Amazing beer

Thank you, thank you, thank you to WillemsUrenkel for that can! Looks really good. Beer in the glass very zippy, nice head. Starts intense hoppy, bitter with fruity notes of grapefruit, lemon. Quite dry, but not too much. Also some grasy hints. Well balanced bitter-hoppy finish. A great beer!

Pours hazy light golden, lots of bubbles, finger creamy white head, lots of thick lacing. Aroma big fresh grapefruit, bready malt, pine, and floral hops, slight grape peel and alcohol. Taste bitter grapefruit, floral, slight pine up front, fresh bread sweet malt to provide some balance mid mouth, grassy, grapefruit rind, floral hops and un-ripe grape peel linger. Mouthfeel fuller side of medium body, medium-high carbonation, creamy, slight alcohol warming, nice peppery hop sensation, balanced finish leans more on the dry side. Overall wow, this is what a double ipa should be, right up there with Pliney and Double Jack for me, probably the best, I would wait in long lines for this!

Followed the instructions and drank it from the can.

Aroma from the can is amazing, simply amazing.

Taste - very nice. Hits you in the front and then a huge blast in the back of the mouth. Wow.

Palate - Very fizzy carbination. Perfect mouth feel.

Overall - Excellent beer. Worth the wait. I wish there was a canned date on the bottom, but I am pretty sure the can is fairly fresh because I don¬ít think any of these sit beers sit on the shelf very long.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2014 16oz cans. Hazy golden yellow with a thin frothy white head. Flavors are biscuity malts, citrus, pineapple, pine resin and alcohol with grassy and juicy notes. Medium body, soft carbonation, smooth texture.

Pours a hazy/murky golden amber, almost glows. Smells of pine, citrus, herbs and fresh floral hops. Taste is extremely danky and herbal, huge notes of pine, citrus and earthy hops. Medium body, medium carbonation. This goes toe to toe with 3 floyd dread naught in my opinion. I like them both equally, 

What sets this beer apart is its uniqueness. Not like any traditional ipa I have had, almost tastes like your squeezing the juice out of a nugget of hops and drinking it.. Which I love.

From the can in my hand on the beach and enjoying a very crisp hop aroma. Flavor is hoppy but not overly bitter with a bit of citrus and a touch of malt. Very very clean palate and nice short finish without the classic over hopped residue lingering.

Loved it and will buy it again. Would drink this everyday. 
Some people find it be a bit harsh to drink when fresh (I love it though) but give it a few weeks and it will be more balanced.

Doesn¬ít taste the alcohol or the malt: hops have the center stage and they will perform a show you will remember all your life :)!
Incredibly flavorful DOUBLE IPA.. On par or better than stone - enjoy by or southern tier IPA and 2xipa - worth every swig!
The consummate hoppy beer. Very hop forward but not overwhelming, not dominated by citrus or piney hops, more herbal. Not too heavy or sweet like you sometimes get with an IIPA.

Can¬ít believe I had a IIPA from the can, and it actually works its magic awesomely! Starts with strong heady cannabis flavors then dives into deep grapefruit hoppiness. Very high drinkability, no useless bitterness, all about a crispy bouquet of hoppy flavors. The ultimate gift for hopheads!

Amber orange, cloudy with a thick white foam. Citrus, citrus and citrus smell all the way, with resinous/grassy smell. Taste is very balanced, a little bitter, quite nice. The aftertaste is long and fruity. Really a great beer.

Bought in a small shop in Vermont, opened in a Hotel in Manhattan a few days later. Pale orange and unclear in the glass. Fine foamy head. Fruity and hopy on the nose. Starts fruity, honey, smooth brewwater, earthy, pleasant longlasting bitterness on a malty base. If you have ever the chance to get one, do it!

Clean hoppy aroma. Great appearance, plenty of head and lace. Flavor is hoppy mainly resin, some citrus, balanced with enough malt. Clean palate. Very drinkable.

Pours a hazy burnt umber with a light creamy head.

Deep funky hops with piney citrus notes. Aroma is in your face and a sign of the bold flavor to come. 

Drinks strong and smooth with a mellow maltiness laying under the powerful hops. A mildly bitter finish lingers for a moment but is rounded out well. 

Overall an outstanding IPA and it's easy to see why it's sought after. That said, the hype may be overplayed just a bit. 

Slightly reminiscent of Six Point's Hi-Res which is high up on my list.

Found a few cans at a store in upstate NY after striking out during an earlier trip to Vermont. Pine, grapefruit, citrus, dark fruit, spice, and some underlying bread and caramel in the aroma. Bitter citrus flavor, with lots of orange, lemon, and grapefruit. Bittersweet, spicy, crisp finish. Certainly really good, but maybe a touch overrated. I¬íve had other big IPAs that were about as good, and a lot less trouble to find.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2014 In trade from bibsbrewing on BA. Thank you! Pours gorgeous glowing rich hazy bright orange. Smell is strong citrus orange grapefruit. Taste is citrusy, orange bitterness. Like candied orange peel. Kind of sweet in the finish. Too syrupy of a body and normal carbonation. Good but doesn¬ít differentiate itself from the field of endless double ipas for me too much really. Kind of reminds me of what I remember Maharaja tasting like. Not my favorite style lately, but glad to have tried it.

Nice to have finally found the notes on this. 
I had two cans. One was poured into a snifter and the other was drank out of the can.
The appearance in the snifter was a hazy burnt orange color with a ton of floaties surrounding the body. The head was about a finger¬ís worth of white foaminess. There was some light lacing sticking nicely to the sides of the glass. 
The smell out of the can and glass was basically the same as it was pure citrus to piney hops that ended up assaulting my nose in a nice bitter/dank sort of way.
The taste between the can and the glass was the same as it was pure bittersweetness from the hops. Even as this one warms, the sweetness comes from the hops and not the malts. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a pretty good sessionability about it. The carbonation was sharp due to the style and was much expected. 
Overall, I can see why so many people like this. If I lived within the brewery¬ís distro I¬ím sure I¬íd be stalking this brew at least on a weekly basis. However, I do have to say this and that¬ís the fact that this isn¬ít exactly the most balanced in the nose. Also, what¬ís with the "only drinking it from the can?" So what if there¬ís floaties - who cares. I didn¬ít know the floaties police would be after John Kimmich for allowing floaties in his beer.
By far the best IPA I have ever had. Hints of citrus and pine with lots of funk. If you find it drink it young and fresh. Wish it made it to the west coast.

Pour from a can (only enough to get an aroma and color) was a hazy gold with a white head. Aroma is floral with a nice citrus. Taste is a little grapefruit with a hint of pine. Goes down smooth and doesnt have much of an after bite.

Light orange, golden hazy pour. Fluffy white head, various size bubbles. Juicy fruity hop aroma. Grapefruit, peach, mango, passion fruit. Flavor is bright, complex and dense. All kinds of hop character. Mostly peach and papaya, but really a huge host of fruits. Malt is very light and really tries it's best to stay out of the way. Bitter finish shows up suddenly, attacks the sweetness and then subsides. It leaves some tingling on the tongue and gums. A touch of heat from the alcohol shows up and somehow enhances the intensity of the fruit. When I casually sip a pint of this, I end up thinking it's just very good but not exceptional. When you sit down and deconstruct it to rate, you discover just how well everything fits together. It really is exceptional and exemplifies everything the style should ambition to be. The best part is the intensity of flavor that comes on the back of a big malt base and alcohol at 8%, but without becoming the sticky sweet mess that too many other beers that try to pull this off usually become. Pretty glorious stuff.

Very nice canned IPA widely available here in VT but apparently a precious commodity elsewhere. Good forward hop pine resin flavors but they stay a bit heavy on the tongue. And at 8.3% hard to quaff more than 1-2 in a session. A bit cloying & syrupy.
Not the best ipa at all as many claim, but still amazing. Super resiny and sticky with hop bittrrness. A lot like six point resin, but better.

Thanks for the graduation gift bmmillsy. Half can half glass. Powerful grapefruit aroma. Pours cloudy, likely why they say to drink from can. Thin head. Tremendous hops indeed. Agreeabley scary to drink for a double. Chewy citrusy hoppy goodness. Well balanced. 

Canned on April 2. Now June 12.
 from the can... Sweeter, little metal, still good

Very hazy golden/yellow color with a soapy head and lacing. Aroma of piney hops, grapefruits, toffee, caramel, citrus and resin. Very strong piney/resin hop flavors with some strong citrus notes and toffee sweetness; Very bitter resiny aftertaste. Heavy body with some moderate carbonation. Yeah, it¬ís pretty good!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2014 16 oz can shared by Huhzubendah. Thanks Matt! Pours a hazy translucent light golden with a wisp of white head and minimal lacing. Aroma is incredible: Perfectly bitter with notes of tropical fruit and perfectly balanced hop bitterness. Nothing more can be said; this is clearly the perfect DIPA. Flavor is more of the same - words are inadequate to describe the perfection in the glass. There is no way this beer could improve. Perfection. Rate 6/7/14.

Hazy amber/gold color; Medium creamy body; Aroma of rich pine/resin hops, floral, & citrus; Flavor of slight sweet malt, caramel, rich pine hops, some tropical fruit, and citrus (notably tangerine & grapefruit); Finish is dry & bitter; The alcohol is fairly well hidden; Very nicely balanced; Worth the hype - simply awesome!

Can pint. Ha! Aroma is very hop, floral. Appearance is I can't tell cause I am drinking it out of the can. I assume a dark bronze. Taste is a resiny hop that is medium bodied that finishes very floral. Never had an IPA like it. Overall, very interesting. Would love to try on cask.

Thanks Luke L for the can.  Released for sale only three days prior to consumption. The can instructs to drink directly from it. I had to pour a bit anyway to gauge the color, but after a comparison, I think I like the glass better. Color is very light, like pineapple juice, hazy-to-cloudy, 1cm head, but fades quickly to ring and oily film. Aroma (from tulip glass) is a citrus blend, huge pineapple, ripe orange, lemon, grapefruit, and a smaller bit of fresh pine. Very fruity and sweet like juice. Flavor is: lots of citrus, floral notes, a more acidic (less sweet) orange, bit of grapefruit, and, again, pineapple. Only a touch of neutral sweetness, then lots of pine when more air is inhaled with the sip. Bitterness is smooth, big, getting heavier as it warms. Mouthfeel is medium, sticky, bit of pillowy carbonation of moderate coarseness. Great beer! Not the best IPA I¬íve ever had; hop oils are different than the typical big, bad (and amber colored) IPA¬ís that I love, maybe less farnesene and berry notes, less floral. As it warms, it gets a bit more bitter than I¬íd prefer given how light it is (little malt flavor to balance). Excellent, not a top 3 though.

Resin, citrus, spruce, floral tastes come in waves moving from the front of the tongue to the back of the pallet. The flavors just keep on coming and never stop. Bitter then citrus and pine landing on grapefruit. Amazing dispersal of hop flavors during the entire experience. Some yeast aftertaste very present as you near the bottom of the aluminum shrine that contains this magic. Outstanding IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2015 What more can I say about this beer that hasn¬ít been said or discussed? Pour was golden and cloudy and had some pieces of hops floating around. Aroma was pine, citrus and bursts out at you. It¬ís a very nice and complex smell and it lasts. Taste followed the nose, some pine with plenty of citrus....grapefruit, lemon, pineapple, orange. Highly bitter, but very easily drinkable. I thought it went down quite smoothly. A little dry on the finish. This was the second time that I¬íve had this and each time was split with a friend. We enjoyed it each time and it¬ís a quality beer. No differences were noted, so it means they are consistent with their product.

Poured an orange/golden hue that was very clear. The head dissipated quickly. Smelled of citrus with hints of pine. Tasted piney with a bit of sweetness at first taste. The bitterness faded quickly, the can was about 8 months old, so I think it probably tasted quite a bit different than a fresh can.

Best beer I've ever had. I wish I knew how to get more. I live in PA. It's brewed in VT. Time for a road trip!

Can from Route 7 Liquor & Deli. Pours a very hazy mango-y orangey-yellow, almost no head. UPDATED: SEP 3, 2014 UPDATE TO RATING. Had two cans from same batch. Don¬ít drink it super fresh - let it sit for at least a month. First can (within 2 weeks of release) was good (see review below). Second can? By far the best American-style beer I¬íve ever had. Better than Pliny. That¬ís all you need to know, I suppose. Have altered rating accordingly.

Fresh can (2nd April 2014) thanks to De Hop Duvel.

Aroma: the best thing about this beer. Less than a month since canning with hop debris littering the can, the aroma is intense and well balanced between citrus fruits and pine. One that makes you simply go "Oh. That¬ís awesome."

Appearance: this is an unfiltered, unfined IPA, and I can only mark it as such. Cloudy, orange. Marked down 1 for lack of professionalism.

Taste: tastes like a fairly flawless homebrew, essentially. All of that amazing aroma is compounded on the palate. No detectable yeast character, despite the proprietary Conan yeast strain. Complex and gradually unfolding hop flavour.

Palate: mouthfeel is sensational - the dry finish combines well with the mouth-coating feel.

Overall: this is an excellent homebrew, on a large scale. Not that that¬ís a bad thing, but it¬ís not the best IPA in the world. That¬ís not to say you shouldn¬ít go out of your way to acquire it - it¬ís still worth it.
Started from the can then poured to a glass. Liked it better from the glass, fantastic beer. Wish it was easier to get!

Balanced and complex. Lots of hops as advertised. The malt bill is nicely sweet and the finish is moderately bitter. Nice sticky mouthfeel, semi-dry finish, but still plenty of juicy, lingering hops. Not many beers compete in terms of flavor when fresh. For the sake of this review I poured a few ounces into a glass for inspection.*gasp* Sediment, murky, moderately carbonated with a nice white fluffy head that clings to the glass. Not a pretty beer, but a damn good one!

had in a super fresh can served at The Blue Stone in Waterbury, Vt., was so into it I smuggled a case back home. beyond all hype, this is one of the best, most rewarding beers I¬íve had. A hop-head¬ís dream, beautifully well-balanced and packed full of piney, earthy citrus goodness. pure craftsmanship.
Cette bi√®re est un ravissement pour les pistoles gustatives. les sommes sont √©quilibr√©s. √Ä boire le plus rapidement possible. Elle se d√©value en vieillissant comme tous les IPA.

They hype was not false. This was absolutely divine!

At the crack of the can, which I drank from, the hops were on attack and when I began to drink it, the onslaught didn¬ít stop at any time. 

By far, one of if not the best I have had. Definitely happy I waited to make this beer #200!

If I could get this regularly, I would be buying everything I could! 

Don¬ít fear the hype. It is all true!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2014 Thanks to ThirstyBird for this fresh can!  Very great hoppy-grassy in the nose. The beer starts great fresh-hoppy. Slightly sweetish body, the hops are intense, fresh. Citrus-like grassy. The aftertaste is long, intense. For me much too sweet - the hops are intense and in the foreground, but the sweetness is too heavy for a great hoppy IPA!
 Still a great brew, but not the best - therefore too sweet! But the fresh hop-aromatic is great! --> 13/12/12/12

16oz can compliments of neohippie. Thanks brother. Pours a lightly hazy orange color with a white head. Aroma is magnificent a bright hoppy citrus melt in your mouth with mango, orange and others. The flavor was so smooth the ibu¬ís very well hidden. The malt base is spot on wonderful. Very well put together. Overall I want more.

There is an extreme floral hoppiness to this beer that is just awesome, the floral also shows up in the taste but it is not overly bitter. It would be awesome to show a little more maltiness in this beer to counterbalance the hops but otherwise this is a very solid and enjoyable beer.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hmmm. How do I explain another overly hopped, could use some more balance beer. The reason this beer is so coveted is because it is so hard to find. I think IPAs like Hopslam have more balance but given it¬ís easier to get a hold of, it doesn¬ít had the same aura. 

Give it a shot¬Ödefinitely worth it if you can¬Ö.i just find it¬ís undifferentiated from the plethora of IPAs on the market today.

16 oz can courtesy bytemesis. This one pours a slightly hazy, glowing orange color that is topped by a small head of eggshell colored foam that quickly recedes and leaves streaks of lace behind. Just a couple of floaties in there too. The aroma is very tropical from the hops showing notes of grapefruit, mango, orange, and stone fruit atop a toasted bread malt base. The flavor follows suit with the tropical fruit, grapefruit, and orange up front followed by a touch of pine and a hint of honey sweetness to go with the toasted bread malt. The hops are the star here as they pack a flavorful punch of and bitterness. There is a nice balance though with all the flavors without getting overly bitter. Nearly full bodied and smooth with balanced carbonation that leads to a drying finish with some residual hop bitterness in there. This is certainly a really good double IPA and well deserving of the praise, but I don¬ít know that it¬ís the best double IPA out there.

Pine and tin aroma with a stale background (probably my fault) golden hazy color(I know I¬ím suppose to drink it out of the can but it¬ís already in a glass) Dry bitter off the bat with a slightly citrus funk after taste.

My first Heady. Thanks, Andy! No idea how fresh or not my can is, but it?s working just fine for me. Wonderful aroma, grapefruit and dank hops. Really amazing smell, actually. Taste almost as amazing. Really flavorful and hoppy, bright, but not overpowering. Just so tastefully crafted.

16oz. can! This one pours a cloudy darker golden color. There a few floaties in there. Small white head that doesn¬ít linger long but does leave some lacing. Big nose of hops, hops and more hops! Grapefruit is the main contributor. Maybe some pineapple, peach and orange in there too. Nothing else making past the hops. The taste is good. Not nearly as bitter as you think it might be. Nice rounded flavor, fairly bitter, but there is a touch of sweetness hiding in there. Grapefruit and pine hops, with a strong malt body behind it. I¬íd say it definitely lives up to the hype. Now to get some more...

Can thanks to Matt, drank from the can so I can¬ít comment on appearance. Aroma is super fresh and zingy, with buckets of citrus and pine. Taste is down a similar line, with enormous, incredibly fresh hop bitterness - again citrus is at the fore, with pine and some lighter tropical fruits present too. There is still a disguised but present malt backbone there. Finish is lively, crisp, dry and with a lovely lingering citrus aftertaste that lasts forever. Gorgeous beer, one of the best I¬íve ever had!
Thanks Bursprak! Drank it from the can. Soft carbonation. Overwhelming aroma of fresh hops. Very fruity (citrus, tropical fruits). Light sweet with very bitter aftertaste. This is very good!

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2015 16 oz can in a trade. Thanks Moy! The pour is a little light for my liking in a solid double. The light gold had a beautiful head, and offered some lovely lacing. Don¬ít worry, I didn¬ít pour all of it out, just a little. The aroma is extraordinarily hoppy. There¬ís a gorgeous citrus and pine note. It¬ís simple, and yet amazing. The flavor is a strong hoppy bitterness followed by a nice piney dryness, and a wonderful grapefruit-esque finish to it. The mouth feel is incredible. Thin, but yet creamy and then really dry. The aftertaste is lingering, dry, bitter and hoppy. This is just a phenomenal double IPA. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy peach color with thin white head. Smells floral with citrus and pine. Tastes very citrusy and piney, but low on the sweet fruit flavor. Hops are present but subdued which was nice to see. Very balanced, and VERY drinkable for a DIPA. I can see where all the hype comes from. This beer feels like it is a finely tuned machine, or a work of art. It feels cohesive and intentional in a great way. However, personally speaking, while I appreciate the superior quality of this beer I have had IPAs that I¬íve liked better for whatever reason, like Ruination. That¬ís not to say I don¬ít like this though. And for sure I will buy some more when I get the chance to get my hands on it again.

Couldn¬ít resist, had to pour it. Hazy amber/orange pour with a white head. Aromas of tons of citrus peel, and lots of floral notes, with some slight pine. Flavor is a wonderful balance of hops and malts not overly bitter but plenty of hoppy goodness. Crazy smooth and very drinkable. This lives up to all of the hype. So freakin good! Props to Drewbzzz for the can! Thanks man!

Ahhh piney flowery hoppy love. Smells great. Looks great. Love drinking out of the can. I wonder if I'd love this as much if it was easy to get... Probably. The only negative thing I can say is I can only drink one of these and I'm drunk. High alcohol content. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Drank straight from can as directed. Drank straight from the fridge at first, but let warm up a little bit in order to get the full flavor. The smoothest IPA one can drink.

This beer made me like IPA's. I always heard that it was an acquired taste, well, Heady Topper, thanks for helping me acquire it. Now I like a whole slew of IPAs but my memory of this one was that it was perfect.

Hazy orange/amber colored pour. Small, somewhat soapy looking head. With big soda-type bubbles. Little bit of splotchy lacing left behind. A lemony aroma of hops, some dankness and pine mixed in. Taste is citrusy, leaning more towards orange with some lemon mixed into it. A slight bit of sweetness. Finishes sweeter than I though it would. A slight bit of alcohol warmth. Not much bitterness. Much more sweetness than bitter. Decent. Not sure how you could get any of this without pouring it OUT of the can. You wouldn¬ít. It would just be for getting drunk at that point. This is a decent Americanized version of an English IPA though. If they made DIPAs over there.
Can at home. Superb aroma of fresh pine and musty, dried flowers. Super smooth palate, full of bright fruity flavors. Bitter, fruity finish.

So the hyped Heady found its way to Denmark. Does it live up to the hype? I would say YES! Enoyed half of this straight from the can and poured the rest into my IPA glass. Liquid is clear golden with a nice dense head. The nose is as nice as it gets, loaded with passionfruit, peaches, grapefruit and elderflower. Taste is really balance between the sweetness of the malt and the fruity hops. Lots of exotic fruits as in the nose. Doesn¬ít get overly bitter like other IIPA¬ís. Really nice!

Got a few cans in a trade. Was supposed to be ~4 weeks old. Drank out of the can every time, as per instructions on the can. Was a sweet, hop forward ale. Great, resinous hoppy mouth-feel. Extremely consistent hop profile and drink-ability. Not too heavy on the stomach, which was nice also! Great IIPA!
Lucky enough to have tried this canned wonder. Love the citrus notes and pine flavor. Best beer I've ever had.
There is nothing like fresh Heady. Amazing aroma that hits you right in the face. It¬ís not over the top with bitterness like a lot of double IPAs. Overall, it is a perfect balance.

Pours hazy light orange. Big pine, peach mango pineapple notes on the nose. Thick, sticky dank hops. Medium full on the palate, piney bitter hops up front, leading to a bitter hoppy fruity finish. Excellent

Heady Topper lived up to the hype. Fantastic IIPA. What can be said about it that hasn¬ít already been said? It¬ís the perfect beer. Even the can is a work of art.

Insane peach/orange color, ridiculously dank aroma, and an orgasmic blend of hops. Perfect amount of bitterness, finishes clean with a pleasant floral aftertaste. Considered moving to Vermont after the last sip. Cheers.
plz keep in mind, this is just my opinion. i do NOT like IPAs, so this beer is not for me.

I've had Pliny and now I've had Heady! I'm gonna have to say... Damn they're both good! This one has HUGE hop aroma but such a sweet flavor. Super duper smooth on the palate. This just sneaks past Pliny as the #1 IPA.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hazy light amber orange color with a frothy off-white to light tan head. Beautiful aroma with tons of citrusy and tropical fruit hop character. Flavor is a bit more subdued with the sweetness, but with a sharp bitter kick. Oily on the palate with bitterness lasting long into the finish. Great IPA, but not quite spectacular for me.
Hard to take your nose away from the unreal citrus hop explosion that permeates through to the last drop. Fantastic hoppy smoothness on the tongue that really does make you want to crawl into the can

This is a great double IPA plain and simple. To me not the best beer on earth but a great beer.

Amazing brew, the smoothest, most drinkable dipa I¬íve ever tried. 
It¬ís hoppy, but not over the top, no dry bitter tongue after taste.
The most impressive part is the ease that this can be consumed.
Smooth smooth smooth.

Hazy straw yellow in color... Aroma is earthy, pine hops, light champagne nose.... Flavor is initially sweet, citrus, gives way to dry earthy, piney bitterness on palate.... Not overwhelmingly bitter, but definitely has a kick... Really complex and well done

I¬íve had some really good DIPAs and this really doesn¬ít approach that level. My friend who brought the can from Vermont, and who has had this beer many times before, said that it didn¬ít strike her as much as previous cans had. The hazy yellow color is nice, and the aroma is fine (standard citrus, etc.) but there¬ís a superficial bitterness that isn¬ít as well compensated by the sweetness and malt backbone as I¬íve found in other DIPAs. This is fine, to be sure, very respectable, but I¬ím surprised it has garnered this high a rating/ranking. Can.
Une des meilleures Double IPA, que j¬íai jamais but. Grande ar√¥me tr√©s floral, une touche de malt et de houblon bien √©quilibr√©. Teneur en alcool parfait. Son seul d√©faut, dure a trouver !!

Can, courtesy of northropfrye. Big hoppy a aroma right out of the can - tons of pine and some nice citrus. Flavour is quite bitter but beautifully balanced, managing to be easy drinking while still full-bodied and packing a huge hoppy punch. Thoroughly enjoyable.

What can I say about such a talked about beer? If we drink with our eyes first, nose second, and mouth third, then this is as close to a perfect beer as I believe is out there. The color is a cloudy yellow gold with a nice pillowy head, Just the look from the nonic pint glass, (yes it does stipulate that you should drink it right from the can, but I can¬ít) is enough to have the saliva begin to flow. The nose is all hops, citrus and pine to the max. The taste is similar, bitterness through and through, but funny enough, there is a very solid malt backbone here. Its in the shadows and hides until the finish, but there is a nice bready taste that cools off the hops just a little. Fantastic.
Such an amazing beer, had out of the can. Has the perfect amount of citrus to it. Simply amazing.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2014 first off..gotta thank John,owner of South Bay beverage in Massapequa,NY..he gave me this FREE tonight..popped open can..great hoppy aroma..excellent pour into a tumbler..hazy orange with 2 finger head..hoppy,but not as much as i thought it would be..overall very good..but overrated.

Pours hazy gold with a creamy white head that leaves lots of lacing. Sorry, can. Aroma of extremely pungent citrus fruit - tangerine and orange being dominant. There are further underlying dank, peach and fruity yeast notes. Superb and totally unique. Taste is medium-sweet malt up front, very quickly leading into massive hop flavour. There is lots of bitterness no doubt, but the citrus and peach flavour balances nicely. Clean and bitter, long finish with a slight spiciness. Hype justified.

Sample at First Sunday. Pours a hazy yellow, with a medium, off-white head. The aroma is intense pine and resin, with some chalk and sawdust. Very bitter flavor, with just a little sweetness. Long, bitter, yet fairly pleasant aftertaste. Medium body, with a sticky, astringent mouthfeel. Maybe this is blasphemy, but I was underwhelmed by this. It is likely that, with more than a couple of ounces, it might¬íve grown on me, but from what I had, I¬ím not impressed.

Bu directement de la canette. Vue: aucune id√©e! Nez: difficile de sentir dans un si petit trou. Bouche: sensationnellement houblonn√©. Tr√®s fruit√©. Malt√©. Sucre d'orge. Tr√®s r√©sineuse/conif√®re. Agrume surtout du pamplemousse et de l'orange. Finale s√®che qui redemande une autre gorg√©. Tr√®s rafraichissante pour le pourcentage. Que demander de mieux.
One of the best IPAs I¬íve ever had. Great aroma, well balanced malt and hops. Perfect alcohol content. Can¬ít wait to have it again.
From Waterbury Vermont a la casa de David. Viva el 2014 con 8 % de contenido de alcohol

Kinda lucked into trying this one. Some dude who looked like a vagrant came into the Panama City Beach Qwikr Likr yesterday and handed a can of this to the manager. Apparently he¬íd promised him one some time before. Got a chance to sample some, and I¬ím extremely glad for his generosity. I¬ím a big DIPA fan, but hadn¬ít had a superb example in quite some time. This is one awesome beer.....great hop aroma and flavor...gritty/dirty in a good way...reminded me of some of the great SoCal DIPAs of my past (Hop Suey comes to mind!). UPDATED: MAY 22, 2014 From the can. Aroma of fresh pine. Heady totally lives up to the hype! Incredible double ipa. Very dank resiny hops. Perfectly described on the can "wave after wave of hoppy goodness." I was lucky enough to get a case from my buddy in VT about a month ago. This can isn¬ít quite as fresh as the first one I had but it¬ís still excellent! Very drinkable and smooth for a double ipa. I can¬ít wait to get more!!

Dark gold.
Rich citrus aroma. Orange flavour, an extra piney twist in the tail. Very refreshing, very drinkable. I¬íd love this as a regular in my fridge!

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2014 Can: Thanks to the many Heady hook ups I¬íve had over the years, Nick being the first. Of all the Heady I¬íve had, my cans have never had sediment. Completely opaque, yeast hazed sunburst orange with a creamy, eggshell foam that leaves nice lacing behind. Aroma is gushing with wet, citric & tropical hops. Pineapple, passion fruit, mango, tangerine, mildly dank hop oils, a touch of green onion, some sweet bread, a hint of honey, & a kiss of malt sugars. Taste is so smooth for 8% ABV. Leafy, oily, lightly herbal hops with notes of grapefruit peel, sweet orange rind, mango, light passion fruit, & some finishing pineapple. Touch of white pepper, grass, & hemp oil. Wet & dripping with hop. Finish of tropical hops, light honey biscuit sweetness, & faint herbal notes. Simply great DIPA, the hype on Heady Topper is legit, & it never disappoints!

Many thanks Northropfrye. Pours a hazy light orange. Beautiful aromas of citrus, tropical fruit, and resin. Flavors are grapefruit, sweet tropical fruit, resiny hop bitterness. Incredibly smooth. A truly delicious beer.

Cloudy, pale yellow, small white head. Melons, floral. Some hay. Very bitter, but balanced against quite a lot of sweetness. Lighter bodied, fairly carbonated. Effervescent. Excellent, tremendously well balanced.

Appearance: Hazy deep golden color with a frothy white head that leaves a fine lacing.Aroma: Rich balanced grapefruit hoppy and mild tropical fruity.Palate: Full body. Slightly sweet, and a rich balanced bitterness. Average carbonation. Oily texture.Taste: Rich grapefruit hoppy, rich fruity and a deep malty back.Overall impression: Well what is there to say about this one that is not already spoken? There is a natural reason why we want this one. Pure pleasure!Personal stats: Can from a trade with Perrin515

Poured from a one-day old pint can: Pours a hazy golden with a one finger white head and a few yeasty chunks on the bottom. Aroma is unlike anything else I¬íve ever had. Floral, grapefruit, lemon rind, little grassy, pine, just wonderfully fresh smelling. Taste is incredible, so much grapefruit, hoppy, resiney goodness. Finish is clean with a little bitter kick at the end. The bitterness increases as the cans age, and the beer gets a bit boozy. Don¬ít sit on these, they only get worse. On tap at the source this might the best IPA in the world. The only knocks I have on it are the slight bitterness at the end of the sip (really knitpicking here), and the rather chunky appearance as it¬ís unfiltered and unpasteurized. Chunky is not appealing. Other than that, it¬ís perfection.

Can, poured into a snifter. Pours a very cloudy straw yellow with a moderate white head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left partial lace. Very pleasant aroma of grapefruit and pine. The flavor begins with mild malt but is quickly overrun by grapefruit and pine hops bitterness. A bit less resinous than I would have liked and more dominated by the grapefruit than the pine. This beer actually gave me heartburn and required 3 Tums after consumption. A fun beer to try but falls a little below the hype for me.

Poured from the can - after a few sips as guided. Great, fresh hop aroma. Fantastic palate and surprisingly smooth for a DIPA. Taste is where it sings. A bit of pine but such a smooth drinking IPA you are necessarily disarmed. It's easy to see how HT has become such a favorite.
16oz can. Pours a hazy golden color with small white head. Intense hoppy aroma with notes of citrus and pine. This is a hop lover¬ís dream, pure bitter hoppy flavor. Full bitter finish. Outstanding.
Not an ipa fan so this is a huge rating. If all ipa¬ís tasted like this is like ipas! The bitterness is really understated. Smooth going down the hatch.
Heady hop aroma with a slightly cloudy appearance. Hoppy throughout with a clean aftertaste.
Complex aroma of caramel, hops, and citrus, cloudy caramel colour with a wonderful head and great lacing. A balanced taste of caramel and hops mild palate of caramel and hops.

Poured from a can. Hazy yellow color, medium white head. Slight floral nose. Medium body with a nice central hops flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
This was an incredible beer. Their ability to shove that much hop flavor into every ounce of liquid while not assaulting the palate is amazing.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2014 Re-rate with adnielsen: Moving this to a 4.0 from a 3.8. Previous rating: Can courtesy of bnielsen13. Thanks Brad! Pours a cloudy golden orange color with white head. Piney, hoppy, citrus, floral, herbal aromas. Hoppy, floral, herbal, citrus flavors. Very tasty IPA.

Drank from the can. Aroma pops immediately with the top of the can with hops, citrus, pine and a little earthiness. Hops punch you in the mouth when it hits your tongue, with a little caramel sweetness to balance out the hop assault. Incredible beer, so glad I drove to the cannery and got the case.
Hazy pungent hop bomb. Rough grassy bitterness. Not bad, not great. Citrus pith flavor.

Drank from can, aromas of pine, wheatgrass and pear.Hops, Hops & more hops. Strong bitter taste from start to finish with slight citrus notes (pineapple and a little orange) with a slight sweetness. Overall the best beer I¬íve had in a long time

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2016 Pint cans, freshly imported @Brent¬ís Chicago tasting ix/13 + 2nd can sampled xii/13. A freshly baked pineapple biscuit, bitterlemon fresh with the resiny hops of grapefruit rind, peel and even some of that white unpalatable skin in between. Heady at 8% - nonesoever. Topper: one of the best DIPAs and a redeeming, creamy specimen for some of the rest of the ABV-fuming family. Worth not heeding the "drink from the can" imperative, although its punch and taste would probably not lose much. Almost worth a 900 mile drive! // Resampled OCT2016, shared at Freiburger Brewpub, canned JUL2016. A lemon meringue pie hidden among dashes of fresh exotic zest, summery with that lovely haze that translates into a haptic bite.

Drank right from can.
Aroma: piney, floral, peach 
Appearance: Light golden color, white head, nice lacing 
Taste: passion fruit, citrus, pineapple 
Palate: Fizzy, Dense, Dank

Can, thanks to NHhophead! Poured just a bit into a glass to look at... Hazy yellow pour with a very thick off white head. Nose is huge grapefruit and pine. Taste mirrors the nose; great earthy Pine and citrus hops that create a really crisp and refreshing body. The malt presence at the end really works well and balances. Slight floral, really nice finish. Worth most of the hype, really well put together.

Received two 4-packs in a trade with bostonbeans originating on the other site. Purchased a week ago, so this beer is fresh to deff... Whatever that means. First time drinking, and I¬ím pretty excited. Thanks, Vini!

AROMA- Wow. Could I just smell this beer forever? So pungent, and so delightful. Huge citrus (specifically grapefruit and clementine), pine, and floral notes with a hint of sweetness. You¬íre not gonna make a beer that smells better than this. You¬íre just not. So don¬ít even try. 

APP- Drank the majority of this beer from the can, but I wanted to see what it looked like, so I poured a few ounces into a snifter. Looks like grapefruit juice with a bit of orange juice poured into it. Pretty friggin¬í cloudy. A small head, that I¬ím sure would expand had I poured the whole can. Overall, not too impressive. I can see why "DRINK FROM THE CAN!" is exclaimed on the label in all caps.

TASTE- Hops on hops on hops. Juicy, fruity sweetness balanced out by the hop bitterness. Hops, citrus, sweetness. In that order. And me likey that order. The bitterness lingers, requiring a solid smacking of the lips. Love that. The taste is not quite as phenomenal as the nose, but quite lovely nonetheless.

PALATE- Not the best mouthfeel I¬íve had in an IPA. Feels just a little bet empty. Maybe a little watery at some points. Doesn¬ít detract too much from the beer, but could be improved. Pretty good amount of carbonation, with a dry finish. Hop oils totally coat the tongue.

O- I think I¬ím understanding the hype. This was a really enjoyable beer. Only room for improvement would be on the appearance and the mouthfeel. But where it really counts, this beer delivers. And I have 7 more in the refrigerator. You lucky dog.

Tried it both ways out of the can and into a glass. I might say the cam is a touch better. The can is right. The pour is a dark orange almost honey color. The lacing is full and stretches all the way up the glass. Aromas of hops fill the room. They are huge and citrusy and pine. Lots of c hops here. Flavor is much the same with the enamel piercing hop profile of a classic west coast profile. There is a little more depth and complexity to the flavor though that takes this to the next level. Honey and light caramel on the flavor. Orange candy sugar sweetness. Bubblegum and a resiny pine finish. Damn each sip is like a different hop. Tasty.
Can at home courtesy of NHHOPHEAD. Pours orange with a white head. Aroma is very citrusy, piney, hoppy. Flavor is a lot of citrus and pine and hops. Very well done.

Poured from a 16 ounce can into a Spiegelau tulip - no, I didn¬ít follow the rules and drink it out of the can. No freshness date printed on the can.

Appearance: Pours a hazy dark honey blond with orange highlights and a 3 finger fluffy eggshell white head which dissipates very slowly leaving a 1/2 finger puddle of foam gently resting on top. Decent lacing.

Smell: The nose is huge. I got a blast of hops as I poured it from the can into the glass. Huge citrus aroma with resinous pine, floral sweetness, pineapple, a touch of honey and just a bit of bready malt in the background .

Taste: Sweet citrus, pine and grapefruit dominate throughout. The flavors aren¬ít overly complex, but it¬ís incredibly well-balanced. The aftertaste is bitter, but not overly so. There are hints of sweet orange in the aftertaste as well. This beer just does what it intends to do: give waves and waves of hoppy goodness on your palate.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with just the right amount of carbonation. 

Drinkability: Insanely high drinkability. I wish they still counted that toward the score here on BA. Goes down so smooth, I can¬ít believe it¬ís 8% ABV. 

Overall: Amazing beer overall. There is a reason this is considered amongst the world¬ís best beers. It¬ís phenomenal. Honestly, I don¬ít think there¬ís one thing I would change about this beer. This is a beer to seek out. If you ever get the chance, you must try it. It¬ís world class.
Overall a very nice DIPA. I¬ím. It sure what all the fuss is about. I have had other DIPAs that I prefer. It doesn¬ít look that great in the glass. I drank half from can first.

Heady pushes the envelope of hop insanity straight to the breaking point then adds 50% more hops. Hop flavor and aroma are overwhelming but bitterness doesn¬ít even begin to keep pace. As DIPA goes, this is very accessible in terms of bitterness. Expression is of citrus and piney resin.

Pours a cloudy, golden color, fantastic citrus aroma. Pleasant bitterness but overall smooth and drinkable. I could put back a bunch of these. Well-balanced flavor - a little piney sweetness - with a nice bitter kick at the end. Great beer.

big thanks to gunnarolis for this. 2 week old can. Beautiful yellow color with a nice firm head. Big lacing. Resiny aroma, some fruits, faint citrus and grapefruits. Rich on the tongue, medium bodied. Fantastic drinkabiliy. Extremely fun to try but hype is maybe doing to much for this beer. Incredibly good session beer.
This was a great tasting beer. I feel it has a very piney taste/smell. It is to bad it is not shipped farther.
la canette fait un peu peur mais il ne faut pas s¬íy fier, superbe fruit√©, les 120IBU ne se sentent pas, longueur √©norme, pas trop s√®che ni r√©sineuse. Une des meilleurs IPA.

Can. Cloudy golden body with a frothy, off-white head, rapidly diminishing. Aroma of orange, citrus, grapefruit, pine, toasted grain. Hint of caramel. The flavor is moderately sweet and lightly to moderately bitter. It finishes lightly to moderately sweet and moderately to heavily bitter. Medium to full body, watery/velvety texture, lively carbonation. Strong bitter finish washes away the orange juice/grapefruit tastes, but not immediately. Some alcohol pepperiness and some light resin and pine. Very nice.

Hoppy aroma faded just a little during the week since canning. Still amazing strong citrusy aroma.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from the can into a tulip glass. This can is from the brewery, fresh in mid-September....

First whiff is hops and then the citrus presence, namely grapefruit, pine and some other hints. So nice on the nose but it doesn¬ít give away anything about what¬ís coming in the tasting....

Poured a hazy rich gold/orange with over 1 finger of off white head. This faded to nice lacing on the glass. Light carbonation noted.

Remembering that this has been sitting in the fridge since mid-September I figured there would be some difference between this and the one I had at the brewery. I wasn¬ít too far off. The hop profile has softened slightly but the first notes are the hops, then the citrus, other fruit hints and pine. The beer is still so balanced there wasn¬ít one flavor that stood out above the others. Certainly the malts haven¬ít taken over and dumbed down the flavor profile, it¬ís just a bit mellower than when fresh.

Medium body for me with a clean, fresh taste and a dry, hop finish. Smooth all the way through. Lower carbonation than what I remember but I don¬ít mind a bit.

Overall this beer lives up to its name. As I compare it to other DIPA, this one is still at the top of my list, even one that¬ís a little older and less-fresh than right out of the brewery. Awesome job Alchemist and hopefully I¬íll come by some more of this down the road.

Cheers!!!
Hazy golden. Massive nose, hops. Earth, pine, citrus, wood. Bitter finish, good but not the best out there.
Zzt¬í13 bij joes. Gele niet heldere kleur, kleine witte schuimkraag. Ruikt hoppig, fris, bitter, beetje fruitig. Smaakt hoppig, bitter, fris, dennenbomen, lekker

thanks to Joes. Pours a yellow golden beer with a good white head. Smells orange, citrus and fresh. Delicious. Tastes insane good. Orange and citrus with a perfect dry finish. Average carbo, medium body and a dry texture.
As good as any IPA you will find. Nice grapefruit piney taste will prevent you from realizing just how strong it is. Not a pretty beer but who cares when it tastes this good.

Great not amazing. If this was available in my neighborhood, I¬íd drink
it all the time. Nice and rich, hoppy and sticky. Definitely give it a try.

Can from pump, thanks! Drank this one from the can on a round of disc golf. Aroma is big and sweet with citrusy and woodsy hops and a nice caramel backer. Taste was fantastic with citrus, grapefruit, pine, caramel and a strong bitter finish.

A R- Dry hopped to perfection what you smell is what you taste
AP- This beer is a traditional golden color that many IPA¬ís have but is not 100% filtered
TA- You get hit with Hops first, taste the malts and a bit yeast and then finishes with hops again
PA- Nice complex flavor that will bath your tongue in liquid goodness
OV- It¬ís hard to find a better beer than this

No comparison, this is serious business. The best IPA you¬íll find, bar none. Like someone created the prefect crossbreed between a luscious mango and a pine tree, and captured the essence in this silver can. It¬ís rich, sweet and ever so hard to get, but it¬ís absolutely perfect. Can¬ít rate appearance because you¬íre supposed to drink it straight from the can, and it¬ís pretty dark in there. Which is how the hops like it, and you can tell they absolutely love it. And you will too.

Mmmmm. Truly the holy grail of IPAs. Full floral fruity hop aroma, no bitterness, full mouthfeel, lovely color. Wish it wasn¬ít so hard to get a hold of. Thanks to our friends at Beer Boutique in Brooklyn for the cans! Beats out Pliny for me.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2014 Can. Pours cloudy pale orange like fresh apple cider with a small white head that disappears quickly leaving little lacing. Nose of grapefruit, peach and citrus. Medium body, average carbonation, hop forward, medium to heavy bitterness, flavor of peach, citrus and caramel, oily texture and a strong grapefruit bitter finish. A bit over rated, though good.

Can. Pours cloudy pale orange with a lasting white head that leaves excellent lacing. Rich aromas of tropical fruit, grapefruit, sweet citrus, ripe peaches and bread. Lightly sweet and medium bitter taste. Flavors of ripe peaches, well balanced medium to full body, hides alcohol very well, oily texture, average carbonation leading to a lightly bitter finish. Much fuller than the first time I drank this.

Elle est tr√®s am√®re, passablement sucr√©e et l√©g√®rement acide. Elle est de corps g√©n√©reux, bien onctueuse, tr√®s effervescente et se termine sur une longue amertume et de forts ar√¥mes.

From Can. Pours a slightly hazy golden/orange hue with a very small white head. Aroma has some tropical fruity hoppy notes like peach, grapefruit, slight pineapple, slight unripe lemons. Some good strong hop profile to this beer. Decent malty/caramelly backbone here as well, and balances out perfectly. Very crisp finish. Medium bodied, with a lively carbonation. One of the best DIPAs I've ever had! Surly Abrasive, Pliny the Elder, Three Floyds Dreadnaught, I'm so confused...
