Hazy, yellow, off-white head, good lace. Nice hoppy bitter DIPA but very unclean and almost over the edge with the grassy hops.
Definitely a mouthful. Tons of citrus hop flavor but well balanced by lots of malt sweetness. Cloudy appearance. Very good beer overall.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2016 What, how have I not rated this after drinking it many, many times. Pure good hoppiness in a can. Citrus/grapefruit, pine and just good hops! Had this multiple times after and need to adjust ... original - 9 4 9 4 18
Aromas of citrus hops & flowers. Bitter tending towards too much but remains balanced. A superb beer but probably there¬ís even better.

Nose of catnip, slight skunkiness; pale orange cloudy, lasting lacey head; slight sweet hoppy flavor throughout blends well with expected lasting bitter finish; medium carbonation; all around great beer!

Pour a beautiful hazy/murky light orange, with a very small white head. 
Aroma has plenty of tropical fruity hoppy notes like peach, grapefruit, slight pineapple, slight unripe lemons. Some hopjuice going on in this bad boy. 
A Big malty/caramelly backbone here as well, and balances this one out beautifully. This thing sure is crisp!!
The taste is pretty darn bitter, with some slight sweet notes, but really crispy bitter. Hot dang this tastes good. 
Medium bodied, with a pretty lively carbonation. 
A huge thanks to Dr. Doodle for sending me this unexpected treat!!

Oh boy this is an easy drinker

Rating #600! 

Can from Freddy at Bev4Less. Thanks Freddy! Open the can and don¬ít pour into a glass, just like the can tells me not to. Aromas are hop rich, surprisingly dank and forward (I thought it would smell less like a west coast offering), with some biscuit malt already apparent. Taste is very, very good. Clean, crisp, ALL of 120 IBUs assault my tongue and roof of my mouth. If you don¬ít love DIPA/IIPA style, with all the crazy bitterness it can bring, this won¬ít do it for you in the same way Pliny, or even a beer like Maine Lunch, will. This is not the crazy malty overhopped rendering of the style, all too common, but a balanced, bitter, bready, sweet craftbrew with balance and intensity in alternate, and proportionate, quantities. Really pleasing. Glad I got to try it. I ended up pouring it into a glass, just because I had to see what it looked like. Definitely murky in appearance, which is apparently how it is supposed to look when fresh. Overall, good yum.

Sweet, with a very broad palate. Has some very dank and resinous flavors from the hops that are met with some slight citrus. I'm surprised that this beer has such a biscuity malt presence, but overall very good.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Thoroughly enjoyable. What else needs to be said? Nice malt balance...hoppy, sweet, complex, beautiful.
J¬íadore cette double ipa, totaly worth the hype! Perfectly balanced. Tellement crisp!

Poured from can. Hazy gold-orange, medium small white head. Wonderful aroma of citrus hops, flowers. Medium body. No alcohol, bit of carbonation. Flavor matches aroma with addition of some malty balance and is pretty intense without overhwhelming the palate. Bitter as expected but not ridiculous. Very smooth. Don¬ít know about best ever or anything but a great beer. Stands out for cramming in all that flavor and complexity but somehow staying really drinkable.

Review 17JUL13
Once again. Here we go. Canned 08JUL13
Looks ugly as ever, but at this point I respect that in it¬ís merit 4. Nice nose with some fruits, resin and lots of herbals 3.75. Flavor is certainly very hoppy without being bitter as fuck, multilayered with the fruits and herbals 4. Medium on heavy with moderately hi carb and an off dry finish 3.75. I think this beer is excellent, but I¬ím not quite sold on the overall exquisite rating it gets here so regularly. I predict this will fall like Pliney in the next few years as the hype dies down (slowly due to distro). 4

Review 05FEB12
Thanks Keith!
3/3.5/4/3/3.5 - 3.53
Pours a cloudy apricot with some off-white foam formation. This falls to a broken sheet of the same. (3) Smells of fruits, resin, pineapple. The nose is a little bit raw and harsh, but not bad. (3.5) The flavor is really nice with a sweetness that is collaborative with the bitterness. There are flavors of resin, pine, mango. Decent enough. (4) Mouthfeel is a bit thin for the style with moderate carb and a dry finish. A little too dry of a finish. (3). This beer is not nearly as wonderful as it was the first time I tried it, maybe it¬ís the fact that I¬íve had it multiple times, or that I¬ím now immune to it¬ís glory, but it is a far cry from the initial tastes I had. Maybe it¬ís the new brewery, whatever the case is, I will likely not be seeking this out again any time soon. too bad. (3.5)

Review: 21SEP11
Dave, you did this. Thanks man.
Can date: not listed, but I know it to be recent.
A: Pours a hazy apricot ale with no domineering head formation, but a night sheet of honey cream foam. Spotty lace.
S: Oh yeah, pine, resin, citrus, pineapple, tropical fruits with a touch of feline urine. Very complex and the underbelly is a sweet malt foundation.
T: Plenty more of what happened in my olfactory: sweetened honey, aggressively bitter with many, many differing fruits on the palate. There are some wood tones as well. This is complex and refreshing.
M: Medium bodied with moderate on hi carb with a semi dry finish.
O: Well, I can see what all the hulla balloo is all about. This beer is hardcore hops and proves its value in my mouth. There have been some discussions about the comparison between pliny and this beer. Simply put, they cannot be compared, they are both outstanding beers with unique and ingenious characteristics which shine to each¬ís own. Simply put: drink this beer, it will make you happy. 4/4.5/4.5/4/4.5 (~4.5)

Nov. 1, 2013; pint can @ Michael¬ís Rest., Sangerfield, NY. Half sampled from can (per brewer¬ís instructions); half placed in tumbler glass. Chewy, well-balanced DIPA. Lighter, unfiltered pour. Minimal lacing. Complex, earthy, bready aroma. High IBUs (more evident drinking from the can) are supported by a sturdy malt backbone. Finish is long & strong. Fabulous brew deserving of the hype. Many thanks to Michael Latreille for the opportunity to preview/sample this.
From the can great citrus hop aroma. Cloudy amber body. Great flavor. Crisp finish. Simply great.
Alcohol is perfectly blended with the powerful aromas, the piny and grapefruit ascents this beer have. Fruity and perfect carbonation. Wish they could sell in Qu√©bec! Easy top 5 of all times for me.

FROM NOTES: July 3, ¬í12
Poured on tap at The Alchemist Brewery into an alchemist goblet. Did I mention it was for BREAKFAST (10:30 AM)! *DISCLAIMER: I am not a huge fan of the hop-bomb, so I did not go into this with big expectations. Most of the highly rated IPA/DIPAs I¬íve had have not lived up to my expectations and left me slightly disappointed. This beer did NOT disappoint.

A: Hoppy, citrusy, maybe even skunky (in a good hop way). Very long lasting nose. 
A: Poured a hazy, murky golden color with a ginormous white head. Excellent head retention and lacing.
T: It is one of the hoppiest beers I¬íve ever had, but at the same time, it is not a hop bomb. Don¬ít know how they do it. Most beers this hoppy are a mess. This is perfect. citrusy. velvety. 
P: Great body. Good carbonation. Oily. 
O: While not a great breakfast dink (LOL), it is better than any other big IPA I¬íve ever had. I picked up a 4 pack of cans while I was at The Alchemist and am scared to drink them because I know I¬íll be sad when I¬ím gone. If you like big IPAs, you MUST try this one.

Golden colour, white head. Aroma of citrus, lemon, hops, grass, hay, passion fruit, apricot, lots of aroma hops. Bitter flavour, but not too bitter. Very fruity. Bitter fruity finish. Very drinkable, very hop forward, just brilliant!!
(From 50cL can, shared @ DDvdK with Ronald. Many thanks joes for giving me this fresh can, so I could try this long time want!)

Went to Vermont to try some regional only beers. This beer was exceptional. The aroma was hop filled but did not prepare me for the hop burst when i took my first drink. A++. This beer would fit nicely in the Three Floyds family with similar aroma and taste.

ivory white head that disappears quite fast. lemon-yellow slight turbid colour. aroma hop, fruits, passion fruit, hint of sulphur. taste like aroma with a bitter finish that is well balanced with some sweet note too. quite dense mouthfeel, medium body and carbonation. ~4 weeks old /thanks for sharing belgBG
Shared at Darkness Day 2013. Incredibly hoppy, refreshing, and drinkable. A great IIPA!

Drinking a beer by Alchemist in and of itself is hilarious because of a certain man who was convinced that he was going to take his hard earned deployment money and invest it into a machine that can turn anything into anything. He said he was going to be turning tires, fucking tires, into gold! He said it was an "alchemist machine." This same guy was put in charge of people¬ís lives. Anyway, this beer is off the chain good. Mind blowing, if you will.  Thanks to TJ for sharing it with me.
Lives up to the hype. Incredibly hoppy and drinkable. Pours a very hazy gold with minimal head. Total hop assault on the senses. Makes me want move to Vermont.

Lauded and respectable. Is it the best IPA ever? No. Is it eminently drinkable? Yep. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2015 Trade from Ready4aHeady. Thanks man!!!! Can poured to tulip so I can see it. Some sediment. This isn¬ít super pretty, but the beautiful creaminess of the head brings the appearance up to a 4. Will go from can next time. Pours a hazy light golden copper color with just under one finger head. Big floral pineapple and grapefruit aromas, sweetness, mango. Yum. Flavor is heavier on the bitter pine up front, some earthy dirt (in a good way), with some beautiful tropical fruit lingering on the palate, and a pretty dry finish. Almost a creamy feel as I get through this. This highlights the tropical hops for sure. Slick mouthfeel but plenty of carbonation to lighten things up. Is this am excellent DIPA? Yes. Did it live up to the hype for me? Probably not. But very nice in a very different way from some other in the style. Would still likely go for Dreadnaught, Hopslam, Pliny, and Enjoy By before this one. But that¬ís pretty good company. I will revisit tomorrow with a fresh palate to make sure, and try out of a can.

Visited the cannery a couple of weeks ago and picked up two four packs and have been slowly enjoying them, out of the can, in a glass, etc...
Cloudy orange-gold with a good sized white frothy head (when poured into a glass of course). Nose was balance of grassy and grapefruit, and the taste was somewhat balanced, but a bit hop forward. Does it live up to its reputation? Not sure, but it is damn good and I put it right up there with Double Jack and Pliny.

Rating #100. Something special for this one. Heady Topper, canned the same day and straight from the source in Waterbury, VT at The Alchemist. Couldn¬ít resist pouring this into a snifter. Pours hazy golden yellow with 1 finger head. Nice lacing. Nose is so unique, like no other hoppy beer I¬íve smelled, and awesome! Aromas are super dank, resin, pine, hops, leaves, sap. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, smooth, with well done amounts of carbonation to balance it out. Taste is resin, pine, sap, occasional peach, tangerine notes, grass, greens, bitter, nice complexity, if there¬ís such a thing as a balanced hop bomb then this is it. Finish is peach, fruity notes, creeping bitterness that takes over the palette but in a good way. This really is a great beer. Love it! (From 10/23 notes)

Cracked a can this evening that is 2months off the line. First burst of aroma is definitely classic grapefruit and pine, with a wet earthy smell emerging as I drink, no yeast/malt on the nose. Bitterness is surprisingly subdued until the end when it merges with a dry finish to give it that oft mentioned drinkability.

Two big surprises: the first is that with all the hops in there, the bitterness is not stronger; most of the hop power is in the aroma and flavor and it almost drinks like a hop elixir. The second big surprise for me is the mouthfeel. This beer has a very round, creamy malt backbone that is not strong but really coats the palate and lets you enjoy the hops for more than just the first second after you sip.

Reminded me a bit of the Denogginizer from Drakes Bay (90ibu) in the balance they maintain with so much hop, but Heady Topper has a superior mouthfeel and finish. The unfiltered quality of this beer may definitely be a factor.

Despite the marketing, I am still rating the appearance: Burnt orange with robust head that dissipates quickly, no lacing. The beer does seem to loose some aromatic intensity when poured into a glass.

Overall, a stellar treat for hopheads. I love it when I find a beer that tries to do one thing really really well and never looks back.

Tried a small sample at a BeerThief gathering. This has been hyped to the limit, so we¬íll see how it works out. We poured these out into glasses (sorry, brewmaster) to limit the spread of disease. The colour was a surprising cloudy yellow. Maybe that¬ís why they want you to drink it from the can. The aroma is hop all over. Grapefruit and pine, back and forth. Taste sensation is mainly sharp. Bitter, but still smooth and moreish. There¬ís a really, really late dryness that makes you want to keep drinking, but alas it¬ís gone. Lived up to the hype!

Can provided by Steasy66 at the Craft Islington. So I¬ím usually a big fan of hoppy IPAs but I¬ím afraid this one just wasn¬ít for me. It¬ís hazy amber with a big white head. In the nose I¬ím detecting a touch of that new sneakers/bug spray aroma, which certain palates seem to pick up in highly hopped IPAs. Loads of bitter grapefruit, tangerine and citrous fruit too. The taste is raw hoppy bitterness and a bit of that new sneakers resin character. The IBU levels are just too high for me. It¬ís too bitter.
Perfection! This is a hop heads dream. If you¬íre an IPA lover this is a must try beer, if you can get your hands on it off course.
Thanks Dave. Hazy gold. Nose is light and floral. Taste is exquisite. A little sweet and slight piney. So good.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Thank you Seth! Holy crap, a beer that lives up to the hype. Somehow they crafted a beer for hop heads that¬ís also incredibly balanced with a creamy mouthfeel. An excellent beer.

As close to perfect as a Double IPA can get. Hugely complex aroma and flavor suggest citrus of all sorts, pine, mango, peach, lychee, and grass. However, the flavor is well-balanced and complemented by a delicately soft yet full mouthfeel and malt profile. The hop character isn¬ít overwhelmed with the bitterness that can characterize some IPAs, allowing the subtleties to be fully appreciated. (By the way, this is the primary reason why Heady Topper is superior than Pliny the Elder even though both are exquisite.) My only critiques are that it needs to be really fresh to be fully appreciated and that it looks a little chunky (due totally to the massive quantities of hops and the nature of the style, not any technical flaw).

Huge thanks to drowland for grabbing some cans for me and my wife. We¬íve been wanting to try this one for awhile. Worth the wait. Cloudy orange-ish pour...just small amount so we could drink in can. Aroma is a wallop of citrus hop, juicy hops, lemon, and dank earthiness. The taste is super balanced with carbonation and playful, changing hop profiles. Nice sweet maltiness as well. The bitterness and citrus lingers. Superb.

Incredible IPA, balanced journey through several distinct hop varieties returning to a slightly hop forward finish that refreshes without staying overly bitter. A great find, an experience worth having.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fresh can from the wonderful Leighton. Hazy amber with lasting white head. Big fresh grapefruit hop aroma. Soft carbonation. Yes there is some alcohol presence. Flavour is pretty damn good. Amazingly drinkable. Alcohol is a little too present for me. Good bitterness on the finish. Grapefruit and some satsuma flavour. It¬ís good. Not the mind blowing beer that the other ratings suggest. Good though.
UPDATED: DEC 21, 2013 Bottles cheers to Ryan you fucking legend. Wow, what a beer. All my notes say is ¬íholy fuck¬í three times over. That says it all. Unbelievably drinkable stuff. The hype is real

Can. Pours a hazy golden orange/yellow with an off-white head (two figures). Aroma is hops, hops hops, citrus, pine and earthy sweet undertones. Taste is grapefruit, citrus, bitter hops, faint sweet caramel, malt. Very balanced, good carbonation, medium body. Excellent beer - start to finish.

Had this on tap and from cans while on trip to Vermont this summer. Pours a hazy amber with a white head. Nose is of pine and citrus. Taste is of grapefruit and lemon with some caramel malt. Mouthfeel is bitter but not overly so and resinous. This is very smooth for a DIPA. Well balanced.  Goes down easily. I could definitely make this my go-to brew if I had it available locally. Fantastic brew! Great drinking experience.

Can. Poured just enough in a Whiskies of the World sampling glass to get a color; pours an attractive hazy honey with a very light, creamy white head. Nose is intensely herbal and citrus -- grapefruit, rosemary, fresh sage, tangerine, and lavender. Amazing on the tongue; well-balanced, bright, hoppy, and perfectly integrated, with citrus heat following the hops punch and closing with a delicate browned-sugar malty sweetness. Finish is long and camphorous. Yeah, worthy of the hype.

Can from 4 pack. Lucky to get at Craft Beer Store in Southampton. Drank one from the can and one in tulip glass. Aroma is all West Coast hops. Citrusy. Taste is beautiful hoppy resin. Not bitter. Slightest of alcohol on back end. Very good beer. Hazy from all of the hop additions. Good DIPA, but I still prefer PTE better. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can, thanks to Amager crew at Borefts. Amber colour with white head. Very hoppy and malty aroma, with some caramel. Hoppy and sweet taste, maybe brown sugar. Medium body.

10/10/2013. From can, and even though it clearly says to drink straight from the can, I had to pour it into a glass. Hazy light amber color with a white head. Pine aromas with citrus, hops, malt, grapefruit. Very hoppy flavors that just won¬ít go away. A masterpiece of a beer.

A: Hazy Golden Straw/Orange Hue, Passes Some Light, White Head, Some Lacing

S: Oranges, Citrus, Floral

T: Floral, Citrus, Oranges, Orange Zest

M: Decent Carbonation, Medium Bodied, Semi Drying, Semi Sweet

Overall, an outstanding DIPA that has a great nose and taste and doesnt burn you out.

Very small pour just for appearance. dark orange with a small white head. Nose is all hops. Very floral and resinous with citrus and some tropical fruitiness. There is a slight bitterness present. Mouth has a ton of resinous/piney hops with a very subtle hint if tropical and citrus. A lot of grapefruit. There is a slight bitterness present again, but the use of bittering hops was minimal. This beer was so smooth with an intense hop bite that remained sharp an hour after cracking the can open. This one will get my 3rd perfect rating for sure.

Pours a cloudy golden with an orange hue, white fine foam. Very full hop aroma with a flowing combination of grapefruit, resinous pine dominant with tropical fruit accompaniment. Mouthfeel is lightly creamy, slightly tacky with a bit of oiliness at the edges. Finish is slightly sweet, bits of pepper, light astringency and some bitterness. Overall a very nice beer. Especially appreciated the full aroma however the mouthfeel and heft seem to detract slightly from the wonderful hop experience.

Opened the can and the aroma was incredibly inviting. Refreshing floral, citrus, and a trace of resin. First sip hits the palate and it is a medium body, with a creamy, slightly oily texture, average carbonation. The taste is right on the button for an IPA that isn¬ít consumed as a dare (there are many more beers whose bitterness will beat you into submission, this one however is easy to drink without the abuse) Tastes are similar to the aroma, but i assume the yeast provides the interesting but subtle limestone flavor and is absolutely welcome to this party. There is no disappointment here. The finish on this gem can¬ít be mentioned enough... UNBELIEVABLY long finish with wave after wave of citrus hops bombing away at you. Not overly bitter but there is a distinct resiny lingering bitterness which is right on the money. Overall great beer which is 100% true to it¬ís style.
From can @ Borefts 2013, thanks to BRW. Grassy, citric slightly herbal aroma. Pineapple, grapefruit, lemon, oily grassy hops. Very well balanced, very good. Lives up to its reputation.

Can pour...duh...ha, ha, a few months back. HT is a hyped beer that lives up to all the hype. Although not my favorite DIPA, it¬ís definetly awesome. I really enjoyed the floral aromas and the grapefruit, citrus notes were perfect.

Finally. Some Heady Topper!! It's a great DIPA and it certainly lives up to all the talk. Wish I could get my hands on more. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a deep orange almost amber or brown with a frothy off white two finger head leaving supreme lacing down the glass.

Smells of pineapple, tropical fruits and a little bit of caramel. Everything about this beer is fantastic so far.

Strong citrus flavors hit at the front of the tongue balanced out in the middle with some caramel malt. Finishes with a light piney resin bitterness.

A little bit sappy and good carbonation levels.

Fantastic beer. Not the very best of the style I¬íve had, but right up there.
One of the best DIPAs out there. Thanks to tectactoe for the split. Would really like to get more of this.

Can from oregonskibum, thanks a lot for this one!
Hazy yellow with a small head that doesn¬ít retain.
Lots of citrus, ripe mango and pine/resin to the aroma, some candylike sweetness as well.
Taste has a lot of grapefruit bitterness but not as heavy and biting as usually in DIPA, (a nice change for once), resin, nice dryness and slight alcohol heat at the end. Really well balanced for the style.
Dry after taste that leaves you wanting more to freshen up.

16 oz can generously given to me as a bonus in a trade with BrewJay. The pour is a hazy murky orange golden with a one inch off white head that falls noisily and quickly. The aroma is fresh citrus pineapple mango, along with a bit of fruit stripe gum. Some resin is present in the back. The taste is the fresh and bright pineapple mango tropical citrus fruit of the nose along with some sharp bitterness, along with resin, earth and some warming alcohol. The palate is medium bodied with active carbonation and the bitter alcohol sweet ending. Solid double IPA, thanks Jay.

Finally got my hands on some Heady. It lives up to the hype. Great fresh hoppy aroma and taste. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
All I can say is... this is the best beer ive ever had!! Its very bitter yet so smooth. With hints of pine and grape fruit all I can say is... this is the holy grail of ipa
Well well well finally got a chance to try this and wow this lives up to the hype it deserves.

UPDATED: DEC 26, 2013 Fresh can thanks to artmcd8.  Poured cloudy yellow orange with decent head. Nice grapefruit citrus aroma. Quite smooth balanced taste. More resinous then the aroma would suggest.

Can that came as a bonus in a trade, thanks Lukaduke! Chilled this one straight away, it didn¬ít stand a chance of making it through the night. I had a couple of these on a trip to Vermont and was excited to revisit. It certainly didn¬ít disappoint. Is it head and shoulders above other DIPAs or even the best one out there? I wouldn¬ít say so but to each their own. Certainly a prime example of the style. Disregarding the hype, it¬ís a delicious beer that I¬íd always be happy to enjoy.

Wow...what an amazing beer! Thank you Alchemist what an awesome experience! Thank you PhillyCraft for including this as a bonus! Wow it's a great beer! Ok on to the actual review...the reason I gave this a 4.8 instead of 5 is the whole appearance thing...drinking from the can all I saw was the can. The flavor is grapefruit, orange hop goodness! Not too bitter. This beer is amazing. Sometimes I wish I lived in Vermont!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bought from the cannery in Waterbury. Was excited to try it and it didn¬ít disappoint. In fact it is unreal how good it is. Resin, spruce, citrus, grass on the nose, but the body is light, it¬ís dry, it¬ís balanced, alcohol well integrated. Also the most recent one I drank smelled like weeeeed man. It was really pronounced. In any case, it¬ís a delicious beer, I literally have nothing bad to say about it, hence the 5. Buy it when you see it.

16oz can. Poured into a sam glass (against clear instructions on can). Cloudy yellow with a white head and medium lacing. Possibly the cloudiest beer I have ever seen. HUGE hop aroma which surprisingly does not overwhelm the flavors. Yes it has alot of hop flavors, great flavors of grapefruit and pine, but somehow the 120 IBUs do not slap you in the face. There is some magic sorcery going on here. I had to go on a quest to find this stuff as I was driving through the organic state of VT but a quickie mart at a mobil gas station saved the day when I found their last 4 pack. The hype is true my friends. Go north to the green state and seek this stuff out. Possibly the best beverage a hop head could wish for.

(can - 16 oz) Hazy gold pour with a fizzy white head. Rich and sweet citrus hop aroma but not overpoweringly hoppy. Flavor is amazingly smooth and citrusy. The hops are definitely present along with the bitterness but they¬íre balanced out by a strong grapefruit sweetness and a lingering pine resin finish. Definitely not as thick or heavy as I thought it would be. Highly impressed.

I have been fortunate enough to have this beer on several occasions now. For me it is almost the perfect beer. The aroma is incredible...like sticking your nose in a bag of hops. The beer is lighter bodied than you would expect form a DIPA. As the can says "So Drinkable it is Scary".
I hope I am lucky enough to have a few more of these soon.

Perfect DIPA even with hype which normally helps make it disappointing. Big hop aroma, pine and citrus. Smooth fresh hops, bittering mango and pine. Clean aftertaste and smooth mouth feel. Really tasty.

Can at home. A huge thank you to the Legend of man that is Leighton. Drank part of this from a glass and the rest from the can, as per the instructions. What a treat! 

Aroma is punchy tropical fruits, mango and lychee. Later develops some light pine. A little nelson sauvin character in there as well? Aroma reminds me of Punk IPA. 

Pour is translucent / cloudy vibrant orange with a persistent soft whte head. Maybe some hop haze.

Flavour is lovely squishy tropical fruit with pineapple and peach. Bitterness is very firm but clean. Lingering grapefruit bitterness. Some alcohol warmth comes through. 

Palate is full, but not overly stick or cloying. lively carbonation drives those hop flavours forth. 

A very fine example and showcase of hops. Double IPA is often not my favourite style, because of the huge bitterness, but this beer concentrates on the hop flavour and aroma and uses the bitterness in balance. Belief the hype. This beer is excellent.

Well not for the faint or heart easily can over power the most frequent of beer advocate. A lot going on good balance and finish from a very strong hoppy beginning. Leave it for the IPA lovers pass in my book.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a cloudy golden color with a white head leaving moderate lacing. Aroma is overwhelmingly hoppy. The flavor is so well balanced the 120 IBU rating is not a killer. Very smooth with a delicious flavor with notes of citrus, grapefruit and a nice bitterness. Awedome beer.

Aroma what you expect from a top tier ipa. Clean crisp. Grapefruit, citrus notes, hops. Pour was cloudy gold pour, white head. Taste is all there. Grapefruit start, smooth bitter finish. Complex yet enjoyable. Must try IPA. Great.

Can from a trade with a fellow Bar Towel member. Pours an absolute cloudy yellow/ copper colour, white head that dies to a ring, decent lace. Awesome citrus and pine hop aroma, with a touch of caramel. So formal. A little biscuity. Tastes is initially bitter and malt forward. A lot of grapefruit, a touch dryness. Amazing stuff.

This beer is just amazing. Have had it multiple times in a can and poured from a can into a glass. I actually prefer it in the can. The flavor stays longer. Out of the can it is one of the cloudiest beers I have ever sen. The aroma is intense and the hops pop out right away. The beer is just awesome. Major hops on the back end. This is my fav DIPA to date!

Great hops beer. Light color. Strong aromas. Solid finish. In a can! Pours with a slight white head. Not as strong as to overwhelm you but definitely every bit of 120 IBU. a hop lovers dream!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

This is not a balanced beer by any means. If you're a hops lover, this beer certainly celebrates it like no other. It's almost comical and whimsical if I had to think of fundamental words to describe it. When you first crack open the can, you get hit with a sledgehammer of aroma; notes of citrus and pine hit you hardest. With every sip, the bitterness provides for a lingering complexity that makes this beer unique.

I found myself laughing at the experience of the entire first can. Not sure how much of it was the reputation that preceded it, but I enjoyed every sip like a fat kid knee deep in chocolate cake. I only wish it was more easily accessible in NYC. As of the time of this review, it's available exclusively at Uncle Barry's in Park Slope, Brooklyn via Union Beer distributers.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Yellow/orange pour, cloudy, with an average white head that persists. A much more vegetal nose than I would have thought with some citrus notes. About the same on the palate, with a more vegetal vibe than was expected.

To me, the Gold Standard. Beautiful peach, cloudy color. Foamy light head. Aromas of tangerines, lemons, vanilla, a sticky forest floor, and Humboldt-county-kind. Hop forward flavors with citrus, burnt caramel, and mild, balanced bitterness. A nice long finish, still haunting my palate as I type. Makes me warm and fuzzy, happy to be alive! I want to leave the brewmaster in my will.

I don¬ít know if I¬íd really consider this an IIPA. At Mark¬ís Fairport Brew Review. Wow. The most highly anticipated brew of the night. Saved for last. Brought in from out of town, Vermont? This was an extremely unusual IPA, I did not recognize many of the flavors and smells in this. But it is noteworthy that it stood out even after a long night of tasting. Nose - biscuits, grapefruit, and a few more things. Taste is floral, spicy, super dry, really interesting. Very murky. I¬íd previously heard how unappetizing chunky and murky this stuff looked but seriously, I did not mind. Great stuff.

Yeah, its that good. I took my first sip - gulp, really - from the can, as instructed. Smooth, and exceedingly crisp. Smells like (I had put it in a glass at this point) citrus, steel, and caramel. flavor is very hop forward, with notes of pine, citrus, and graham cracker. The best thing about this beer, though, is what it is not. I have grown weary of Double IPAs that overly sweet, syrupy, and heavy. This is crisp, and very in touch the hoppy side of the equation. Very drinkable, as well,. I could be tricked into drinking this like a session beer... Thanks to daknole for the awesome trade bonus!

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2013 Mike gave me this beer. Everyone should have a friend like Mike! Thanks dude you rock! I didn¬ít follow the instructions on the can. Cloudy golden. Dry grainy hoppy nose. Hoppy wheaty and a nice sweetness to go with it. Fresh rich oily hops.

Straight from the can as directed. Drinkable as all get out. It¬ís hop forward, but somehow is malt balanced at the same time. Citrus and other complex hop aromas seep out of the can opening while drinking. Too much of a pain to get these though. Estimated to be consumed 4 weeks after bottling. Please print a bottle date on the can (should be the law in my opinion). I didn¬ít notice much, if any, resin or sediment in the last chug. Awesome beer - but I¬ím a sucker for the local Surly¬ís as THE best.

Un petit bijou pour mon 400e rating. Cannette de 1 pinte. Couleur orang√©e trouble, mousse beige disparaissant en laissant un anneau. Ar√¥me d¬íagrumes, incluant du pamplemousse, de l¬íorange, du citron, pointe d¬íalcool, miel, houblon r√©sineux. En bouche, c¬íest une symphonie d¬íagrumes, de houblon r√©sineux, avec un malt plut√¥t subtil, une amertume persistente et un peu d¬íalcool en fin de bouche. Carbonation moyenne, corps moyen-dense, l√©g√®rement collante. Buvabilit√© incroyable. Tout simplement exquise!

A once in a lifetime beer for me. On a business trip, I met a couple guys at Mekong that had made a beer run to the brewery. They said this can only be bought in a twenty mile radius of the brewery. Well worth the trip. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16 ounce can from Timfoolery, big grapefruit aroma, resinous taste, mildly bitter. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can from my man WillRunForBeer. It says to drink out of the can? I don¬ít know what I should do. I guess I¬íll rate one from the glass and one from the can. From Glass: Pours a hazy yellow- orange with a quickly dissipating head. Aroma of lemon sherbet, some pale malt. Various citrus rind, some dank aromas. Flavor is very citrus, so hoppy and smooth. Quite nice. I would say about a 3.8.

From the can: I cant see what it looks like. Aroma is very dank, very citrusy. Flavor is citrus, lemon, sherbet, lots of peach and tropical fruits. Absolutely delicious. Medium bodied.Yeah, this is a 4.3.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2013 At the brewery. Hazy light orange with foamy white head, not much lacing. Huge hop presence with ripe grapefruit and pine notes. Flavors of mixed citrus, orange peel and grapefruit, nicely balanced malt profile, hardly notice the alcohol... Certainly one of the best DIPAs... Outstanding! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours hazy orange with white head, but no lacing. Aroma of dank and grapefruit. Taste is incredibly smooth with citrus hops and orange peel. Outstanding.

A great smelling and looking DIPA that is worth it if you are able to get your hands on one, or two or three! A solid tasting beer that meet all of my expectations, except for knocking my socks off when I sipped it! A very light golden appearance with a touch of amber, very smooth going down and doesn¬ít have an overpowering hoppy aftertaste like so many DIPA¬ís!

From the can of course. The color is a cloudy pale yellow leading up to a tremendous white head that lingers to the end. Moderate carbonation. The aroma is flagrantly hopped up with esters of orange and grapefruit to boot. Not much malt. The body is medium to full. The taste has only the slightest maltiness but it is overwhelmed by the hops. Yet the hops do not cause me to pucker up like some uber-hopped beers do. Alcohol well-integrated. It¬ís reputation is well deserved but at the same time I don¬ít see a lot of difference between this one and say Smuttynose IPA or Shipyard Pugsley XXXX IPA.
big hop aroma, hazy amber honey color. modest head. huge hop flavor -- hop juice. plenty of hop bitterness, with some solid malt flavor and body. extreme but balanced.

Clearly one of the best if not the best IPA out there. Great appearance, great taste. Lots of hops going on!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can at Windjammer Restaurant in Burlington VT. Pour is a cloudy yellow-gold. The aroma and flavor is dominated by big citrus hops. The body is full and it is amazingly easy to drink for the high alcohol content. Somehow they managed to keep the body relatively light. Good stuff and surprisingly popular among the non-beer-geeks that I was with.

Pours semi-clear yellow. Aroma is peach, grass, pine cones, grapefruit. Taste is peach, grapefruit, kiwi, pne cones. Aftertaste is grass, peach and hop bitterness. Fantastic!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Finally tried this as it was smuggled from Vermont by the local beer shop guru. Dank resinous hop aroma. Copper colored, looks innocent enough. Taste is an extreme pine and hemp mixture of bitterness and sweet burn. Never has an IPA been so effectively nuanced yet palate wrecking. Great dry finish. Supposedly this beer changes each time you try it...time for a road trip.

Can. Pours hazy copper with a decent white head. Aroma is HOPS, floral, grapefruit, citrus, caramel. Taste is medium sweet and very bitter. Awesome, such a deep taste. Very long bitter finish. Full bodied with average carbonation.

No doubt, top 5 beer in the world for double IPA! So smooth for a hoppy ale you will be amazed. Medium to full body. Medium to full hops. Velvet texture. I can drink this all day. Enjoy, if you can find it.

From can courtesy of Ridgewood. 

Yowza - powerful citrus aroma, flavor, and aftertaste. Delicious. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Big thanks to my friend Mike for sharing this with me! Canned 8/8/13. Poured (yes I poured) 8/18/13. Cloudy gold color with a fluffy white head; thick, resilient, great retention. Aroma is floral, citrus, grapefruit, some bread; not incredibly aromatic. Taste is floral, citrus, earthy; interesting finish of bitter fruit rind, a touch of peat and a subtle lingering sweetness. Medium-full bodied. Some astringency. Beautiful lacing. Medium carbonation. 8% ABV not evident. I¬ím torn here. I didn¬ít get all the bitterness, the aromatics, the flavor, just the experience I expected from what is supposed to be one of the world¬ís best IPAs. That being said, it was still quite good. But the hype is not deserved.

I¬ím an IPA fanatic, and this is my favorite. But the hop balance is so perfect and the bitterness is subdued, even IPA-haters find themselves surprisingly pleased by this beer. There may be better tasting IPA¬ís at Hill Farmstead or Alpine if you go on the right day, but HT is excellent week after week. It gets bonus points for the cans, the cool branding, and the year round consistency. It also ages well - I¬íd argue it¬ís best with a month or two of age. All of these things make it the best IPA overall. I love ratebeer and prefer it to BA, but BA is right about this being the best beer in the world.

Can at JF¬ís, big thanks to George from NC for trading me this one!
Hazed golden orange with a good white covering.
Nose is hop forward, pine, dank hops, a little piss, toasted malts.
Taste far outweighs the nose - I can see why they run with the ¬ídrink from the can gimic¬í, the nose is good but not in the same class as the taste !
Taste is bitter grapefruit, hops, pine, grass, caramel malt - all the DIPA boxes well and truly ticked!
Medium bodied with a little bite, fine carbonation, resinous pine and dry grassy finish.
Top draw DIPA - DFTC gimic aside !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text:
Got from a bartenders personal stash. Wrapped the can in a napkin so no one could see it. Knew that it was going to be good after that. Did t pour it so no idea the color or head. First sip is like getting smacked in the face by hoppy awesomeness. Second and consecutive sips are smooth and very drinkable. Need to have this again. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma: Citrus, herbal, subtle resin. Some earthy yeast. Flavor: Tangerine-like citrus, peppery spice, and resinous hop flavors. Nice texture; a little thick, maybe partially from resinous oils. Strong bitter aftertaste. Some bread crust malt flavor once it warmed up a little.

Nothing not to like with this beer for the hop lovers. Pours a pale hazy yellow with a thin head. The aroma has a nice malt sweet base with hops lingering. The flavor has just a touch of sweetness and then the hops come over you. The finish is extremely dry with a long lasting after taste.

Can from Dad that he got from a gracious soul at a concert! Can to wine glass. Pours a hazy light golden with a white foamy head. Aromas of citrus fruit, light pine, slight alcohol, and a earthy note. The flavor is damn smooth and full of dank hops and fruit. Really dinkable dispite the abv and really balanced. A sure winner here!
On tap at the brewery. Maybe it¬ís just the location but this is one of the best IPA I ever had. Rich, balanced not crazy with the hops. They make only one beer, but this is good stuff. Amazing.

Big east coast hop aroma. More substantial caramel malt backbone than most. Pretty bitter and dry finish

---Rated via iPhone

Aroma - Bright citrus, but not piney.

Appearance - Pale, cloudy.

Taste - Exceptional example of the style. Not a hop monster. A taste to enjoy everyday and not be bored. Ever.

Palate - Pleasant mouth feel.

I¬ím glad I finally had this. Definitely met the hype straight on. Drank from the can as directed. Aroma is huge and beautiful. Nicely balanced set of aromas ranging from citrus to pine. This is a mufti-dimensional IPA. I poured a bit and loved the hazy-dazy yellow. Taste is great, less long-lasting than I would have hoped but wow. Palate is crisp, not cloying, and what you want from an 8abv..

Honestly, probably the best colored DIPA I¬íve ever seen. Love the can. Smells just like the brewery (i.e. like magic (hops)). Tastes like Citrus, Pine, and Pumpernickel. One of the best IPA¬ís I¬íve ever had!!

Houblons puissants et herbac√©s au nez, dans un liquide trouble couleur paille. En bouche, √©tonnamment douce malgr√© sa haute teneur en alcool, mais les houblons sont superbement balanc√©s, ainsi que l¬íeffervescence. Les sucres ajoutent √† la complexit√©, et encore une fois c¬íest le dosage des diff√©rents ar√¥mes qui impressionne le plus. Une tr√®s belle IPA √† la hauteur de sa r√©putation, √† la fois rac√©e, puissante et accessible. Un d√©lice.
Wow! Amazing citrus nose. Taste is orange and lemon zest. Terrifically balanced. Very smooth and easy to drink. This is the perfect IPA. I refuse to drink it out of the can though.

Can. Poured to inspect appearance. A hazy yellow golden color with a heavy white head. Smell is beautiful, consists of lemon, grapefruit, tropical, pine, peach and floral. Neither overpowering the other but very distinct. Powerful hop upfront taste with sweet malt background. Tastes of grapefruit, citrus, pine, lemon. Well balanced carbonation, no hint of the booze. Could never have too much of this.

By following the directions on the can I didn't get the full nose but very floral none the less. But oh my this hop bomb delivers on every resinous promise you ever heard about. Flavor lingers like few others. Sweetness and hops. Hop slam in some of its better years delivers like this beer does every can. Drank most of a case over the course of a months time. The flavors developed nicely it became a bit chewy at the end. Great beer from first sip to last. In my top three 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours one of the most beautiful golden oranges I have seen with a thick white head. Aroma is strong pine and citrus, almost like lemon grass with a hint of hops. Taste is similar with a strong citrus note up front, followed by well balanced hops, and finished with a taste of lemon. Excellent and unique IPA.

Bon, bon, bon. Mon ami Louis se pointe chez nous avec un 4-pack de ce produit. Il me la d√©crit de long en large et forc√©ment, lorsqu¬íon cr√©e chez moi des attentes de la sorte, je suis souvent d√©√ßu. Donc, je patiente. Le lendemain, il me demande si j¬íen ai bu. Je lui r√©pond que non et il s¬íimpatiente presque. Je reste clame et ne c√®de pas. √áa me prend encore quelques jours avant de me lancer. Tabou√®re! La lupuline attaque litt√©ralement les voies nasales. Il y a certaines fines herbes fra√Æches, l¬íorigan entre autres, m√™l√© √† de la menthe, √† de la lavande et √† du pamplemousse. Un effet d¬í√©ther nous ram√®ne en vie, ou du moins, nous tient bien √©veill√©. Je savoure l¬íinstant avant de me la mettre aux l√®vres. Sans surprise, c¬íest houblonn√© √† souhait. De la r√©sine de conif√®re qui se m√™le √† du jus de pamplemousse fra√Æchement press√© et √† du zeste de citron en grande quantit√©. Pour employer son expression, c¬íest du jus de houblon. C¬íest de la grande r√©alisation, du grand art ce produit. Faut dire qu¬íelle avait √† peine une semaine, donc, assez fra√Æche. L¬íamertume, quoique intense, est d¬íune gentillesse extr√™me. J¬íai respect√© la notice qui veut qu¬íon la boive directement √† la cannette, mais √©tant donn√© que j¬íen avais plus d¬íune, je me suis permis d¬íen servir une dans un verre pour voir son aspect. Elle est alors blonde opaque et un col de mousse s¬íinstalle √† demeure. Comme un jus Oasis, celui au fruit de la passion. Merci encore l¬íami. (728-060713)

Appearance (4/5)
We broke away from the can¬ís instructions (The Alchemist wants you to drink straight from the can) and poured Heady into our tulip glasses. Right away you can see that this is a can-conditioned beer. The beer is an apricot/gold color that is very cloudy, with a steady stream of carbonation coming up the sides of the glass. Toward the end, there are some little hop floaties and resin particles floating around. 

Aroma (10/10)
The nose is a fruit bomb; there are big grapefruit, tangerine, passion fruit, mango and lemon zest notes in the aroma with some undertones of big resiny hops. There is a touch of a sort of vegetal dankness mixed in there as well. If you¬íre a fan of IPAs in general, this is the type of aroma that intoxicates and makes the drinker salivate in anticipation.

Taste (19/20)
There can be no doubt that this beer has a big, bold flavor profile, and it is clear why this profile is heralded by hop heads around the country as being one of the best examples of the style produced on the east coast. Up front, there are a lot of those same fruit flavors; it¬ís grapefruit and lemon zest primarily, with tangerine, apricot, pineapple, and mango in the background. This citrus flavor up front gets shifted and dried out in the finish and aftertaste, with a heavy dose of hop bitterness punching the drinker in the face as he or she swallows. That dankness from (I¬ím assuming) the Simcoe hops rounds it out and it¬ís an overall great IPA taste. 

Drinkability (4/5)
Heady has a nice mouthfeel, with steady carbonation and a good medium body that works well for a beer of this caliber and alcohol content. If this beer were available locally, I could see myself drinking it in quantity without too much problem (well, excepting the fact that I¬íd get really drunk).

Intangibles (8/10)
The ¬ìproblem¬î with a beer like Heady Topper, and I¬ím not even sure you can qualify it as a true problem, is that it suffers from inflated expectations because of the hype machine that is the Internet. And I realize the irony in that statement, especially because I¬ím technically adding to it right now. While it is without a doubt one of the best double/Imperial IPAs available on this coast, I can extend to the point of saying that it is the best I¬íve ever had. It¬ís in the conversation, though. If you¬íre able to get your hands on one, and you like hops, you owe it to yourself to do so.

Overall (45/50)

Thanks to my cousin Jill for driving across state lines to buy a case. Had about six of these over vacay. All the drink from the can! had me wondering why.
The hoppy aromas are intense upon opening, and very focused. The taste is refined and mellow, and the head dissipates in your mouth, I found this very easy to drink, and the nose somewhat sugary mixed with pinne/resin. I love the cartoon on the silver can. Since I drank it from the can, I can¬ít say what appearance Heady had, but each one left a good buzz afterwards.
This is a treat for all beer lover¬ís to try - at least once! BOOM POW Flavor!

Can. Pour hazy yellow with little head. Smell of a great amount of hops and citrus. Taste grapefruit, hops and zest. This is a fantastic beer. I recommend everyone should have at least one heady. I¬íll want more!

Can courtesy of Gregg657, thanks!
Orang√©e, l√©ger trouble, col cr√©meux blanc/blanc-cass√©.
Ar√¥me est une belle claque au niveau des houblons, et vraiment ce que j¬íentends par une bi√®re de style IPA. Notes tropicales, fruit√©, pamplemousse, note de pin et s√®ve. Malt l√©ger caramel.


Palais est complexe, et en effet les houblons d√©bordent de toutes parts.
Le caract√®re est √©pais, huileux, presque liquoreux de alpha, s√®ve avec une belle p√©tillance et certaine robe onctueuse √† chaque gorg√©e.
Profil de grains, et des houblons offrant √† la fois un cot√© r√©sineux, pin, agrumes; pamplemousse, herbac√© avec un fini l√©g√®rement huileux.
Les malts restent en retrait mais suffisamment pr√©sent pour rajouter un c√¥t√© grains qui est appr√©ciable.
On se retrouve vraiment face √† un concentr√© de houblons qui explosent en bouche dans un feu d¬íartifice de saveurs. Dangereusement facile √† boire.

Superbe bi√®re, et dans ce domaine, les belges ont encore un tr√®s long chemin pour arriver √† ce niveau, ou du moins avoir la demande pour ce genre de bi√®re.

Straight from the can. Smells fantastic, with pine and grapefruit and lemon - it's all hop. Tastes like it smells, plenty of citrus hop with a piney finish that's not overpoweringly bitter. What makes this an amazing dipa is that it manages a hop wallop without being excessively bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2015 Pours murky yellow with low frothy white head. Aroma of pine, citrus, passion fruit, papaya, light grass, honey melon. Taste is very balanced fruit sweet and hop bitter with a gentle but long bitter and slightly perfumey finish. Body is light and slick with soft carbonation. A very drinkable DIPA, but Pliny is still #1!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

30 July 3013, bottle. Yellow and a bit hazy. Nose is big grapefruit. Thin body and moderately fizzy. Pine hops and passion fruit. Decent but not amazing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16oz can. Pours a deep golden color with one inch thick dense frothy white head that fell quickly to a ring. Smells very heavily of pine hops; very dominating. Also smells of citrus hops, grape fruit, tropical fruit, and faint, sweet fruity malts. Hint of floral hops. A very nice mix of pine and fruit in the smell. Tastes of citrus and grapefruit, fruity malts, piney hops and a hint of floral hops. Some nice bitterness. Medium body and moderate carbonation, very easy to drink.

Wonderful floral, hoppy aroma. Not extremely bitter. Perfectly balanced. Blah blah blah blah blah blah extra word requirement blaw blah blah.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks so much to Tom for this beautiful can of elusive goodness from vermont.  

Pours a murky banana yellow with an orange hue and is not as ugly as everyone said.( I think) It has some floaties in it but no matter. Bone white head of foam that fell pretty fast to some decent lace. Pine and earth. Nose is pounding citrus. Pink grapefruit, and pungent with tropical notes. Stone fruits too, mango, apricot and peach. The malt is not heavy on the nose but there is plenty of honey to tempt and tease. It¬ís drippy, and sticky with it and I can¬ít wait to taste it. First sip is powerful grapefruit, enamel stripping hops with a forceful bitter that lays itself in to stay for a while. Pine resin and bitter. All the tropical fruits are flashing in evidence on the nose and on the palate. They all are there. I won¬ít make a list. The malt is thick with honey and balanced so well that you hardly notice it except for the sticky sweetness and the fact that it lends substantial body. A bit of spice to bite you and an almost imperceptible edge that is sharp like crushed aspirin. That edge is just a little sour.  

Holy god almighty. More!

A tasty, if mild, IPA. The body is a hazy lemon meringue color, and the aroma has citrus and grassy hop qualities. The flavor has more of that lemon I saw in the color, but it might have been psychosomatic. I also picked up on other sweet citrus, like tangerine and pineapple, and a bready malt foundation. Most of these hard-to-find IPAs don¬ít live up to the hype the first time I have time, even Pliny the Elder underwhelmed me the first time. But the second sampling is always better, so I look forward to the day I have another Heady Topper. As it is, this isn¬ít quite what I look for in an Imperial IPA. Keep in mind, of course, that my palate tends toward the sledgehammer approach of beers from Stone, etc.

NOT from the can. Beer is drunk from glasses, short of Steins.  Thick, whipped cream-like head, stable, yellowish, over fully hazy peach-coloured beer. Resiny, citrussy hops exploding out of the glass. Nectarine,lunaria, grapes, grapefruit. Bitterish, quite resiny, but with a truckload of balancing sweet malts. Yeasty esters, straw, shortbread. And some hopoils... Fully accomplished balance, yet a flavourbomb. Yeast/grist filled, very slick, oily, creamy MF. Resins keep coming into the aftertaste. Archetypal - but outstanding - DIPA.  Many thanks to M & L !

Pours a golden amber with a two-finger off-white head. No "floaties" that many reviewers speak of. Nice lacing. A complex and unique aroma. Redolent of pine, tropical fruit, citrus, and earthiness; the kind of earthiness you experience walking through the parking lot of a Grateful Dead concert (for those old enough to remember the Dead). As it warms, there's a wonderfully faint floral aroma. Through all those hops one can still get a whiff of the sweet malt! Incredibly complex. The taste is very juicy, more fruit than pine. Tropical fruit hits the tongue first followed by citrus, mainly grapefruit, and dried apricot. Lots of caramel and biscuity malt flavors balance this hop bomb perfectly. Full bodied with the perfect amount of carbonation. Overall, this is my highest rated beer and my favorite beer yet. Truly worth all the hype (and the aggravation to get it)!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Appearance:
Soft cloudy oranges under a bready white head which lingers long and full.

Nose:
A bit thin. Lemon and grapefruit rind held together with pine while hop oils pool in the middle. Table crackers along the edges and underneath. Orange oils.

Palate:
Dry and parching which I found to be a minor deterrent to the veracity of the flavors within. Biggest flavor punch in the middle with lemon and orange oils, hop resins. Table crackers underneath. Pine needles and Christmas trees.

Final Thoughts:
For all the rave reviews and online hoopla regarding this particular IPA, I was expecting a bit more oomph. Was it good? Yes. Was it awesome? No. Nonetheless it is definitely worth a try or two for those who love their hops.

(An original written work by Beer Ambassador, LLC. Plagiarism is not tolerated.)
Travelled to the cannery in Waterbury VT. Complex hops aroma, citrus, pine. Bitter but not over the top. Excellent finish, the bitterness stays with you.

From the can thanks to a good friend of mine, who kept this delicious beer safe from Vermont to Chicago. Aroma was fantastic. I opened the can and was punched in the face with grassy, floral goodness, with notes of spice. Taste was so satisfying. Booze was nicely hidden by the bitter notes, but definitely wasn¬ít overbearing. The one thing that stuck with me was the crisp and clean palate. It reminded me of fresh spring water, but not in a bad way at all. Great beer.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2014 CAN at home. Shared with Mathieu87.
APPEARANCE: clouded blond beer, small unstable white head.
NOSE: pepper, hops, fresh. Very good nose!
TASTE: hoppy, some alcohol, quite heavy.

No real appearance, since I took the suggestion and drank directly from the can. However, I popped the top, and it immediately smelled like I was in the middle of Shenandoah Valley. One of my favorite places to go hiking/camping with my dad. Heady is clean, slightly piney, sweetly floral, and rather bright in aroma. The taste is really light for the 8% ABV. A great hop presence on the tongue, and sweet/bitter combination from the malt/hops. Surprisingly, the piney-ness of the hops isn¬ít bothering me. I typically don¬ít like that in my IPAs, and tend to stick towards brighter/more tropical offerings. Short duration on the tongue, which is making me drink this beer faster than I normally would have. My first HT thanks to a trade.

Can. Thanks d! Pours a cloudy medium amber with a dense and creamy tan head. Big grassy nose, balanced and sweet. Creamy medium body with lively carb. Darkly toasted caramel with grassy herbal hop notes. Lots of dimensionality to the hops, but no harshness.

Canned 568ml. -Courtesy of luttonm, shared with him and Marko. Hazy orange coloured, medium sized off-white head, intensive fruity hoppy nose. Moderate malty, strong earthy hoppy, quite fruity and light herbal. Bitter hoppy finish. Lots of hops overall.

16 oz can 2 weeks old.
big hop nose, Very floral and a slight citrus tinge. Small sweetness in the smell. Pours golden, hardly any haze, medium white frothy head. its a sweet malty taste at first, the the piney, citrus and bitter hop flavor, but not over barring. very smooth and well balanced. Not boozy or under hopped. Overall a very solid DIPA. One of my favorites. But doesn¬ít beat out pliny.

I can see why they only make one thing. As advertised this is not a palate killer. It's nicely balanced and fantastic. Drink it. Drink it now!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can shared by a friend. Chunky gold pour with a medium off-white head. Aroma of piney hops, spicy hops and some maltiness. Malty flavor at first, then a burst of pine before a grassy hop finish. Solid, but not quite up to the hype.

So drinkable it¬ís scary. I had to stop myself from drinking the whole can in about a minute. Smooth like nobody¬ís business. As the can says, it¬ís not the most bitter, just a perfect beer. Worth of the hype.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2014 Smells of floral, citrus like hops. Almost get a hop oil type smell. Great aroma! Taste grapefruit like hoppiness, not the piney bitter finish, more citrus hoppy. Well balanced. I would say this is my favorite IPA for sure! Maybe slightly malty, but only slightly if at all.  EDIT:  have some still in my fridge after 2 months. Citrus and grapefruit flavors are noticeably less. This is one you really need to have fresh. Still good, but not as good---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can

Appearance: UNK (from can)

Aroma: Intense fresh citrus, grapefruit

Taste: Grapefruit, pine needles, bitter, but not in an off-putting way

Palate: Pine, resin finish. Coating mouthfeel. Feels like it¬ís going to finish extremely bitter, but ends up being nicely balanced and slightly sweet.

Overall: Great drinkability for a DIPA. Great, extremely intense flavors.

UPDATED: JUL 10, 2013 The beer that turned the tides. Was not much of an IPA fan until this little master piece. Taste was amazing very much citrus and hoppy but not overwhelming. This beer had the right amount of everything that made me want more. This beer is by far a game changer for those just getting into IPA¬ís or not a fan of them altogether. Cheers!

Can. Thanks canon. Can't comment on appearance but upon opening it, it reminded me of opening a bag of hops but access able immediately. I just want to keep sucking it down which is the downside of leaving it in the can. You are in the habit of chugging canned beer. Must attempt clone of this. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks to Ben. Murky dirty orange pour with an off-white head. Aroma is hops-spicy. Taste is a mouthful of hop juice. Very tasty. Little creamy. Hop is flavorful but not overbearing. A Ver-montsterous of a beerI am so glad I finally got to try this. Costant hop mouthfeel. OK lacing.

Can. Poured a small amount to get a visual. Poured hazy gold with a thin white head. Aroma is huge citrusy and tropical hops with a touch of pine at the finish. Taste follows the same pattern with a strong malt backbone. Palate is rich and rounded but finishes with a prickly carb. This is just about perfect. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Honestly a huge pain in the ass to get ur hands on this one !! But after having it one would understand why that is. Quite simply the finest ipa on this planet imo I drink ipa¬ís exclusively and it is sad too think I only have one of these left ! I know this is being called a dipa but imo more like an ipa the 8.0 abv is higher than what is considered a ipa. All in all wonderful grapefruit taste and a hop lovers dream it is the best I have had better than surly furious and at least a tick above lunch and jai alai. Simply delicious.

Luttonm¬ís "special beer" at the tasting. Enormous thanks Matt! I seem to have forgot to note the appearance, damn. ?Cheese? maltiness and aroma hops in the nose, slightly sweet... The taste... orange, earthy/resinous as fuck, malty, light carramel (or was it carrot?), nice and sweet, with very light tart notes here and there... I did note the appearance it would seem, yay! - Murky golden. The earthy/tree sap/resin notes grew and grew and grew on me. Initially slightly underwhelmed, in the end I was a believer. Not your typical I2PA and all the better for it.

Thanks to a friend for the hook up. This Double IPA is currently my favorite to date. Drinking such a tasty beer from a can engulfs you with constant hits of citrusy, earthy and floral American hop flavors and aromas.

The key to this beer is definitely "balance." All hops up front without being fussy or annoying in a very easy to drink package. Unfortunately it was so easy to drink I realized I¬íve drank half of the can in no time. 

Heady Topper to me is a celebration of craft beers, a quality beer that has taste and aroma that should be drank and enjoyed as much as possible rather than be seen as a mystical beast.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2014 Poured from the can. Aroma is very strong, lots of floral hops. Pours a nice golden color and white head. Taste is very strong hops that take over the more you sip it. This is my favorite DIPA to date.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2017 Very citrusy on the nose. Pours a cloudy light orange. Very very light with a nice citrus hop bite. Really refreshing for a DIPA.

Re-rating:

Intense grassy hops on the nose. Pours a cloudy light orange. Extremely light bodied but with intense flavor. Medium to high bitterness with smooth hoppy flavor.  Very easy drinking.

Color of the inside of a kumquat, slightly opaque with not too much sediment. Citrusy; pairs well with watermelon. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Had as a taster at the brewery. They were in the middle of an active boil at the time and the smell of malt brewing and 6 kinds of hops filled the air completely (and I¬ím a homebrewer and LIKE the smell of brewing beer but this was too much in such a confined space). The aroma of the boiling beer effectively prevented an accurate tasting of the beer and I¬ím afraid it wasn¬ít in a good way. My review therefore is probably skewed low and my tasting notes reflect the aroma overwhelming my tastebuds. azy golden color, lemon nose, hard to pinpoint aroma, happy, but brewery openness is making it hard to tell, just a crap-ton of hops. To me they are just fighting with each other. Citrus and pine and astringency are all fighting with each other.
UPDATED: APR 17, 2015 Can thanks to GT2¬ís friends. Aroma is very hoppy, and pour is gold with nice white head. Hints of grapefruit. Overall good brew!

Can (pint). This is one awesome double ipa - one that impressed me more with each drink. Powerful hops and grapefruit? Cirtus finish. I absolutely loved this beer. Only had one so will need to try again. Big fan
