Burk ca 3-4 v. Pigg tallkotte och terpentin i doften. Bra balans. J√§mf√∂rt med g√•rdagens Pliny s√• n√•r den h√§r inte upp till riktigt samma niv√•. Beska i harmoni med s√∂tman. (Thnaks Biggsbowler)
Can shared graciously at Andy¬ís corner Bar. An excellent beer with an outstanding balance if hops and malt.

Got these in a trade from FooFaa. I¬ím very appreciative. Going to save one of these for the finish line of the Peachtree Road Race. Pours a hazy orange gold pear color. Smell is all pine. Nice bitter front end. Great beer, my only complaint is that the finish could be just a touch sweeter. Can - Trade from FooFaa

Can, shared generously by Ferris (I just found my notes on this on my iPhone!). Golden colour, heavy, frothy peristent head. Resinous piney hop profile, lots of oily hops in here to be certain, with not-too-sweet malts in support. Really excellent to be sure, but I¬íve had fresh Stone, and Ballast Point and Port Brewing products on tap that were jut as good or better. Obviously freshness is a key factor here, so I will definitely revisit this beer if ever the opportunity presents itself.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: UPDATED: OCT 16, 2013 Can at home via Dusseldorf! Many thanks to Rian (Thirstybird) and his wife Lara who brought it over for me. Slightly hazy gold with a lively white head. Huge hoppy nose of pungent tropical fruit and pine. Smooth, natural carbonation. Perfectly integrated bitter/sweet flavour with sweet juicey malts and  citrus fruity hoppiness. By far the best canned beer I¬íve ever sampled. Superb!

Great complex double ipa that isn't boozy like many double ipas can be. Even better on draft. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Okay, so this is my second Heady experience. My first one was during a bottle share with a good friend of mine, and what followed felt magical. I couldn¬ít believe the flavors I was tasting, and feeling, and comprehending.

Now, 8 months or so later, I got my hands on a second can (thanks to the same friend), and just cracked it this morning. I finally ventured to pour a small amount into a glass (completely against the very big and bold instructions on the can to ¬ìDRINK FROM THE CAN¬î) But, I just had to see what it looked, felt, and tasted like out of a snifter. I was a little disappointed to say the least. I¬ím glad that it tells you over and over on the can to drink from it, because it was really pale in color, with a light IPA flavor to it. NOTHING like the powerhouse I had remembered¬Ö Thankfully I had just poured 2-3 ounces. 

So, now that I was following instructions and drinking from the can, my second taste of this amazing elixir was just as memorable as the first. It is an incredibly resin-y beer with just absolutely incredible hop flavor. The resins coat your tongue BUT beg for more at the same time. The flavors dance on your palate for just long enough that you need more. This beer, at 8% is crushable, but also begs to be sipped, savored, and enjoyed. They tell you to drink it fresh because they¬íre always making more¬Ö but an 8 hour drive isn¬ít in the cards all the time.

The Alchemist, you brilliant, brilliant brewers. You sell over 90% of your product from your own brewery¬Ö. And I know that you know you¬íve made one of America¬ís best beers. And I know that you are proud of it¬Ö and you should be. This gem is to be savored, enjoyed and drank straight from the can. Do it, don¬ít even consider pouring this into a glass¬Ö just drink it from the can. Lick your lips, say ¬ìahhh¬î and beg your friends to get in their cars and go buy more.

Hazy orange with some white head. Kind of a muddled aroma of orange apricot pine and booze. Plenty of bitterness, but no other real stand out characteristics. A bit on the heavy side. Good, but there are many I¬íd rather have.

Enjoyed from a friend who got this from his boss, happy to try this! Appearance bright cloudy gold with rich frothy white head. Aroma I'm not getting much, probably since I have a cold. Taste is fantastic, orange peel, grassy, light lemon, but aggressively hopped with a great bitterness. Extremely drinkable as the can says. This is definitely great, not sure if there's one thing that defines how it's great, just everything coming together.
UPDATED: OCT 11, 2014 Amazing. Weed smell. Resiny pine, grapefruit combo is intense but balanced. One of the best DIPAS ever made. (if not the best)

The hype of this beer made me want it. Got it on a beer trade from a bloke in nj. Opened the can and dug my nose in it... So delicious. Super hop aroma and pine. Put a chug in my mouth and swished it around like scope and put it down. Then came. Nothing more.

Well I got to finally try one...can at a bottle (can) share in Boca Raton, FL. Small snifter. Pours light in color with significant sediment. A hazy yellowish pour. Very light head. Very potent hop aroma of pine and pine resin along with grapefruit. Balanced very well with the malts on the taste. Mostly a pine and floral taste along with citrus. It didn¬ít seem to be an 8%. Finishes dry and clean.

this is a very good.  that being said, it is very expensive for what it is.  i have had better beers but i do enjoy me a heady when i am feeling saucy.  great on the nose, super floral, and not to sweet like most double ipa¬ís can be.  if you don¬ít have an ipa glass, keep this beer in the can.  it really makes a difference.
Very well balanced double!  Not too heavy and not too hoppy - perfect.
UPDATED: NOV 6, 2015 Huge hoppy aroma of pine and spice , very sweet. Big sweet citrus and resin hop flavor, well balanced. Wow wow wow.
Can: Hazy gold color with a white head.  Super dry aroma of pine needles, grapefruit.  Super hoppy flavor that is really well done.  Dry bitter aftertaste.  Big body and full of flavor.

Can pour cloudy orange wit lots of sediment and floaters.   Nose pine, floral and resin.  Taste initial grapefruit bite, pine ,resin hops all balanced by a sweet backbone and bitter finish.  Very good.

Can shared generously by Max at tasting. Pours hazy apricot-hued yellow with thick foamy head. Aroma is outrageous; this is the best smelling IPA I¬íve ever encountered. Lovely aroma of grapefruit with notes of lemon and lime zest and tropical fruits. Just heavenly. Taste is lots of hoppy citrus pith, grapefruit juice and light pine. Great balanced. Terrific finish. Definitely lives up to the hype.

Canned love!!!

Hazy, orange yellow color. One finger head that falls to a thick collar leaving a solid ring of soapy lacing. Vibrant carbonation. 

Citrus and citrus nose. Tangerine, grapefruit, grapefruit, lemon, lime, mango. Holy crap. 

Tropical fruit bowl taste. Touches of malt backbone. Hops sing in harmony with this.  High acid but not overly bitter. Complex mother.

Long lasting candied citrus feel. Perfect carbonation. Oily, dry and just touches of sweet.  Brilliant, just brilliant
Pours hazy yellow into glass. Clearly unfiltered and loving it. Nice hop nose - citrusy grapefruit tangerine and lemon. Taste citrus and resiness but very balanced and easy to drink. Lovely beer

Pours a hazed yellow.... nice lacing and retention.

Wow... the nose is pretty damn good... citrus zest... grapefruit... tangerine... maybe some lemon.... balanced just slightly by a light pale malt presence.... smells very fresh and very yummy.

Big bitterness up front quickly moves to a palate blast of citrus hops that have a touch of pine in there.... even some tropical fruitiness is accentuated by a slight pale maltiness... very good.

Body and carbonation are spot-on for the style.

Pretty damn good.... If I could get this regularly, it would be a fridge staple.
Aroma is strong american hops, citrus and dank.  Taste is strongly bitter up front, more American hop flavor and some caramel sweetness.  Finish is pretty bitter.

I find that the best IPAs are the ones that impart all the goodness that is IPA while still being smoothly drinkable. And that's what you get here. Cloudy pour (still haven't figured out how that affects flavor in an IPA, but there you go), with strong pine and citrus notes. And the lingering backend is all IPA bitter -- hence the high IBU. But the middle is where this beer shows its beauty. Hoppy flavors of pine, some resin, and some citrus come through on a good, unsweet malt base. This is pure hops, without gimmicks. Seems easy enough but harder to find than you might expect. This beer is thusly recommended!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2013 Can, shared with friend and wife, poured into glass because I¬ím a rule breaker. Big citrus aroma - grapefruit and orange, packs huge citrus punch. Can smells basically like fresh hops. Pours hazy yellow/gold. Taste big citrus deliciousness. Well balanced, with some sweetness to go with the citrus. Even though it packs a hoppy punch the bitterness is surprisingly well-integrated and not even remotely harsh. Medium body, average carbonation, slick texture, long finish. Overall: initial assessment was "this is damned tasty, but no need to trade my firstborn for it - good double ipas abound out here." then we followed it with the freshest batch of stone enjoy by 7/4/13, which hit the shelves today, and which was practically a revelation for me regarding fresh, great ipas when I had it last time around. Directly following on the heels of heady topper really drives home that heady topper is in another league. Yeah, different flavor profiles and all, but I didn¬ít expect anything could make stone¬ís offering taste bland and tame by comparison. Actually a good combo for me - wanting to keep open mind, rejecting the hype, then getting a second look that showed me a glimpse of where it¬ís coming from. Damn fine brew. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Citrusy a tad sweet and not very bitter. Honestly never had an IPA like it, in a good way! Very easy to drink. One of my favorites in the world!

Can courtesy of jercraigs & mabel. Yeah, I drank a few mouthfuls from the can as suggested, but then I poured the rest into a glass - sorry, my snobbery got the best of me. Lovely hazy-orange with a big white head and some sparkling floaties. Aroma is ridiculous, like smelling a handful of fresh hops - pungently floral and fruity, with notes of pine, peach, orange peel and heady herbs. Flavour is obviously heavy on the hops - OK, that¬ís a bit of an understatement - bit it¬ís not aggressively bitter or astringent like many hop-heavy beers. The hop character is rounder and more complex - there¬ís the expected citrus and pine, some papaya and passionfruit, a bit of orange blossom honey, some zippy spiciness, and a long, palate-coating finish of grapefruit peel and hop resin. I was skeptical that this would live up to the hype, but goddamn, it surely did!

500 ml can from czar - thanks mate. I did pour some of it into a glass, but as suggested, drank most straight from the can. A very hazy orange-brownish gold with a resilient, whitish-yellowish head. Aroma is tons of floral, citrus, herbal and spicy hops. Flavor is fruity, fresh cereals, malt, citrus, tropical fruit. Finish is very bitter, lots of citrus, somewhat floral and accompanied by a touch of spice. Lingering floral, fruity, pine tree and mint flavors. Medium body, sticky mouthfeel, average carbonation. A very, very solid Double IPA, taste fresh, like I was biting straight into fresh hops.

The IPA!  In a class all it's own!  All others want to be it!  All of us want to drink it!  The Alchemist needs to increase production a couple thousand percent please!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can courtesy of Tommy as en extra, thanks man!! Shared around the fire right after some Pliny, double jack and Mag 7. Nice golden pour, there were litterly chunks of goodness  floating in each glass. Great smell lots of pine, the taste was Lemmon and very crisp. Really enjoyed this

Canned on May 27, 2013.
Appearance: The body is amber colored with murky clarity, some sediment is floating around, nothing can be seen through this only the color is noted. The head is tall and messy with great retention, slowly settling into a messy ring and lots of spotty foam on top.
Aroma: The aroma is complex with notes of pine, peach, apricot, oranges, and mango. Very fruity and hinting at some bitterness.
Taste: Peach greets the tongue immediately into a moderate bitterness of pine with some spicy notes. Mango is woven in towards the mid-taste through the finish as the pine mellows out and orange is left lingering with some spice on the finish. Long after the sip, pine sits on the tongue.
Palate: Medium bodied with sharp carbonation, moderate to high levels.
Overall: This is a fantastic imperial IPA. The bitterness isn¬ít harsh, and the flavors are complex. I wouldn¬ít go out of my way to get this again, but when I travel to Vermont I will be picking a case up.
Hazy golden blonde with a generous fluffy white head and tons of floaties. Big citrus and fruity bomb. Clean, fresh, hoppy, fruit salad. Alcohol very well hidden here. Delicious!

Can courtesy of bytemesis, thanks! Heady Topper certainly lives up to its reputation. Nice smell, not too strong, of citrusy pine. Orange color, quite hazy. The flavor finds a perfect balance of hoppiness - lots of character without overpowering - and a classic, clean lager-like malt, grain, etc. It is mostly bitter but also sweet and spicy in turns. The aftertaste is remarkable, it makes your mouth feel cleaner, like a beer-based breath freshener. What really sets this DIPA apart is not the particular smells/flavors. It is how deeply integrated all those components are to create something that tastes like it was squeezed from a single plant instead of a bunch of ingredients steeped in water.
A very complex and bitter brew. Lots of pine and citrus. An amazing IPA that is worth the effort to obtain

500 mL can.  (From Rob T via Dave T - thanks guys!)  I poured it into a glass so I could see it.  Sorry Heady purists.  It¬ís pale and really hazy with a small white head.  Now you know.  The huge hoppiness hits your nose as soon as the pour begins.  This is hop juice, plain and simple  There is no attempt at balance here, other than the balance of pine and citrus.  Bitterness is perfect.  Incredibly drinkable for such a hoppy beer.

Pours a cloudy golden with white head and big lacing. Aroma is piney, magos, pineapple. Taste is full of mangos. grapefruits, piney, grassy, good malt backbone without being too sweet. Medium to full body and medium carbonation. Fantastic

Pungent hops, onions, color of dark pineapple juice. Opaque, hazy, tons of yeast sediment. Tastes bitter: grapefruit, heavy pine oil. Juicy feel. This is pretty outstanding. If I didn¬ít have sky high expectations I might even rate it higher.

"Drink from the can!" The Alchemist Heady Topper is amazing. I did just as it said on the can and drank it direct. With that said... I didn't see the pour. It doesn't matter. This beer is amazing. Smells citrusy and piney. Flavor is bold. Hops, pine, lots of citrus. Simply amazing and definitely worth the hype.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Can, fresh.  The pour is a light hazy yellow.  The aroma is big time hops, pine.  The taste is bitter big upfront and continues.  Seems like a hop heads dream come true.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2014 50cl can, American brew, from De Hopduvel Gent, very complex bitter brew, fruity/bitter and slightly floral/woody, very balanced, cloudy, good head, very good brew!, yet expensive! "I couldn¬ít resist rating this (I normally never rate cans); this is indeed an awesome IPA!"

Can from growler.  aroma of moderate hops.  very floral.  pours a cloudy, but not chunky light red with large head.  moderate hop bitterness.  very smooth hop flavor and malty backbone.  overall, a very nice enjoyable beer
Floral nose.  Great head and color.  Fruitier and cloudier than I expected.  Very good, but not great.

Friend shared pint can, poured to stemware with a yeasty cloudiness and orangy hue, a decent layer of cream colored head foam, and wavy lacing. The nose was intensely resiny & grapefruity, with some pleasant, backup tropical notes. Very malty, with a nice creaminess to the mouthfeel. Medium+ bodied, hop bitterness was strong, very lingering, but drinkably under control, with the flavor also presenting some dusty earthiness, a touch of soapiness, and obvious but subdued alcohol. Impressive DIPA!

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2013 Can in trade with phatdog1! Pours a hazy golden orange with dissipating creamy off-white head that webs nicely. Aroma of citrus and tropical fruits. Taste is a slightly bitter menagerie of tropical fruits and citrus with a nice caramel malt back end. Nothing over the top, a nice balance. Great IPA.
Can. Deep golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is peaches, malt, hop, pine, grapefruit. Flavour is peaches, malt, hop, alcohol, pine, grapefruit. Full body. Nice beer.

Can in Massachusetts, thanks so much to my cousin Lauren who saved a couple for me! (and to know that she loves this as much as all of us, is just great). Fantastic aroma, dank, tart hops with vinegar. Body is huge resiny hops. Full, heavy mouthfeel, and heavy acid hop finish. Rich and smooth. This is crazy huge and thick but oddly restrained and balanced in that context of huge dipa. Funky citrus, citrus rind. Sticky sweetness. Crazy good. Rich and tasty. East coast¬ís intense dipa king.. east coast Pliny. Both beers I simply wish I could have more often.
Amazing aroma of pineapple, peaches, and tropical fruits. Taste is fruity with a really well balances bitterness that is quite small for being an Dbl IPA.
A great DIPA one of the best out there.  The only thing I don¬ít like about this beer is the chunks of fish food flakes floating around in it.  Other than that everything about this beer is great.

From the can, obviously but poured into a tulip. Huge, overwhelming aromas of fresh pine, peaches, citrus pith & spicy hops; you could seriously sniff this all day long and not get bored. Poured a cloudy amber orange with a thin head, that dies to a fine lace. Well, I wasn¬ít expecting this......the taste is just so one dimensional with fresh pine, spicy bitter hops...........and then nothing. No linger, no malt to back it up, no hint of sweetness, nothing, nada, zilch. There is just no finish!! It¬ís like drinking a stripped wine. I just don¬ít know what all the hype is about.....oh wait, I do......it¬ís just hype and everyone is on this train.

(can)  The grand finally celebrating 1883 ELCO 30th HS reunion at the Porch in Myerstown.  Drank straight from the can by the recommendation of bartender.  Let¬ís not get too serious.  It¬ís beer, It¬ís fun.   Ultra smooth for this IBU.   Even a novice can appreciate the quality of this fine ultra- hoppy IPA.   The high ABV is well disguised.

Can to flute
Aroma of pine, resin and orange. Cloudy amber with a thin white head. Taste is all hops with a orangey tinge.
Can - Fresh pine and spicy.  Cloudy orange with a thin head.  Taste is fairly one dimensional fresh pine, great on a hot day.  Very refreshing IPA.

Hops hops hops hops bitter bitter bitter bitter clean clean clean clean rare and definitely something to seek in the firure

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

liked it but not sure why rating is this high?  aroma of slight barnyard funk.  nice pour; med -thick palate.  less hops than others in this style - which isn¬ít a negative, but not much really stood out?

Hazy golden amber color. Frothy white head. Clean, slightly sweet malty back bone. Quit a bit of marijuana. Highly drinkable, moderately hoppy very drinkable. So well executed. Slightly off center to the smallest degree.

Zeebra Extreme Beer Festival - Served from a can! Hazy, dark yellow colour. Has a nice ¬ígreen¬í, fresh hop aroma. The carbonation is fine lending to a smooth, creamy feel. Low on sweetness and it¬ís bitterness is not overpowering.

Source : From The Alchemist in Vermont, 1 Pint can.
Appearance : Hazy orange with a nice head.
Aroma : Fresh citrus aroma.
Taste : Hoppy hop hop and bitter.
Palate : Bitter and creamy.
Overall : Wow, this is a great Imperial IPA, I want to open an other.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2013 Bottle at home. Pours a hazy orange with beautiful white head. Aroma of grapefruit, oranges with hints of malty sweetness. Taste is strong bitterness balanced by stunning citrusy sweetness - incredibly juicy. Mouthfeel is notably full. Among the best beers I¬íve tasted.

at zeebra extreme festival
very nice piney aroma. mouthfull beer with lots of alcohol on taste. dry bitter aftertaste

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2013 Hazy orange body, white lace, very nice. Very rich hop aroma, floral, refreshing, grapefruit. All the goodness of American hops. Strong bitterness, enough pale malts to balance a bit. Nothing to be faulted on this ipa, and an amazing aroma. Warming palate. Amazing. (Zeebra)

Pours cloudy copper, healthy frothy head. Nose of heavy citrus and flowers. Lemon stands out, followed by bread and yeast. Very bitter, to me the bitterness and taste of alcohol mask the fruit flavors.  Slight malty on the finish. It seems like the longer I let it sit, the more flavors opened up... However, this beer is just not my type, but it is well made for what it is.

Hard to rate aroma and appearance when drinking out of the can. I imagine from the tiny bubbles on the rim of the can its a beauty with some sediment at the end. But this is what an everlasting pineapple hop iced tea tastes like. Always a treat.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2015 RE-RATE 
Fresh can. Much more expressive tropical fruit than the first time I had it. This is God nectar and I no longer question its cult like following.  
Pours a hazy orange with a shit ton of floaties. Aromas of freshly squeezed oranges and lemons, sharp pine needles. Taste is creamy, bitter, round hop juice. Finishes dry with a bitter twang. Meh. Not the best I¬íve had, but still good.

Thanks to Nikki for this can. Pours a cloudy golden with a foamy warm cap and dirty lace. Typical American IPA nose that is pretty hoppy. Thick mouthfeel with well-hidden alcohol. Still hoppy for taste, but just a little more tamer as the alcohol takes care of thing. Lots of good fruits also show up. Grapefruits, oranges and other citrus. Goes down very well for an Imperial IPA.

Une apparence assez ingrate (son seul d√©faut!):orange terne et particule en suspension. Mousse qui colle bien au verre. Pour les aromes, c¬íest le plaisir total: houblon r√©sineux en profusion, de l¬íagrume, un peu d¬í√©pinette, mangue, peche, etc. on se sent sous les tropiques. En bouche, c¬íest rond, moelleux et une amertume tout en √©quilibre pour l¬íibu; longue finale d¬íagrume non agressante. Tr√®s buvable

As others have mentioned as soon as you open the can a smell of peaches, citrus fruits and bitter hops just resonates. The taste is phenomenal, it¬ís almost as if your chewing on a hop. The taste is amazing citrus juicy juicy citrus. This is my top IIpa!

As you open the can, the aroma is superb; citrusy, aromatic and hoppy bitterness all evident. The only knock on this is for the appearance as I enjoyed this treat from the can as the instructions suggest. Oily on the tongue; taste and residue linger for the perfect amount of time. Alcohol is virtually non-existant. Perfectly balanced and smooth. Hands down the best IIPA I¬íve ever had. Ever. Wish it was easier to get my hands on aside from rare road trips north. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Can(big thanks to ThirstyBird!): Deep golden sith an orangey sheen, hazy, some floaties visible, mid-sized persistent off-white head, pineapples and grapefruits in the solid herbal-hoppy nose, some tropic sweet fruits underneath; moderate to solid bitter-sweet flavour, medium to full bodied and pretty soft; lingering - hops still sticking to the palate - grapefruity-tart finish, some malt as a counterpart still present. A nice pleasure
Can shared by Austin - thanks.  Pours a bright gold with white head.  Nose is sharp hops, pine; flavor follows with grapefruit and malt.  One of the best IPAs I¬íve tried.

Heady pours a unfiltered, cloudy gold appearance. Yes, I poured it out of the can into a glass. Warms to a fruity jolly rancher aroma, piney undertones with citrus bergamot adding complexity. Cream soda like, big juice body, nice bitter mid section finishing dry. Freaking delicious.

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2013 Bitterness, malt, tropical sweetness and floral notes come together at the perfectly harmonized levels at the right time, gentle bourbon, little weed taste. 
No taste sticks out like a sore thumb.
Absurdly drinkable for a substantive beer. At $12/can it¬ís pricey but extremely enjoyable. That¬ís my biggest complaint..and it is a big one. Hard to get and expensive, but that¬ís Alchemist¬ís right to limit their distribution but I don¬ít have to like it.
This is a must try for any aficionado and aspiring brewer. This is an example of perfect brewing execution.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2016 Far out - this is the Robocop of beers. Clean cut, honest, but ruthlessly efficient. Huge citrus, tropical fruit nose. Super clean body, lots of big hops, well balanced, though this is an unabashed hop monster. A tad sticky. Dry finish. World class. Big thanks to Beerkat for letting me try this.

Excellent character, individuality, amazing balance and drinkability for all of those hops. A good Ale makes it¬ís own friends and The Alchemist doesn¬ít need to spend much on marketing. I notice the picture on this site shows the Heady Topper label on a bottle. I was not aware that they offered this in bottles as the brewer is insistent that in order to enjoy the full bloom of the hop aromatics this ale should be drank right out of the can.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2013 A friend brought me a can back from a VT. trip.  Best beer I ever had, OMG, just really good, strong hop but not overpowering.  Only gave it a 3 on apperance due to average coloring and sediment floating around, don¬ít get me wrong, I wouldn¬ít change a thing

kick ass, perhaps the east coast answer to pliny the elder.  It¬ís super hoppy, yet balanced and not overly strong.  8% is plenty, we don¬ít need 12% with our hops!  Lots of citrus, pine, resin all over, and comes in a big can.  what¬ís not to love?

WOW!! had a friend give this to me. changed my palate forever!! Best IPA ive had. smells of citrus hops, orange color with medium head, great bitter ipa taste while also being balanced. looks like im making a road trip!!

Caramel, floral, spruce, herbs, and enough resin that if I closed my eyes, I could confuse it for the hop¬ís mostly illegal cousin.  The nose on this is otherworldly, I think I sprained my olfactory glands.   It poured a murky golden tan, and the taste fit the aroma but was more subdued and bitter.  A fine DIPA that is a must try for the aroma if you ever have an opportunity.
Aroma was a citrus grapefruit.  Appearance was a little hazy.  This beer had a lot of hop.  This beer was in your face and delivered exactly what you expect out of this excellent beer.

Smells of grapefruit and pine. Very aromatic. Drank most from can as per directions, but a 5 oz pour into a snifter revealed a hazy beer without much in the looks department. I was, at first, convinced the drink from can direction was a ploy to keep people from looking at the beer, but further taste comparison made me feel like the can was really quite superior. Taste-wise, the beer was a bit unbalanced in the direction of bitterness over maltiness, but a complete lack of lingering bitterness on the palate made me appreciate the overly hoppy character, and this is the only beer I¬íve yet to see do that right. Full marks, except for appearance, which was abysmal.
UPDATED: SEP 21, 2013 16oz can thanks to toastedpuppy. Pours a hazy orange with a white head. Pineapple pine aroma. Grapefruit and big orange and citrus hop taste. Very enjoyable.

Bonused by nate321 in a recent trade (read: received it today), thanks a lot man!! This isn¬ít my first time with Heady but it is my first time rating it, let¬ís dissect this. Pours clear golden with only the slightest haze and almost no head. Smell is heavenly, pine and grapefuits loaded. It does smell even more of pine when sniffing from the can, marvelous! Taste is medium bitter with a medium sweetness coming from the supportive malt backbone. Flavors remind again of pine mostly, covering a grapefruity canva. Overall a marvelous double IPA, one that I should someday go drink straight from the source!

I¬íd walk across the blazing Sahara desert for a good IPA.  This IPA strikes a wonderful balance...not too sweet, not too dry, well carbonated.  The one aspect of balance that stands out is the balance between nose and palate.  This beer is magnificently hopped with a perfect balance between wet and dry, with aromatic hints of pine and grapefruit.  As much as I used to taunt my wine loving friends (catcalls of "Tannic, but fruity, with essence of oak" were my typical sophomoric jeer...), I grudgingly admire their descriptive nomenclature.  Now, I simply have to convert them to beer.

From the brewery. Pours a bright effervescent gold with lots of white head. Perfect spruce hop sting that is short and sweet and piney and everything that is good in an iipa. Wonderful grapefruit in the aroma just adds to the enjoyment. This is fantastic.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2016 I¬ím ready for a Heady! Fresh can. In the can, smell is big pine. Poured into a small taster also getting some fruity smell. Pours murky light tangerine with no head or lacing. Aromas are pine, some light peach or apricot, maybe some biscuit. Tastes are light sweet and heavy bitter. Body is medium, bitterness almost makes it feel sticky. Bitterness and flavours last a long time. This is crazy drinkable.
Fresh can. Hazy orange, white head. Nose is citrus fruits, pine, grapefruit. Taste is citrus fruits, earth, grapefruit, pine. Really smooth mouthfeel, dangerously drinkable.

Chilled 16 oz. can, big thanks for Josh.  Rating was blind against two other IPAs.  Pours deep golden/light amber with small white head.  Medium body, low carbonation, and nice hop aroma.  Taste is heavy grapefruit, pine, spicy hops, and bitter finish.  Lots of flavor, but the grapefruit was too heavy and not the lighter fruitier I prefer and I am not a fan of the pine.  I expected more from the highly rated Heady-Topper.

Pours a murky, pale, wheat golden color with a cottony, stubborn white head. Flecks of barley and vegetable matter float all around the beer. Juicy grapefruit with some pine on the nose. Once the beer settles, sweeter fruit breaks through. Grapefruit up front then grass and pine emerge. But, the flavor suddenly falls of a cliff for an abrupt finish. Alcohol and unami get picked up right away and pervade throughout. The mouthfeel is a little thin for the style. It dries a little toward the finish. Pretty big disappointment. Pliny, Abrasive, Sucks, all way superior in my opinion.
16oz. can. Nice hop on the nose, hop punch on the tongue. Citrus. Bit thin on the tongue for a double IPA, but overall delightful.
Very hoppy with citrus flavors. Very drinkable, but drink it from the can.

Pint can from Grand Cru Rhinebeck, NY.  Amazing beer that lives up to the hype.  I will make a trip to VT to get more.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Fresh can from Phatdog1. Been looking forward to sampling this one. Golden pour, big thick, lacey white head that doesn¬ít go away fast. The aroma on this is amazing. Smells like a bag of hops when I homebrew. Super fresh. Taste is big hop forward without being massively aggressive on the palate. Mostly pine notes. Very resiny, but again, not overdone. Balanced but still interesting, which I think is often a challenge, but the brewer got it right. Finishes with a lingering bitterness, but at the right level. I think what sets this apart is how well it pushes the envelope with the use of hops without going too far, and just the incredibly fresh nature of it. Appropriately rated high. Thank you, Craig!

Bi√®re orang√©e floconneuse avec un col de mousse satisfaisant. Le nez est incroyable : du houblon frais, du houblon fruit√©, des agrumes et encore du houblon. √áa sent la tondeuse! En bouche, la magie se poursuit avec les notes fruit√©es et am√®res des houblons. M√™me √† 8%, √ßa se boit d¬íun trait. Cette bi√®re est simplement dangereuse. J¬íaurais aim√© ne pas avoir √† suivre la cohue et scander que cette bi√®re est surestim√©e par tous les beer geeks qui la placent obsessivement sur un pi√©destal... mais puisqu¬íils ont raison : je vais simplement hocher de la t√™te en esp√©rant pouvoir me ramener quelques cannettes du Vermont tr√®s bient√¥t.
It¬ís a really good beer.  I hate to jump on the bandwagon, but drinking this beer is like breaking the seal on a fresh bag of hops...game, set, match.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2014 half from can, half from snifter.  pour is cloudy golden straw with lots of sediment.  aroma is strong tropical hops (fresh pineapple and mango?).  taste starts with lightly sweet hops (citrus and tropical flavors) and trends toward piney hop bitterness in the finish.  alcohol is barely noticeable. very enjoyable.
Can to snifter. Light murky amber color. Ok smell bit not the best aroma of the dipas I¬íve had. Nice sweet start with a bitter finish that lingers.

Pint can. Pale yellow with sediment. Thin white head with medium sized bubbles. Citrus, pine, hops and honey aromas. Sweet upfront an then really piney finish. Body changes from smooth to astringent as well.

I live in NJ and just got a case of 24 x 16¬ís home from the brewery.  Definitely worth an almost 4 hour round trip detour from some business I was doing in southern Vermont.  One of the best beers I¬íve ever had.  Being a DIPA and me being IPA lover...it takes a lot for me to rate an IPA this high.  You definitely don¬ít taste the 8%.  I poured my first one out in a large Sam Adams glass.  Great head that stood firm and  tall...but then fell in on itself pretty quickly like a souffl√©.  Still got the great aromas...although smelling into the can after the pour revealed some additional intensity.  The hops in this beer are very enjoyable...with a lot of complex flavors...but what¬ís most amazing is how smooth this highly hopped 8% IPA drinks.  Obviously the scarcity of the beer and difficulty in getting outside of northern Vermont just add to the allure.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2013 Can - thanks MWBrady12. Pours hazy amber with a quadrillion floaties. Oh-oh. Small white head that dissipates quickly but leaves nice lacing. Aroma is not strong; citrus pine and caramel - pretty standard stuff. Flavor is actually pretty pleasant for an IPA that is clearly past its prime. Nice citrus and pine dominating, a bit of sweetness, medium bitter through to the finish. Full bodied and intensely creamy/oily mouthfeel - 5+ for that one! This is a good beer, I am extremely interested to find out what it is like when fresh.

Rerate with a two day old can. Ok, this is an amazing beer when fresh.
Bottle at a bottle share. Pours a clear dark golden color with a moderate head. Nose and taste are bitter and hoppy. Great beer.

Canete partag√©e par Tom10101, merci ben! On passe vite sur l¬íapparence moyenne de cette bi√®re (que le brasseur n¬íessaie pas de cacher). Mais que dire d l¬íar√¥me et du go√ªt, tout-√†-fait √† la hauteur de ce qu¬íon attend des meilleurs I2PA. Du bon houblon terreux, des fruits en masse, de la r√©sine, des agrumes, dans un m√©lange savamment √©quilibr√©! Je r√™ve du jour o√π on pourra s¬íen acheter des 4-packs dans les d√©panneurs du Qu√©bec... je risque d¬íattendre longtemps!

From the can. Intense tropical/dank aroma. Amazing hop flavor on the palate that is a wave of hop intensity. Tropical, grapefruit, a little piney, dank that lingers on your palate and leaves you wanting more. No sign of the 8% and no bitter at all compared to other DIPA. THE best DIPA I¬íve ever had.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2013 Can. Believe the hype. The only reason this doesn¬ít score a perfect 5 is that it isn¬ít the prettiest beer to look at (which is probably why they want you to drink straight from the can). Had this side by side with Pliny the Younger, and although Pliny is great, this was the clear winner.

I can¬ít report much on appearance because I tried this as directed - from the can.  Nose was citrus - grapefruit, mango and pineapple along with some pine, grassiness and floral elements.  Taste followed with big citrus flavors, especially grapefruit and orange, but with a biscuity, caramel malt for balance.  Bitterness was there but not overwhelming.  It predominates in the aftertaste as well, along with pine oil and honey. Mouthfeel was medium and mildly carbonated.  There is little to no alcohol burn.  I can understand why so many people love this beer¬Öit was great¬Öjust not my all-time favorite as it is for so many.

Wow the nose is a hop buffet, I barely had the can open and the aroma was invading the air. It¬ís extremely hop forward, the most prevalent flavors I get are grapefruit, citrus, and a strong floral taste. Probably the best double I¬íve ever had!!!

Pours a hazy gold colour with a white head that dissipates quickly, some white lacing. Aroma of fresh roses and citrus hops, probably one of the best aromas ever. Tastes of roses followed by citrus hop, it's a great beer missing a little on the back end. This is honestly one of my top 5 beers ever if not #1. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2013 Wow! Definitely lives up to the hype for me! Beautiful unfiltered golden color. Aroma is citrus, pine, mango, pineapple, pineapple, and more pineapple!! Love the bits of hop sediment floating around the glass. Taste is sweet, citrusy, and again PINEAPPLE! Excellently balanced! Yum!!

From a taster snifter at the brewery: Light, sudsy head with a little staying power. amber color. Big bready aroma with piney hop overdrive. Huge taste with a soft but pronounced bitterness. Stays on the palate like a slice of bread, initial bitterness softens quickly. This is a great complex DIPA that is unusually easy to drink.
From the 16oz can at Hunahpu¬ís Day 2013. Pours with a gigantic and rich head. Citrus and grapefruit. Big on bitter and floral and finishes extremely balanced. Great DIPA.

Aroma is malt, peach, grapefruit, citrus and grass. Flavour is caramel alcohol, grapefruit, peach and citrus.

Canned, at Man in The Moon, Stockholm.  Hazy deep golden, small head. Citric pineapple aroma. Mid sweet with clea, rounded mouthfeel and medium-full body. Juicy and citric with quite bitter finish. One in the crowd.

Wintergreen like mix of citrus an pine with a nice dry finish with hops that linger. Love the flowery aroma. Malt has a somewhat biscuit flavor but its not dominant as this is really bittered up. I am guessing they use a load of amarillo hops because its a bit pungent. Strong hype factor! I enjoy this but would take hopslam or devient dales too.

Can at Man in the Moon, StockholmHeady golden color, with small creamy head. The aroma is quite earthy, with some light manure. The body is leaner than expected, but the mouthfeel is smooth enough; strong flavor of malt, toffee, light crystal-like flavor too, moderate residual sweetness; strong bitterness, the hop provides a lot of resins, some bitter orange, but no freshness, and just a minimal fruity touch, it provides instead some sweaty and earthy character. Long final, quite balanced.Good, but I¬ím not impressed at all.

16 ounce can thanks to ekroper, thanks a ton Ed, poured a hazy orange color wih huge aromas of fresh pineapple, pine, citrus, and a kiss of caramel.  Flavors were just the same a mixture of fresh tropical fruit andsone pine resin.  Wow this beer was so good I drank all the cans he sent me in one sitting, there was never enough.

Can courtesy DanR.  Pours hazy orange, nice fluffy off white head, dissipating.  Huge hop nose, dank grassy nose, orange and lemon.  Caramel start, huge orange and resin flavor, litter box, and a mild/moderate bitter than lingers well into the after.  Really, really good.

Large off-white head of fine bubbles with very good carbonation.  Awesome aroma with lots of pine, oranges and grapefruit.  A plethora of all things hoppy and wonderful.  Some sweet malts and hint of cat urine.  Not in a bad way though.  Color is a hazy golden orange.  Flavor is extreamly well balanced with a good malt backbone to offset the huge amount of hops.  Bitterness does not overwealm but certainly takes front stage.  More grapefruit and a bit of nuttiness.  Very smooth and easy drinking with just a hint of alcohol presence.  Finishes a bit of herbal hops and lingering sweet malts.  This is a fantastic IIPA.  One of the best.  Big thaks to Fredward for this gem!

another from whatsarezaf thanks again didnt do as directed we poured into tasting glasses i know weak. but it poured a beautiful amber with a little bit of hop residue this is a hop bomb  very pinny oily and floral it is a hop heads dream i want to swim in this dipa this beer made me miss drinking ipa¬ís all the time

Wow! Drank from can as directed. So I'm just assuming the appearance is as good as it smells and tastes! This beer lives up to the hype! Big ole stinky American DIPA. Huge hop flavor. Citrusy and bitter! Lingering hop sticks around for quite some time! My kind of punch in the mouth big boy IPA! If I could only drink one beer for the rest of my life this would be it!! Wish it was distributed to NC. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a hazy orange.  (Yes, I know we¬íre supposed to drink it from the can, but I just couldn¬ít bear to do that.  But I am lucky enough to have another can so I¬íll try that experience as well!)  Not bad looking but unremarkable, as far as appearances go.  Nice, piney, grapefruit hop bomb for the nose.  Drinks sharp with loads of grapefruity citrus and pine resin. Some sweet malt in the finish but overall, a nice, scrubbing effect.  IMO, one of the few beers that lives up to the hype.  I¬ím not trading my first born for a 4 pack but you can bet I¬íll make the pilgrimage to try and score some more! Good job!

Pours a cloudy light orange with a 2 finger off white foam. The foam is thick and so is the hoppy aroma. Resiny, citrus, and appealing. Medium body has a thick hop bitterness. Body supports well without sweetness. Finish is dry, clean, and very smooth. Excellent IPA.

16 ounce can.  Thanks Gary!  Poured a few ounces, drank the rest from the can.  Pours a hazy gold with a nice white head.  Aroma of citrus and some pine.  Taste is grapefruit, other tropicals, pine, florals, and some caramel malt.  Great balance and a great finish.  Well worth the trade I made.

Poured from 16 oz can. Cloudy amber with cream head. Citrus pine nose, very bitter. I can see where the hop head go nuts however, most imperial IPA I¬íve had have some malt to balance out the bitter. Didn¬ít really get that blend. There are others that are better with a lot less hype. Still good though.

16 oz can at a tasting at Greg¬ís, served in a stem glass. Pours cloudy amber with a small white head that fades to a thin remnant, leaving behind a small amount of fine lace. The nose has nice floral hops, along with caramel malts, cookie and grapefruit. The flavour is balanced between moderately bitter piney hops and moderately sweet caramel malts. Flowers are present throughout. It finishes with a long, lingering bitterness with spice and grapefruit. On the palate, it is medium in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice double IPA but I felt the finish to be a bit of a disappointment. 2012-09-15

Cans thanks to Balto_MD.  Very bitter. Lots of hops.  Didnt get much malt on the back end to balance it out.  This was a very good IIPA.  Had it against the other top competitors.  Up there not better.

Can 473cl @ Geokkjer
Pours hazy  deep golden/copper with a off-white head. Aroma has notes of malt, caramel, citrus, grape, orange and peach. Taste is medium sweet and medium to heavy bitter with a long warm, citrus and tropical fruity finish. Body is full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

Can, from trade with the little grumpy old Dane. A not-so-cute golden-orange beer with some floaties and a finger-thick off-white head leaving lacings. The aroma is really hop-driven, leaving little room for the malts. Peaches, pine cones, grapefruit peel, resins and some alcohol. It¬ís full-bodied and nicely carbonated, with some warmth. Nice bitterness, and lots of hoppy aromas. Sufficient amounts of malty sweetness blends in. Lasting finish with the hops dominating, and so much bitterness it leaves a feeling of having drank a dry beer. A rather wonderful beer. 130222

Can. Pours golden with lots of floaties and a small white head. Aroma of floral, cheesy hops, some citrus and pine. Flavor is sweet and bitter with some floral and citrus hops and some malt and fruitiness. Medium body, average carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 5, 2013 Cans thanks to Balto_MD. Poured into a tulip even though it tells me to drink from the can. Huge pillowy white head. Pours a cloudy orange. Powerful grapefruity hops aroma. As the head dissipates it leaves a beautiful lacing along the glass. Much of the head lasts for some time. Slightly on the bitter side of balanced. This could be due to my pouring it into a glass (just read the can). Actually taking a swig from the can is slightly less bitter. Still an amazing beer that I am glad I got to try. The next three will be drank directly from the can, as it was intended!

Is there anything better than a Heady Topper in a 16 ounce can?! I am not a hop-head, I like tasty hops. This is simply the tastiest. Citrus and pine flavors. Problem is, you have to drive up to Vermont to find it.

From the can as it should be.  Huge floral hits after cracking the can.  Love the citrus pulling through.  The hops are well balanced for a double and it is a bit scary just how easy drinking this is. I'll go back again and again.

4 pack of 16oz cans that Eric brought back from VT for me.  Thanks dude.... I will watch your dog anytime!  It says to drink straight from the can (that is a faux pas in my house... and yes, I had to google-it to get the correct spelling!)  I dumped this one into my Sam Smith nonick pint.  It is a cloudy, pale orange pour with a short white head.   The aroma is all citrus and a hint of fresh bread.  Orange, grapefruit, and pineapple aromas dominate this one.  The first sip is acidic and thirst quenching.  The hop flavors are very strong, but not harsh at all.  The flavors and carbonation are surprisingly soft.  Whenever I pour a double IPA, I prepare myself for harsh hop oils to murder my mouth.  This was soft and citrus-juicy-sweet from start to finish.  The 8% is hidden even in the last cellar-temp sip... wow.  
This is a rare occasion where I try a beer after reading about it for a year+.  This is hyped as much as Pliny, and after a fresh 4-pack... I know it is legit.  I love this beer, I love that it is from VT, and I hope that this becomes as readily available as Budweiser in my lifetime.
Heady Topper is the most drinkable DIPA I¬íve ever had. Smooth and bitter, it makes you crave the next sip. The only roadblock to having enough is the ABV
On can @ Man in the Moon, Stockholm. Awesome aroma of citrus, high drinkability for being a DIPA. Really well balanced.

Hands down the best IPA I have ever tried. It is extremely drinkable, smooth, flavorful, and it is not overpowered by hops.  It tastes exactly how it smells which is amazing!  Find a way to try this beer!!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Thanks Drew. Hazy orange with generous off white head. Pine and musty citrus dominate the aroma with a little "body odor" funk. Flavors are pine and caramel with a bitterness which is aggressive but a bit stale. Good DIPA, but it is missing clean distinct flavors/aroma - a bit muddy.

Warning, do not look at my ratings, I¬ím not good ,for giving grades but, I¬íve had lots of IPAs and DIPAs and this one is the absolute best DIPA I¬íve ever had. The bitterness is so complex it even feels like it¬ís shifting in the after taste. SO DRINKABLE it¬ís scary. I¬íll have to find time to go down there (I¬ím from Montreal) and pick up a couple of cases...Amazing stuff!
4 pint cans courtesy of a friend. Poured in a snifter. Hazy yellow orange. Nice citrus/bitter balance. Very good. Says to drink out of a can, I¬íll do that next.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2013 Nice rich golden-amber color with decent layer of sudsy off-white head.  A floral, citrus-spiked sweet hop aroma and light maltiness which carries through in taste.    " Waves" of hop flavors; floral then a bit earthy in the finish with some bite in the cheeks (so to speak).  Really a great beer. 

Notes:
I was fortunate to try it from the can and on tap at the pub back before the flood with some excellent food.

From can. Nice fruity fresh hop aroma. Apricot, pear, pine. Sweetness abounds with alcohol vapor and funky resin. Amber clear with light haze and thin white head. Medium body with high carbonation. Starts sweet with lots of juicy hops, fruity and bitter. Light caramel. Bit bitter finish and after.

Wow wow wow my 100th rate and what a beer to do it with :) can acquired via a trade from kingcecil. Pour hazy golden with a white one finger head. Aroma is citrus and piney, smooth on the palette growing bitterness on the aftertaste which is great. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very strong IPA. Clear taste,  almost overwhelming hoppy flavor .. one of my rare favorite IPAs

This one is so much fun to try and get hold of - I guess it¬ís hard not to let the romanticism enter into the review. But having had it both in and out of can, and having tried many of the other top rated double IPA¬ís, I still have to say this one is on my top three. Something about the aroma / palate / flavor profile makes it incredibly drinkable and all around outstanding.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2013 Can from RB trade; hazy amber off white head, Simcoe hop bitter tropical hop resinous mouthfeel. Had a fresher can probably only a couple of weeks old and my god this is so drinkable, tropical hop freshness hitting my tastes buds big time.

Incredible hoppy aroma, dirty yellow pour, solid taste and satisfying mouthfeel.

Amazing floral hop with some definite alcohol in there. Real deep breath reveals some cat friendliness.  Great full sweet bitterness. A little muddled. Full body great bitter finish.

I waited a long time for this and am satisfied. Beer bucket list checked off. I will be seeking out more. I traded a DFH Old School barley wine for this and it was a great trade! There are bits of hops afloat in this IPA pool. Passion fruit forward, this is an excellent DIPA.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2013 16oz can, thanks to caterwaul. Why don¬ít these cans have dates on them? Mildly hazy golden color. Little fine particles in the glass. Thin white head. Leaves pretty good lace. Smooth light carbonation. Bigger body. Piney hop flavor, very nice. Sweet taste, light bitter for me. Nice drinkable piney sweet DIPA. 8 / 4 / 7 / 4 / 15 Revisit, 1/26/13: Got my hands on two of these, thanks to caterwaul. The first one I split with him in a glass. My second can I had all to my self, which I enjoyed straight from the can this time, at a small social gathering. Wow! It¬ís amazing how much more enjoyable this is from the can. I couldn¬ít believe how much more I was enjoying it, even did some side by sides with some in the glass, some straight from the can. It really makes a difference, with this beer.

Can for rating #4600: ¬† Dirty orangish straw, light to moderate frothy off-white head, spotty lacing. ¬† Bright and sweet pithy nose, a bit citrusy, somewhat candied. ¬† Fresh and bright on the tongue, hoppy, citrusy, some caramel like sweetness, candied orange bits. ¬† Not overly biting, hoppy, but well within reason. ¬† Good amount of sweetness to balance it out. ¬† Body and mouthfeel are moderate to full. ¬† Clean hoppy finish. ¬† Absolutely straight forward and a great representation for the style. ¬† Not overly hoppy, not terribly sticky. ¬† Very well balanced. ¬† Thanks to Nat of Brouwer¬ís Caf√© for the can!

Crazy scents. Blended fruit, citrus, and floral. Thick head and hazy golden color. Starts a little sweet on the tongue with a nice bitter finish. Not too bitter for an 8% ipa. One of my favorite ips¬ís for sure.

1 pint can (trade with Leighton). A hazy golden/orange coloured pour with a medium white fluffy head on top. Hoppy, citrus, grapefruit aroma. Tastes of grapefruit, hoppy, citrus fruit, pine, slight marmalade taste, slightly malty with some bitterness. Pretty good stuff, almost in the Kernel mould.

Can generously donated by HopHead Fred. A light, hazy orange color. Awesome hopped-up citrus nose, with some fresh-cut hay and a bit of sweetness, that is detectable from more than a foot away. Piney hop resin dominates the taste, but despite the high IBUs, the bitterness is just the right amount without overpowering the secondary notes of grapefruit and honey. Very dry with an abrupt finish; I wish it had more of an aftertaste. I¬ím not sure it¬ís the absolute best DIPA I¬íve had, but it does live up to its hype.
It was delicious! Best beer ive had in along time! I recommend every hop head to try it.

Quarter can pour, lightly hazed golden with full finger straw head. Nose is nice Simcoe hop, resin and straw, sticky and dank. Flavor is healthy hop, woody, like oak, rich and sticky. Killer amazing. Great body with nice lacing. Really a standout beer

A lil conflicted about keeping this in the can, it says I must to retain the hop aroma¬ís, still I will pour a little for scent and complexion. Can smells of piny, bitter hops like a stronger dales. Pours a light unfiltered yellow with a foamy white head, kind of looks like grapefruit juice. After pouring I can smell lemon, citrus and honey but smell isn¬ít too complex. Is more bitter and less aromatic in the can but I¬ím sure this can be enjoyed either way. Quite drinkable for the alcohol and not super bitter. Is quite dry and finishes bitter and dry and tasting like cut grass. Its good but nowhere close to the best double IPA I¬íve ever had and that grass aftertaste is not good.

Poured from tall can and consumed from can as it instructs me to do.  I poured out a bit into a glass to make the rating.  Pours copper in color with off white head.  Aroma is grapefruit and malt.  Tasty stuff.

16 oz. can from the Booyamachine himself. It¬ís every bit as good as people claim it is. Hops are straight up lumberyard pine. Very intense. Palate is destroyed well before the can is finished. Distribution is so limited but if you can get your hands on it, you should grab as many as you can.
Bottle.  Grapefruit peel and pine aroma - very intense.   Cloudy golden yellow with small head.    Sweet orange malt and moderately bitter grapefruit peel flavor.  Lingering bitter aftertaste.

First time actually pouring it in a glass. Poured a nice opaque straw/orange color with a finger and a half white head. Scent is definitely more pronounced when sampling from the can, but it is still fantastic. Strong floral hops dominate, a little citrus, and a little hay. Taste is like a hop punch in the teeth. Awesome citrus and resiny hops sip after sip. Bitterness is slight and well balanced and the 8% alcohol is hidden well. One of the best!

16 oz can courtesy of Dan the man, thanks Dan! I drank the first half from the can (as instructed) second half poured a hazy straw color with a two finger bone white head. Sticky retention. Aroma is stupid. Like a sniffing a handful of citra hops. Mixed with some earthy fresh undertones, it¬ís floral and spicy. Really wonderful. Taste is amazing, like hops in a can. Extremely fresh, sweet tropical fruits upfront, melon, mango, citrus, balanced flawlessly by a caramel malt backbone and finishing with a nice crisp finish. Bitterness like the rind of a grapefruit. Mouthfeel is bubbly and excellently carbonated, a medium thickness makes this extremely drinkable. I would have liked to guzzle a whole 4pk of these guys. By far one of the best double IPAs out there (east coast pliny, anyone?) Extraordinary brew, get it if you can!

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2014 [4678-20120817] Can. Fresh leafy hops aroma. Slightly hazy, light orange body with a quick foamy white head. Orange bitter hops flavour has a nice underlying tangerine sweetness. Medium body. Very tasty, very drinkable. (7/3/8/4/16) 3.8
(@ Campground Brewdown 2012, Millmont, PA)

[5269B-20130427] Tap. Orange resiny hops aroma. Hazy, light orange yellow body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head and lattice lacing. Bitter orange hops flavour with a resiny base. Medium body is quite bitter. Delicious and fresh. (7/4/8/4/16) 3.9
(@ brewery, Waterbury, VT)
Can. Pours a cloudy orange. Strong floral pine grapefruit hop aroma. Strong hop and grapefruit. Bitter hop Dry finish. Hides alcohol well, a very impressive IIPA from Alchemist.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2013 Can courtesy of Atom. Tropical fruit, citrus hops aroma - also something almost lactic. Cloudy orange amber with a moderate white head, chunky white sediment... ugly beer... the command to drink from the can is a cop out in my opinion. Super sweet biscuity malt, citrus and weedy hops flavor. Full body.  I¬íve had so much better, and simply don¬ít understand the hype on this one. (original rate 7-2-6-3-13=3.1)Fresh refrigerated can courtesy of 8003F. Fruity citrusy piney hops and bready caramel malt aroma. Cloudy copper with a small white head.  Cirtrusy apricot, bready caramel malt, resinous piney hops, and citrus peel flavor. Medium body, moderate carbonation.  Better than my first experience, but still overhyped in my opinion.

Great classic hop aroma for an imperial ipa. Notes of citrus fruit, grass, pine and some floral aroma. I only poured half (because can demanded I drink it from the can but I couldn¬ít help myself and had to see it) it was a bland gold color with some chill haze. Rich and creamy in the mouth it is like drinking a delicious hop emulsion.

A bit over hyped, but truly an outstanding beer. Aroma, is a huge hop punch, with wonderful citrus and resinous tones. I love unfiltered beers, so hazy with a touch of gold is lovely. Beautiful carbonation, soft and velvety co2 across the palate. Dry lingering finish, extremely well balanced, quaffable almost to a fault, as you can easily get into trouble drinking a few. Kimmich created an outstanding beer here, with out the vegetal properties of an over hopped double IPA. Truly world class.
Incredibly aromatic with grapefruit and resin. Not dank, more citrusy. Very drinkable, tho strong.
Drank from the can as instructed. Amazing aroma and very floral taste. One of my top 5.

Drank this fantastic beer out of the can, as the instructions on the can demands.  Taste is full of hops with smooth hints of grapefruit and rosemary.  The finish is perfect and keeps you wanting more.  They did a great job controlling the intensity of the hops with the balance of citrus flavors.  A beer that lives up to all the hype in my opinion.

Can from Capones.  Can¬ít believe I haven¬ít rated this yet.  Pours a murky glowing golden orange with hop particles abound.  Thick fluffy cream colored head and thick lacing.  The hop particles might be off putting until you taste this thing.  Aroma is fresh pineapples.  If there is anything else in the nose it certainly doesn¬ít matter, that delicious pineapple aroma is over powering and amazing.  Taste is pineapple - a little sweet upfront, not overly bitter. Can.  BIG thanks to Gabe at Grape & Gourmet for sharing!  I can smell the American hops from a few feet away.  Wow.  I¬ím scared.  Orange, amber.  This is hop juice, all the way.  Beautifully bounded citrus, grapefruit, flowers.  Exceptionally wound into a well-assembled beer.  Me want more.  (#4855, 12/9/2012)

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2013 Drinking from the can as I am told. 
Aroma is a pleasant blend of hops - lots of citrus, peach and tropical fruit with pine resin backing it all up. No real malt aroma to speak of. 
Appearance is that of a silver can. Having had this from a glass I can say that it is a yellow gold with a nice white head. It is a very cloudy beer. 
Flavor is a touch sweet with light cracker and biscuit character. The light malt character is the perfect platform to showcase the hop flavors. Hop flavors are sweet orange and grapefruit, tropical fruit and peach. There is a light resin note in the finish. The bitterness is solid, but clean and not astringent at all. Does not strike me as being near 120 IBUs. 
The mouthfeel is smooth but crisp. The beer is fairly dry and not sticky sweet at all. Balanced but assertive bitterness. The alcohol is sufficiently hidden and the beer provides only a moderate warming character. 
Overall this is a very enjoyable DIPA; one of my all time favorites.

Can. Pour is unclear golden with lacing small and long-lasting white head. Aroma is massive hop-soup, pineapple, pine, grass sweet fruit, a lot of peach. Taste is bitter and heavy sweet but nicely balanced. not sure if it has a slight acidic tone or it¬¥s a light hop-burn. Body is medium- full, texture is light syrupy, carbonation is soft, finish is long and delicately bitter. This hop-bomb blew me away!

Bought from a health food store in Burlington VT. Told it arrived that day so it musta been fresh. I like the pounder can format too!  Pours a very pretty hazy orange. Fiery! Taken from my BA account, reviewed 2/25/12

Live tasting 16 oz can into Duvel tulip...

Appearance; pours a hazy yellow gold, and a moderate pour yeilds a finger of straw colored head that recedes after a couple minutes... Lacing is good with spiderwebs of head sticking to the sides of the glass. I did get a little carried away during the pour and per the warning on the can, dumped some resin and yeast into my glass so there is some suspended floaties... Will try the next one straight from the can, and no points off for my dumping sediment into the glass... 

Smell; popped the tab and stepped into a tropical rainforest!! I had a feeling this was coming given my experience with Abrasive and the fact that it¬ís canned as well... I¬íll save my "can revolution" talk for another time and place but this beer smells phenomenal. Citruses such as orange and grapefruit and tons of tropics, mango, hints of peach, and pineapple.

Taste; absolutely the smell personified here.. Pineapple, orange and grapefruit rinds, mango, peach, tangerine, just the faintest hints of pine, with the perfect amount of hop bite that sneaks in after a couple sips... Notes of caramel, round it out... Exceptionally well balanced.

Mouthfeel; on the fuller side of medium body, slightly sticky with a lingering bitter finish that never becomes overbearing or intrusive carbonation is perfect. 

Overall; DAMN. This is one hell of a beer, and I will be continuously on the lookout for more. Absolutely fantastic DIPA.



Revisited direct from the can 3/17/12;

Live review, can directy into my mouth...

Appearance; looks great, a slightly polished silver color with screen printed black graphics... No dents, dings or major scratches, information about the brewery on the back along with an advisory pro-recycling statement. 

Smell; great tropical aromas spring out of the mouth hole and continue oozing out of the can, mango, pineapple, tons of other assorted tropical aromas that I can¬ít quite pin down..

Taste; simply outstanding pineapple, citrus, and markedly more resinous notes than I picked up pouring into a glass... A slightly more significant pine characteristic is also evident...

Mouthfeel; identical to the mouthfeel in the glass, absolutely fantastic.

Overall; direct from the can or in a glass, this is a damn fine beer. I¬íll be sad when Im outta these...
UPDATED: FEB 7, 2013 Poured from a can. Huge overpowering dry hop, just the way I like it. Excellent ipa. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Sample at Borefts Beer Festival 2012. Pours an unclear and golden beer with a white head. The aroma is malt and hops with peach, tropical fruit and citrus. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is bitterness. Overall a good beer.

A canned version graciously shared by Linzy. Great floral bouquet. An aroma that you want to keep inhaling. The flavor is light and fresh and a continuation of the smell. Lovely. It does not taste like a double at all. Too effervescent and drinkable for that moniker.

355ml can - shared by Janne - thanks!
Poured it - ug, flecky bits everywhere, yuck. But I¬ím not drinking a beer from a can even if ordered, and even if I did, I¬íd be forced to mark down its aroma, taste, and palate - cans are not neutral. Far better to mark down just the look. This is no worse than (in fact better than) Abbey de Rocs, say. Does have a full fruity IPA aroma, lots of sticky juicy aromatics. Sweet too, obviously - full of biscuity flapjack caramels. Good hops in the body too, that¬ís the first thing you notice. Full in the mouth. Very tasty, I like it. Alas it¬ís also sticky and stodgy. Finish is bitter and drying. Not as drinkable as some other US IPAs I¬íve had, but as drinkable but tastier than some others. All in all pretty OK, but not wowing me at all.

Thanks Joey!

Poured into a glass out of a can.  WOW is all i can say about the smell.... CITRUS. and hops. Where was this can when i was in college?  Can only imagine beer pong with this one.

Taste of citrus is extremely well balanced against the hops. very clean on the palate, refreshing would highly suggest drinking this fresh
From a pint can at a beer tasting. Pours cloudy dark yellow with a white  head. Strong fruity citrus aroma. Orange zest bitter finish. Wow!

Can courtesy of Beer Necessities.  Poured (despite the can instructions) wild honey with a medium white head, active carbonation, and excellent lacing.  Amazing citrus aroma surges from the can followed by hints of caramel malt, melon, and piney hops.  Taste is very well balanced with a wave of citrus and semi-sweet malt to start, then a wave of palatable hoppy bitterness, and finishing with more citrus. Surprisingly smooth finish with blend of citrus and hoppy flavors lingering.  Most drinkable top notch DIPA that I have had and just wish I had access to more.

16 ounce can via Glouglouburp- thanks for the awesome extra! Pours hazy peach orange with a thick one finger head. Soapy sticky lacing. Aroma- very resinous, piney, melon and ripe pineapple. Taste- sweet fruits, white grapefruit and cookie dough, then quickly a wave of bitterness dries the mouth. The hops literally feel caked in my mouth. Carbonation is spot on.  Great brew and obviously a fresh can that makes it an even better experience.

Trade from Pittsburg. Poured into a glass, cloudy amber color. Hop explosion all around. Taste was similar, dry bitter grapefruit that lingers. Awesome, similar to Pliny, or goose island IPA.

Awesome nose of resin and citrus.  Opened only a few hours after shipment from picking up on a trade, pretty cloudy.  Easily a top 3 IPA for me.  Very easy to drink, unfortunately only 3 left.

Re-rate...
Yeah, this stuff is awesome...fresh! Lots of dank, resinous hops; loads of grapefruit. Excellent beer!

Poured from can despite the warning.  Hazy and chunky pour.  Nose is the best I¬íve had from an IIPA, citrus and pine with tropical fruits. Hazy orange, with a nice white head. Aroma is: orange, pine, sweet grapefruit, nice malty sweetness. Taste is: bitter grapefruit, orange, pine, tangerine, sweet malts. Tastes like fressh squeezed hop pellets. Very nice DIPA! (6 days old)

March 21, 2012 with blankboy and garthicus. 16oz can c/o garthicus.  Cloudy orange-gold with some sludge with a smallish frothy head.  [various incoherent sounds of pleasure relating to hoppy aroma here]. UPDATED: OCT 14, 2012 I had this in a pint can and, other than a small pour into a glass to discern color and clarity, followed the recommendations to drink from the can.

Poured a very hazy golden color with decent head and a grassy hop nose. Strong, spicy hop palate with grapefruit and a touch of pine. Lighter bodied than many double or imperial IPAs. An easy drinker (unfortunately, as it¬ís 8% abv), as the can text suggests, but nothing unusual for an American style IPA.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2013  Had some room temperature samples of this stuff @ Borefts 2012. Split a 500 ml. with two others at the train station before heading heading of to Kwintessens - still nicely cooled. Taste is quite bitter, bitter white grapes, lighter pineapple, kiwi, rather bitter pine raisin in the back, light honey, grapefruit, citrus, tangerine, light alcohol in the finish coming through which is a bit odd. Really dries out the mouth, well-carbonated. I like my DIPA a bit fruitier with a sweeter edge but this is very fine stuff, probably to bitter for me to ever actually drink a lot of this. This is a fine beer. /// Tried again, small sample, more fruity, mellower than I remember, more white grape. No idea of the age of the sample. It is a good beer but still not getting why people go so crazy for it.

Poured from a 16 oz. can and served in a DFH signature glass. Big thanks to Mike (Gushue3) for sending me a few of them!

A: Pours a dark amber color with a little light brown in the body and some orange hues around the edges. Has a bunch of floaties as well. A nice off-white head forms on the pour and recedes to a nice film ring. Leaves a nice sticky lace down the glass.

S: Grapefruits and resin with a light flower back note. Nice caramel malts and some solid breadiness as well.

T: The taste is more of the same. Nice flowery notes pop up, some candied sugar and some biscuit malt with a little toffee as well. Solid grapefruit with a little citrus pop to round it all out. There is some solid bitterness on the finish with a hint of pine needle.

M: Nicely carbonated with a nice medium to light body. Leaves a nice floral and fruit taste across the palate. Very drinkable.

O: Awesome beer. Tons of flavor and it really lingers in your mouth for a while. Glad I got some more of these guys!

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 10-21-2011

On tap at the Hill Farmstead Harvest Festival 2012 VIP Event, Vermont. I liked it. I really liked it. Fairly earthy, damn resinous. Stood up well to the HF DIPAs that were also on offer. (4.2)Can at Nikki and Andre¬ís wedding, CT. Again, epic. Shared some cans with friends. Liked it better from the can than on draft. (4.4)Cans shared at the Craft Beer Co., London, many thanks to Mike. This stuff is totally rad. Out of academic interest I poured a small amount into my glass to find that this liquid is cloudy, glowing gold with a small, white foam head. Otherwise, slammed it straight to my face. Heady as shit, big and resinous, though not too big, or abrasively bitter. Huge pine character, ridiculously well balanced. Full bodied with fine carbonation. Big sticky finish, moderate earth. Just outrageous stuff. (4.6)

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 Draught @ Prohibition Pig. Brought case of cans home to PA. Aroma is as good as it gets for a hoppy beer. Super aromatic, fresh hops, grapefruit, tangerine, pine resin, honey, stonefruit.  Taste follows suit. Medium body. Deliciously refreshing. UPDATED: JUN 28, 2013 16oz can.  Looks like a nice color.  Aroma strong of citrusy and grapefruit like hops plus a good amount of caramel malts. Hazy golden orange pour from a fresh-as-tits can.  Aroma is meaty hop leaf, pineapple, bitter hop resin, fresh squeezed citrus.  Crisp and creamy, this comes out of the gate with Huge Juicy citrus hop resin, perfectly balanced bitterness and grapefruit sweetness.  I drank 3 cans of this in one sitting and wanted more.

Cloudy golden with a small white head. Big fruity hop aroma with peach, pineapple and tangerine in particular. Sweet and juicy hoppy flavour with the sweetness, but little malt character as such. All in all, an expressive and clean hop bomb, with a good bitter finish
