Canned at Mikkeller Bar. Golden beer with an off-white head. Hoppy aroma, creamy, fruity, pineapple, citrus, pears, hay, metal notes, sweetish, pleasant bitterness. Hoppy flavor, grassy, fruity, grapes, pineapples, smooth bitterness, metallic, mango notes, some pine. Bitter finish with fruity notes.

Bottle. Pours a murky golden orange color with a white head. Aroma is super fruity with lots of hop juice, I get lots of orange, tangerine, peach and nectarine, tropical fruits like mango and pineapple and some sweet sugary notes. The flavor is again intensely juicy with lots of tropical fruits again mango, pineapple and passion fruit, some sweet orange and tangerine along with the peach and nectarine notes. The body is medium with a dry mouth feel. Overall an amazing DIPA!!

Sampled out of cans a couple times over DLD weekend, first was Scott from Houston at Flossmoor, so he gets the thanks: Nice coppery hue with a good head and lace. The aroma has notes of mango, peaches, tangerines, pineapple, pepper and clove hop esters along with some pine and grassy notes. Grainy and aromatic malts have what a DIPA should smell like. The taste actually has a nice balance between acidic fruitiness, hop bitterness and base malt goodness. A bit hop spicy and grassy with some minerally notes. I must say I was actually expecting the hops to be a tad more forceful. The mouth feel is lively and sharp, crisp and shockingly easy to drink. While this is very good and I would not turn down a chance to have more, not too sure I would place it among the best beers in the world.

Opened with the pull of the tab... nice silver can with cool little label.  Drinkin it from the can the way it tells you too ! (Ive dumped it in the glass a few times as well) Anyhow... rich aromas of pineapple and a touch of pine...fresh tropical hops....mmmm  Flavors are rich full and heady... Pineapple sweetness at the start that rolls into a crisp bitterness of citrus and pine... it starts to get a little sappy but the finish brings out a whole heap of tropical flavors again that make this beer a big WINNER !

Pours cloudy gold with white head. Drank out of the can as instructed.  Aroma is grapefruit, citrus and resin...ridiculous.  Taste is bitter all the way through.  Mouth feel is smooth and creamy.  Alcohol is very well hidden.  Just a fantastic beer.

Yet another brew I had, but for some reason didn¬ít rate it right after I had it. Pours a hazy amber color with a big white head and nice lacing. Aroma is citrus, grapefruit hops. Medium body with average carbonation. Excellent citrus hop flavor with a nice malt balance and a nice bitter hop finish. Taste is similar to some west coast DIPAs. Which is not a bad thing! This is Delicious.

16 oz can generously shared by colonelforbin.  Thanks Mike.  Pours a very cloudy light amber with a small light tan head that has decent retention and leaves a good lacing on the glass.  The aroma is big mango, floral notes, light caramel, a bit of pineapple, and some sugar cookie.  The initial taste is sweet with mango and pineapple going into a bit of caramel, sugar cookie, and some light dankness. There is a very light bitterness on finish along with some lingering mango. Light bodied.  Low carbonation.  I definitely could use a bit more bitterness and a bit less sweetness.  Not bad, but certainly not in the class of the best west coast IPAs.
Pretty sure this was poured from the can at Flossmoor¬ís pre-DLD party. Sweet, resiny, fruity and all around awesomeness. Completely drinkable for a high-IBU DIPA.

Don¬ít get me wrong - this is very good stuff. I hate drinking anything out of the can though, no matter what the brewer thinks. It¬ís thick and orange with a lot of floaties. Frothy head fades quickly in the glass. Big hoppy aromas and flavors. Smooth pine, burnt rubber and lots of bitter citrus-grapefruit resins. Body is very heavy. This one hits quickly. I would much rather prefer six 12 ounce cans instead of four 16 ounce cans. Not as good as Hill¬ís Farmstead Society & Solitude #3.

This is the poor mans pliny, THis beer pours with some floaties but the aroma will fill a fairly good size room. From the can as the beer can explains is the way they want you to enjoy it. I disagree, let those hops out and pour it in to a glass. This is a great beer for sure!

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2015 Golden orange pour with a finger of head.  Noticed the aroma immediately as it fills the room upon opening the can.  Grapefruit, Pine, Mango, Floral - a virtual citrus fruit salad.  Burst of bitter hops up front, Fresh grapefruit, lemon and orange zest, fresh Mango, caramal maalt for balance.  Big gobs of lacing.  Medium body, nice finish, carbonation is on.  Very fresh can and it shows.  Highly rated, and for good reason.

Can.  Wow.  This was promised as "the best grapefruit juice you¬íve ever tasted"....and I don¬ít think that¬ís far off.  Pours a very, very hazy orange-yellow that basically looks like a slushy with all the unfiltered floaties.  Has a sweet pineapple scent but definitely has a lot of grapefruit in the taste.  The alcohol content is definitely hidden.  This is easily one of the best beers I¬íve ever had.

From can. Does pour cloudy as advertised (unfiltered) let¬ís give points to the cool can! Aroma of hops still pours through the can opening. wonderful hop bitterness with citrus notes and sweetness smooth drinkable double IPA with sweet bitterness finish leaves you wanting more!

4oz poured into glass to get a view of the appearance. The rest tasted from the can as per instructions. 

A: Cloudy straw color. My previous can had some floaters in it, but this is devoid of the blobs. 

N: Missing the hop blast I¬íd hoped for. Grapefruit, pineapple, pine. This falls really short of the high water mark of Sculpin, IMO.

T: Bitter hop goodness. Plenty of earth and pine with pineapple, mango, and pineapple laced through. This is well balanced and the 8% is muted if not non-existent altogether. Definitely finishes bone dry. 

Mouthfeel: Expands across the palate. No complaints here. 

Overall: Definitely enjoyable, and a beer I¬íll be glad to have time and time again. I just wish I got more than a whisper of hop on the nose.

16 oz can. I poured half into a pint glass and drank the other half from the can ala the instructions. Not sure when this was canned, but it comes from the late March release to a few Massachusetts beer shops. 

A - Super hazy dark yellow body. Lets just a bit of light through. Some floating sediment and yeast. Soapy off-white four finger high head forms after a quick pour. Settles down to a dirty cap with plenty of lacing and retention. Leaves behind a slick coating with each sip.

S - Super juicy grapefruit with some peach, mango, and orange. Just a hint of some biscuity and bready malts. Simply perfect.

T - Orange juice. A touch of sour grapefruit and light floral and grass. Not getting much of a malt backbone. Just some faint buttery biscuit notes that work really well with the intense orange and grapefruit notes. Really clean and refreshing with a pleasant but quick bitterness on the finish. Medium moth feel with low carbonation. Alcohol is not noticeable at all. Taste is identical from the can...

O - This is unbelievably easy drinking, I¬ím afraid this four pack isn¬ít going to last very long. Which sucks since the inflated shop price was $18. I don¬ít think its one of the best beers in the world, but it is really high up when it comes to DIPA¬ís.

Have had from can, and on tap at Alchemist before it was destroyed by Irene. Aroma- Intense piney, floral the instant you open the can, and it continues throughout the drinking. Appearance- typically drink from a can, but when poured, it is a rich, hazy gold. Taste- A full bodied hoppy bitterness tempered by slight citrusy sweetness which allows the beer to have a smoothness one would think impossible from such a high IBU brew. Palate- a medium bodied brew with lively carbonation. As said, is quite smooth, but finishes bitter, with the hops back to the forefront. Overall- A fantastic Double IPA that is surprisingly easy to drink, but does not sacrifice an ounce of flavor for that.

Several cans, from the can. Aroma is a burst of juicy fruity hops; pinneaples, mangos and oranges. Some wet grass and resinous hops which tends to fade as the beer gets older. Taste: I¬íd say it is the best tasting double IPA I¬íve ever had. Flavors are very coherent with the aroma. Definitly hops at its best. The perfect level of bitterness with a sharp citrus touch. Balance and drinkability is through the roof and alcohol is very well hidden. The ultimate beach beverage.

I gotta say, wow, great pour, heady topper indeed, literally huge.  Taste is awesome, bitter, sweet, fruity, and sticky as hell.  Dark murky orange color.  One of the best, if not the best dipas I have come across.  Had from a 16 oz can.  Definitely a keeper.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2015 Half from the can: as soon as you crack it, you get blasted by piney citrus hops.  Very drinkable from the can.. I could have kept going, but I had to give it a look...poured into tulip: cloudy golden, excessive sediment despite careful pour.  Aroma remains true.  Full bodied, full flavored,some carbonated kick, a hint of alcohol burn. Nice big bitterness throughout and lasts intO next drink.  Floral, grapefruit, evergreen... Sweet sour bitter. A resounding winner.

Can.  Pours a cloudy straw gold with thick head.  The aroma is piney, citrusy hops with a similar flavor.  The aftertaste is resinous and very bitter which detracts from this beer in my opinion.  I would prefer the citrus aroma and flavor with less bitter aftertaste.

Going to try to rate this as instructed on can. Aroma has citrus, bright dry hops, and some tropics but it is a bitch to get a nose full through this little opening and swirling the can is going to result in me spilling it somehow. Mouth feel is medium and there is good carbonation. Flavor is a big old hoppy blast, citrus, grapefruit, medium bitterness, and a kick of pines.

 I can¬ít do this anymore.... Getting a glass.

 Pour is surprisingly hazy, amber in color, and has a bit of sediment. Nose is so much more punchy in a proper glass really opening up the tropical fruit and grapefruit. Flavor is actually less intense somehow in the glass with the bitterness and resins less concentrated. I left a good bit in the can and going back to compare it there is really a noticeable difference even sipped back to back. Bottom line this is a fantastic beer regardless of what vessel it comes in!

Can from hbmason...thanks Tim! Pour hazy amber with massive chunky floaties in mass quantities. Wow. I¬ím all for some floaties, but this is ridiculous. All sorts of hops in this one--big tropical fruity hops, a touch of garlic, pine, and some hot, spicy hops. Just a massive nose, and a lot of sweet malt in the background. Taste is equally as big, but the heat comes through more, along with the grassy, spicy hops. Not as much tropical fruit hoppiness, though there¬ís more citrus rind that comes through. A bit of heat in the long finish, but mostly just big juicy, bitter hops. The malt thickens it up and it¬ís too sweet for my liking on the finish, but I suppose this beer isn¬ít supposed to be an exercise in restraint. It¬ís still tasty, even if the sweetness means I couldn¬ít drink more than one at a time. Which, being a DIPA, I suppose I wouldn¬ít want to. Big, thick and slick in the mouth, this one really fills up the glass.

Amazing. Smell is all hops. Tropical fruits, citrus, and grass. Taste is grapefruit pineapple mango and citrus. Touch of malt balances the intense hop and resin flavors. Finish is perfectly bitter and dry. Every bit as good as the hype. Awesome brew. My only problem is that I don't have any more. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16oz. Can:  Aroma of holy hops!  Scents of hops, pine, resin, hop oil, grass, grapefruit, citrus, and a hint of caramel malt.  Poured amber in color with a tiny, off-white head that disappeared quickly.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny, small, and massive-sized particles throughout.  Flavor is heavily bitter.  Tastes of hops, pine, resin, grass, hop oil, citrus, and caramel malt.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Heavily bitter, hop, pine, resin, citrus, grass finish is dry.  8%ABV is completely hidden throughout.
Can. Pours copper with a small head, decent lacing, and some unfiltered resin. Aroma is full of weed and floral hops. Taste is bitter and full of herbs. Amazing brew.

From the Can. Every bit as good as people have been saying it is. Rich Tropical hop aroma, Hops smack my palate, I get Mango, pineapple and some citrus. The Alcohol isn¬ít noticeable and this goes down very easily. Very clean and fresh. Best IPA of the year so far and reminds me of the Kernel beers from London.
Yes, it¬ís that good.  Smells like a citrus jungle, looks like a golden haze and tastes like a hoppy, creamy dreamsicle.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2013 Per the instructions on the can, I did not pour into a glass.  I will do that next time though to see the difference.  A strong aroma still comes through pretty well out of the can and I love it.  Hop resin aroma is big along with some malt and maybe spruce?  Taste reminds me Bell¬ís Hop Slam.  Incredibly smooth, oily texture, nice malt backbone and amazing finish leaving the resin and spruce on the tongue for a long long time.  Drank this so fast because it was just delicious.  Probably the best Imperial IPA I have had.  Re-rate 5/5/13 - Just traded for a bunch of this fresh and it¬ís amazing.  And for some reason it¬ís so much better from the can than pouring into a glass.  Aroma and taste is packed with pine and spruce mostly but some floral notes and malt make it through.  Super fresh hop flavor and so smooth while being so bitter at the same time.  This stuff is seriously awesome.

Hazy orange pour thin white head .... aroma is of grapefruits, oranges, peaches and pineapples wow very fruity aroma .... taste is of dank earthy hops, very very citrusy: peaches, grapefruits, oranges, pineapple a very fruity ipa, rindy and not overly sugary .... bitter rindy hops throughout ... reminds me of three floyds dreadnaught ... abv hidden throughout .... mouthfeel is smooth, balanced, little oily and lives up to the hype

On tap at the cannery in Waterbury, VT. Pours a cloudy, bright orange colored body with a golden hue. Inch thick, very dense, creamy and frothy, pure white head that dissipates slowly and leaves a veil of lacing. Gorgeous beer. Aroma is awesome. Tons of fresh, juicy citruses with plenty of grapefruits, tangerines, and oranges. Lots of tropical fruits with some pineapple showing up with pines and florals galore. Very nice caramel backing offering a nice sweetness that accentuates the freshness and resins from the hops. Flavor is...wow. So many fresh pineapples, grapefruits, tangerines, oranges, and tropical fruits. Very juicy in the middle with pines and florals accompanied by a soft malt backing with a light caramel and pale malt sweetness. Resins come on nicely towards the end as this finishes juicy, moderately bitter, and filled with fruits as this dries nicely and remains soft and balanced. Lengthy aftertaste following an ultra soft, medium-light body and a very gentle, moderate carbonation. Overall, this is definitely worth the hype. Soooo many fresh fruits and plenty of bright pine resins and florals with such a soft and easy drinking palate. Wow, I came a long way for this one and it was worth every mile. Absolutely outstanding.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2016 Pounder can from PUB¬íR courtesy of a Vermont operative (the Pennsylvania Underground Beer Railroad, which I am founder and chairman of).  Pours turbid orange with 2-finger white head and some floaties.  Looks like Dreadnaught, so that¬ís a great start.  Nose is complex and huge; a medley of tropical fruit, including mango, papaya, pineapple, tangerine, black peppery spice, and caramel malt.  Tastes incredibly hoppy, tropical fruity, resiny, and peppery, with a huge malt bill that balances the hops well.  The mouthfeel is dense, complex, and the finish pounds the papillae with hops, tropical fruit, and spicy peppery flavor.  The repour gets thicker, more turbid, with a huge amount of flocculence,

A can with no date via a trade with 46er3498. Pours (into my glass, although I did try some out of the can as instructed) with a very lightly hazed golden hued body with a large and lasting, frothy, eggshell hued head. Body hue is on par with west coast hop bombs (light in color). Pretty good retention and solid lace. Aromas are floral, hoppy, resin, pine, grapefruit pith, tangerine, mild candied and tropical fruits, grassy. Smells pretty tasty. Floral, very minimal malt and clean yeast wise. Its all about the hops as it should be. Flavors are citrusy, grassy and floral with light tropical fruit. Medium bitterness with quite a bit of resin character. Tangerine, grapefruit and some (medium) notes of high cohumulone hops that leave a bit of a tickle at the back of the throat. Very light bready and malty qualities, medium alcohol. Medium to slightly fuller carbonation, medium bodied, lasting resins, dry. Quite good, but I might lean towards fresh Surly Abrasive (especially as they have easy to find canned on dates). Solid.

I¬íve had it from the can and from a glass.  It pours a hazy pale amber with a nice white head.  The color is fittingly not too unlike the color of grapefruit juice.  The aroma is unbelievable with an extremely pungent bouquet of hoppy, citrus, grapefruit awesomeness and some floral notes.  The taste is more of the same, very dry with intense hoppy flavor and bitterness.  Literally like drinking carbonated grapefruit juice, this brew is spectacular.  An instant all-time favorite.

Can [500ml] shared with garthicus & HogTownHarry -- c/o garthicus. March 21. Pours a hazy copper-gold with a small diminishing frothy white head. Great aroma with tons of grapefruit, tropical fruit, resiny/catty/hempy hops and a touch of sweetness. Flavour is just as good and follows the aroma: Very citrusy, catty and hempy along with some sweetness and a big bitter finish. Alcohol is pretty well hidden. Medium bodied. Fantastic stuff!

pours a murky yellow hue with head - aroma is of tropical fruits, yeast, and of course hops
flavor is refreshing with hints of spice, orange peel, pineapple and wheat in it
medium mouthfeel with light carbonation
great brew!

471ml can. The Alchemist people insist you drink from the can, but I shared this with maddmaxstar so I poured half into a glass for him. The half that was poured out was a cloudy yellow/orange with a moderate head and some particulate. Aroma is both a citrus sweetness and bitterness with some pine notes. Taste is very hopsy with some earthy hops as well at the citrus. Taste is very well balanced, it is hopsy without being overly bitter. Body is light enough to be highly drinkable. Overall, this is a DIPA that could have broader appeal, which is kind of fascinating.

Re-reviewing the Heady Topper from The Alchemist. I know I promised never to drink this one outside of the can again, but I thought a snifter glassed might do Heady Topper some justice. And I was right.
Score (snifter): 97

Canned 01/12/12 and enjoyed 01/21/12 in a snifter glass. This is about as fresh as you can get this in the Midwest. Thank you AdamJackson for hooking me up with this brew this time around!

Appearance: Like my previous pour in a Duvel tulip, Heady Topper is a hazy orange-amber color with a finger of super foamy cream-colored head that sticks around for a bit, settling into a ring around the glass. Slightly below average lacing -- leaves behind an oily layer with no sticky head. 4/5

Smell: Less than 10 days old, this one has even bigger notes of citrus than my first can did. LOTS of intense, fresh tropical fruits -- oranges, grapefruits, pineapple, papaya and mangoes. Fresh grass clippings and dank resin. The nose is absolutely packed with bright, floral hops. I stand by my original sentiment: that this is like sniffing "a sunshine of citrus." Even after having Pliny The Elder, Blind Pig, White Rajah, Anit-Hero IPA and Zombie Dust, Heady Topper is still the best smelling heavily hopped beer that I have ever had. Short of Surly Darkness, this is the best smelling beer that I have had to date. I still "wish I could buy an air-freshener that smelled just like this!" 5/5

Taste: Zesty lemon rind and tropical fruit with a sharp malty backbone throughout. Huge waves of citrus. In my original review, I felt the taste was mellower and more subdued than the aroma. Having a sampled a fresher can (my original can was just under a month old), I can say that my original sentiment no longer stands. Heady Topper is sharply bitter, loaded with tropical citrus and malty. Oranges, lemons, mangos, pineapple, papaya, and rainbow sherbert throughout. You name your citrus, it¬ís here. The sharp bitterness is more earthy and dank than piney. Finish is a lingering orange citrus hoppiness. 5/5

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied, medium-high carbonation. The Citra hops really explode on the palate like a Citra hop bomb. Finish is dry and bitter with a little stickiness. 4.5/5

Overall: Though this beer is hard to find because it is only sold in a few places in Vermont, it is well worth the effort that it takes to get ahold of this brew. Heady Topper an absolute must try beer. While I have softened my original "you must drink this out of a can" stance, I still think it should be enjoyed in a vessel that minimizes the oxidation of volatiles present in the brew and maximizes the concentration of the aroma. In other words, serve this in a snifter and not a tulip glass. Even my friend who hates IPAs enjoyed this one.

Recommendation: This is an absolutely must-seek out imperial IPA. Drink it from the can or a snifter glass.

Food Pairings: Kuma¬ís Corner hamburgers or spicy Mexican food.

Cost: $12 for a four pack.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2015 Can 1 pint.
Note: drank from can, but sampled in glass too.
Pours hazy golden, low white head, some lacing.
Aroma is of grapefruits, pine, fruits. Taste is of grapefruits, other sweeter fruits, christmas tree gone wild, pine, resin. Very refreshing, good bitterness. Incredible balance. Packed with hops. Certainly one of the best DIPA on the shelves.

Can poured into a duvel glass. Oops didn¬ít read the instructions first. Big thanks to fbm115 for a very generous bonus! It pours a hazy orange color with a big off white head. The aroma is really complex hoppy with nice notes of florals, spicy hop, grapefruit, tangerine and a little cat pee. The flavor is off the charts with tangy grapefruit up front followed by minor notes of sweet peaches, pineapple and oranges, finishing off with a bitter/spicy hop finish. The body is perfectly light and crisp considering the gravity. Absolutely delicious. One of the best IPA¬ís I¬íve had.

Can from Miamilice (Thanks!). Pours bright orange with soapy white head that fades to a film and lacing. Aroma is bright fruity pineapple and grapefruit. Taste is more fresh pineapple and grapefruit with a solid bitter resinous hops and just the right amount of malt to round it off. Palate is sticky and chalky with a dry finish. Awesome balance and alcohol is well hidden!

Can shared by portableparty!  Clear dark apricot pour, medium carbonation and a dry hop aroma.  Flavor is slick, slightly sweet hops and left an aftertaste of dry bitter oranges and hops.  Alcohol on this is well hidden, very nice!

Shared by Jeff at Caleb's - pineapple grapefruit nose. Thin white head, golden in color. Taste hoppy, fresh, light and snappy. Excellent!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

16 ounce can from my friend Brett. Thanks! Pours a hazy amber color with a medium sized white frothy head. Good head retention. Aroma of earthy and resin hops with big caramel and other malt notes. The taste is nutty caramel malts and lots of hop notes.. earthy, citrus, resin and tropical. Medium bodied, low carbonation, well balanced. Quite nice.

What a great beer thanks Ernesto987 for letting me indulge. This is a chunky beer the smell ooooohhh the smell so good it¬ís like they picked some hops and just put them in the can I can¬ít say anymore what a great beer.

Pours light coppery orange with a nice thin white head there is a suprising amount of sediment floating about. Great aroma! Tons of tropical fruit, pineapple, tangerine, mango, grapefruit, also pleanty of pine. The flavor is big on hop resin, pine and grapefruit. There are some sweet flavors in there but I¬íd defiantly lable this as on the dry side. This beer has some very lively carbonation, and a nice sticky mouthfeel. The finish is pretty dry, the aggressive hops really leave a nice feel on the palate.

Can thanks to bauermj.  Brilliant gold with all sorts of floating garbage - nice.  Big, big floral pine, grapefruit and at the end a little citrus.  Flavor is smooth, sticky grapefruit and citrus bitterness with a little pine. Enough malt to balance the hops a bit, but not much in the flavor department.  Was expecting a bit more palate presence.  Residual sticky citrus and grapefruit.  Fresh.  Crisp.  Phenominal.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2013 pours a very hazy peach color with loads of sediment floating around and white ring. The nose has a fair bit of citrus and notes of grapefruit. Faint undertone of a sweet caramel malt. The flavor is nice, sweet hops and malts blend together but seems well attenuated. Light grapefruit and bitter citrus round off the dominant hop presence as the bitterness lingers for a moment but doesn¬ít disrupt the drinkability. The body is very inviting with a gentle tingling carbonation and a smooth soft feel to it.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2014 Completely edited. Can. An extra from phillycraft, thanks Vin! Hazy yellow/golden with a beautiful white head and nice lacing. If it was not of all the particles, it would gain 1 or 2 appearance points. Taste is incredible with tons of tropical fruits (mango, pineapple, orange) along with piney notes. Taste is also extremely fruity along with pine, decent malt backbone and some grassy notes. Good bitterness. Mouthfeel is dry. Medium body. Alcohol is well hidden. Great balance and drinkability

Directly from can as instructed (purchased at the Alchemist cannery). Incredible hops aroma, very strong citrus and floral notes. Taste is bitter, as we should expect from the advertised 120 IBUs, but is not too harsh. Incredibly easy to drink for such a strong and hoppy beer, definitely of my favourite IPAs... (and if you dare to pour it into a glass, appearance is light orange, really hazy, with hops resin swirling all around)

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2012 Drank from the can as instructed. I thought Pliny the Elder was the best IPA untill I had some Heady Topper. It¬ís definitely on the same level. There is a hops explosion upfront with grapefruit and smooth pine cone. The carbonation kicks in and transitions this to an almost candy-like smoothness on the back end. The smell is pure hops. This beer is hoppy as hell and still maintains a strong balance.

Pours a motor oil yellow -orange, two finger white bubbly head.  Smells like mango, pineapple,  sweet goodness!  Taste is hoppy with a quick bite and then a smooth sour finish...not too bitter. This beer is so drinkable...so lucky to have it locally!

Appearance: Pours out a hazy, light yellow-orange body strewn with fine particles and topped with a barely off-white head.

Smell: Heavy, heady resins, staunch florals, crushed aspirin tablets, and a squirt of white grapefruit juice over a thin cracker-toned malt base.

Taste: Lightly bready, lightly crackery malts with just a little bit of honeyish sweetness. Strongly floral, heavily resinous rounded with a fruity kick of grapefruit. Medium-high bitterness. Dry, citrusy, pithy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Oily mouthfeel.

Overall: Not bad. Not bad at all.

Can generously shared by blotz and sparky - thanks, guys!  Pours golden in color with a fluffy white head.  Smells from an arm¬ís length away of hops.  Packed with bitter citrus and crisp malt.  The can is like it¬ís own randle.  This was a month old and tasted like it just got done with fermentation.  An amazing IPA.

Style et r√©sum√©: Double IPA am√©ricaine tr√®s houblonn√©e.  
Comment: Canette de 12oz. merci  Patrick. 
Description: J¬íaime les IPA/Double IPA quand le malt caramel ne prend pas toute la robe comme ici o√π la bi√®re est jaune trouble. Le nez est tropical, pamplemousse, marmelade d¬íagrumes et de jus d¬íorange. La bouche est piquante, le gaz carbonique est bien pr√©sent et pique le bout de la langue. L¬íalcool est pr√©sent. Il y a une forte amertume en fin de bouche qui il me semble est herbeuse. La sensation n¬íest pas trop agr√©able en bouche. Un autre exemplaire en f√ªt ou en bouteille serait appr√©ci√©. 
Note:  7/10

Can.  Aroma has notes of crazy citrus, tropical fruits, caramel malts and flowers.  Great hoppy aroma!   Light orange amber hue with lots of small particles and a small off-white head that fully diminished and left little lace.  Flavor is heavy sweet and bitter.  Palate is very full bodied and oily soft.  Overall a great hop bomb.  Great tropical citrus notes and sweet flavor.  Loved it.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2012 Pours a beautiful golden orange with a white head. Aromas of grapefruit,orange, lemon, cut grass and pine. Flavors are awseome, bitter to sweet. Finishes dry. So drinkable. Amazing IPA. Well worth the wait.

(trade w/LIVEFAST) 16oz, Can - Upon craking the pop-top you¬íre greeted with a huge pine need/resin aroma. Pours a rocky yellowish head. Very cloudy dusky yellow body. Lots of big bubbles can be seen in the glass. Not overly heavy mouthfeel. Flavor packed with grapefruit and tangerine. Hop character more pronounced on the back end. A lot of DIPA are thick and take quite some time to drink. This one is quite drinkable.

16 oz. can courtesy of daknole - Pours a hazy amber color with a one and a half finger thick off white head.  Aroma is big time citrus, pine, and floral hops.  Flavor is much of the same with the addition of some light malt swwetness and resin hops.  The has some lingering bitterness, but not too astringent.  Medium body.  A great beer.

drank from can as advised from the can itself.  Aroma is amazing, floral with strong citrus fruits.  Lots of grapefruit.  Taste is grapefruit with strong floral notes.  nice malt backbone doesn¬ít leave the palate destroyed.  nice finish.  great beer.  Wish it was available in Hawaii.
freaking awesome. huge hop aroma, hops over power the strong malt presence, exactly what i like in a double ipa. more please. thanks Andrew!
Can from ??? Medium golden pour. Big grapefruity hop aroma. Aggressive grapefruity bitterness. Awesome flavor, piney , grapefruit heavy. Seek this one out

12oz cans from a trade with indyjb (Kevin) thanks again. Pale orange in color with medium carbonation and a bit dirty in the pour, lots of floaties. Aroma is of citrus bomb with a tropical touch and malts. More sweet citrus and pines in the mouth, along with a solid pale malt presence. Solid bitterness. Sweet without being malty or cloying. A west coast hop profile with a mid-west malt bill.  Tasty stuff.

Shared at Jackie-O¬ís. Poured from a 16 ounce can into a snifter. Appearance is a hazy gold with a fluffy white head of foam. Aroma is well hopped beer. A pretty hefty dose citrus and resin reach the nose upon first sniff. Taste is a potent mix of hop bitterness and faint sweetness. I thoroughly enjoyed this beer. Wish I had more of it. Thanks for sharing!

(Une canette qui provient d¬íun √©change avec Marheb)  Un liquide qui pr√©sente une robe jaune passablement travers√©e par de nombreux s√©diments.  Un col mousseux bien mince.  Un nez fortement expressif.  Une attaque de houblons fruit√©s.  Des tonnes d¬íagrumes fra√Æchement press√©s : des pamplemousses et des oranges.  Des houblons floraux et r√©sineux : la pin√®de et les merveilles de la nature.  Une pr√©sence malt√©e qui conna√Æt son r√¥le : une touche mielleuse qui ne semble pas vouloir contenir l¬íexplosion des cultivars.  Des saveurs tr√®s intenses.  Des agrumes qui mordent la langue.  De la r√©sine qui √©corche les papilles.  Du parfum.  Un crescendo de notes citriques qui m√®ne √† une crispation de ma cavit√© buccale.  Des malts qui ne sont jamais capables de contenir cette orgie houblonn√©e.  Une bouche qui m¬í√©tonne quelque peu : le p√©tillement est soutenue et presque trop actif.  Un corps qui est de moyenne densit√© avec une texture qui me semble √™tre √† la limite huileuse.  Une finale qui est la savante combinaison de notes houblonn√©es fruit√©es et r√©sineuses qui cherchent l¬íintensit√© et la longueur.

Can (thanks Stephen): Poured a cloudy light yellow color ale with large chunks of protein floating around and a large foamy head with good retention. Aroma of super intense pine hops notes with some citrus and resin notes. Taste is also a super intense mix of pine, resin and light citrus undertones hops with a dry malt backbone that is hard to distinguish from the hops attack. The floral aromas are huge end very enjoyable. Body is full with great carbonation. I must admit the hype is totally justified for this one, truly one of the great IIPA.

16 oz can.  Cloudy yellow brown with an off-white head.  Nose is orange, pine, caramel and pink grapefruit.  Chewy with a buzz.  Lots of hops but not so resiny.  Taste is unsweetened grapefruit juice, gin, lime and orange peel. What a great citrus melange.

Can from BeerPilgrim11.  What a great beer this is; all the high scores are certainly justified!  This starts off with a huge tropical fruit aroma; melons, mango, grapefruit, it¬ís like a uber-hopped summer fruit cocktail.  The pour is a rusty gold color with a thin off-white head that yields some spotty lacing.  The flavor is just as impressive as the scent, if not more, offering lemon, herbal, and grassy flavors that join the big tropical fruit melange.  Not overly bitter but crisp and chalk full of aromatic hops.  The finish is dry, bitter, and long-lasting.  It¬ís tasty as hell, has lots of hops, but is also clean and refreshing.  This beer is incredible.  I¬íd love to do a taste test with this and Pliny the Elder and I wouldn¬ít be shocked if I found this to be better.

Appearance: Proud golden orange, TONS of floaters, medium white head. Aroma: Super pineapple, mango, cat piss, lemons and tons of hops, just smells great. Flavour: Bitter, good floral notes, lots of pine and cat piss, nice malt backbone too, pineapple and mango finish, quite lovely.

Appears a cloudy deep honey color with a nice off white head that falls to a skim and stays. Mild lacing.

The smell is of grapefruit, topical fruit. A juicy fruity nose with some nice rich malt lingering in the mix.

The taste is really wonderful. This is a great DIPA. It¬ís wet and juicy, tropical fruit, mild bitterness. Really damn good.

I loved the mouthfeel of this brew. Light/medium in body it is wet and refreshing...and it¬ís 8%!

So this is a delectable brew and should be sought out if you are into IPAs at all.

Can..Hazy golden pour,fluffy white head,good lace. Aroma is huge citrus fruit notes,pine needles,dank and resinous.Malt sweetness upfront leads to an excellent hop bitterness that builds as you continue to drink it. Juicy hops,strong resin notes,long lingering bitterness in the finish. Medium bodied and carbonation. The drinkability of this beer is ridiculous. Amazing.
Can. Light golden with frothy head. Heavy, heavy pine & hops aroma. initial citrus taste then piney hops the rest of the way that finishes excellently. I want more of this.

1 PINT can from pushkinwow (thanks!), served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Bright deep golden with a nice white head.
  
Aroma:  A true hop tonic, so dank and resinous and piney and citrusy, and fresh and juice and and and, there is sufficient biscuit malt for support but the hops truly shines, lemons and grapefruits and blood oranges...oh my.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, full, soft effervescence.
  
Flav.:  huge, oily, resinous, citrusy, piney, dank hops (sound familiar?), sweet biscuity malts, honey, a little yeasty, wow; sweet with big bitterness and a long, bitter, wonderfully hoppy finish.

No wonder this is so highly rated.  An ode to hops if there ever was one.

Got in a trade thanks to Circlenine, cheers and happy St Paddy¬ís day!

Poured into Tulilp (had one from the can the other day, looking to compare). Bunch of sediment, two or three fingers of white head, decent retention. Smell is pure hoppieness. More on the fruity citrus side. Taste is smooth, almost closer to sweet than bitter. Viscous and fruity, very balanced, very drinkable. Very good IPA.

3/2/12 - Excellent IPA served in a can and poured into a chalice even though the can says not to. Oh well

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Huge thanks to pushkinwow for this one.  I drank the first half as recommended, straight from the can... while having the first BBQ of the year might I add.  Huge aroma when you stick your nose in the can.Lots of citrus, lots of pine.  Tastes of quite a bit of pineapple, grapefruit. Tons of resin. Actually really bitter compared to a lot of DIPA. When I poured the 2nd half into a glass, it¬ís a golden honey colour with floating flakes throughout.  Wish I could get more.

Can consumed between FOBAB and Three Floyds 15th anniversary release.  Pours golden orange with a big white head. Aroma is big citrus pine and nice grassiness with the tropical and grapefruit character. Flavor is all the same, very fresh citric and resin character, all with a nice balanced malt backbone. Medium to medium full body and a crisp carbonation. Damn fine beer

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2013 Pine, citrus, classic american hops.  Subtle tropical fruit, tons of resin.  Dry finish, very full flavored, subtle wheaty-cereal grain hiding underneath big, beautiful hops.  giant fluffy white head when poured.

From a 16oz can into a clear plastic tumbler. Looks like a hefeweizen. Smells like walking through a sassafras grove on the warm summer afternoon. For its vividness and abv the beer is very balanced and soothing. Clingy, refreshing, layers of soft resinous dewy golden flowers, fruits, and herbs. Sweet vs bitter battle long toward a no decision. Can¬ít recall a better strong IPA in this classic American style.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 Can at home, courtesy of Frank. Thanks buddy! Poured a hazy, bright orange, with a big off-white head. The smell of this beer is off the charts, just fresh hopiness. Aromas of grapefruit, citrus, pine, and big resin. I could smell this beer all night long. The lacing is sticking around nicely. Taste is bitter from the start and continues throughout, I am not picking up much malt at all - pine, citrus, weed, grass, and biscuit. This beer is just hoppy, hoppy, hoppy, and I love it. A hophead¬ís dream. Delicious.

Can shared by bhensonb. Pours dirty blonde with a thick off-white head and a citrus aroma. There is a very satisfying sweet caramel malt flavor with nice balancing hop bitterness that doesn¬ít seem like 120 IBU. Very tasty.
Can. Pours hazy amber with a near-white head. Strong resin/citrus aroma. Med body. Flavor is grapefruit ring with maybe a little resin. There¬ís a nice malt backbone, which struggles to stay afloat.

Hazy orange/straw hue with 1 finger white head. Best lacing I have seen on a beer, no visible carbonation. Citrus (orange/lemon) and pine hops in the back. Pine hops dominate, mostly bitter hops with a good malt background. Slightly grainy. Light to medium bodied

From notes.  First reviewed 10/14/2011.  Poured from a 16 oz. can into a tulip. Thanks to CharlieMurphy for dropping this in my box.

Out of the can, Heady Topper has a bright orange amber color, slightly hazy, with a soft sea foam froth.

Pale malt, some honey, and a long drawn out bitterness. Pine, grapefruit, and a little spice.

The flavor starts with a little malt sweetness and toasted grains, then moves to a blend of hoppy bitterness - pine, grapefruit, and a bit of herbal spice. The finish is a straight bitterness.

The body is slightly fuller than medium for the style. Grainy character, with some hoppy resin from the middle to the end. Medium carbonation.

Heady Topper has a strong, pleasant bitterness, with the hop flavors taking a backseat. Good, but I don¬ít see how it really differentiates itself from the top notch DIPA¬ís.

16oz can as an extra in my growler swap box. Rating #233. Very cloudy, almost looks like a hefeweizen, dark yellow in color with some orange highlights and a small white head. Decent citrus aroma with a little onion in there mixed with some pine. Above average bitterness, a touch of sweetness, mild citrus and pine. Decent stuff. (2229)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Thanks to the chap in line that shared this with me at Hunahpu 2012. Nose is huge grapefruit and orange. Earthy as well. Incredible aroma. Pour was a light amber color with some light off white head. Taste was full of citrus and grass with some light honey malt. Dry as hell on the finish with an effect that makes you come back for more. Excellent DIPA.
Can. Pours a nice amber. Pine tar aroma is almost stinky. Flavor is highly pine pitch with some slight sweetness. Really nice.
The aroma is full of grapefruit, resin, and pine resin.  The flavor is spicier than expected but mostly dominated by sweet malts.  Very bready and full of caramel.  Great balance.  Fantastico!
Very nice citrus smell. Can¬ít see what it looks like as its in the can ;) . This is the definition of a dipa. Bitter and sweet and Fucking unreal

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2012 Notes from 10/19/11.  Thanks to Jnorton00 for this brew. It¬ís better than Pliny (the Elder). The quintessential camping beer (and yes, the can contributes to this moniker). Everything you want and nothing you don¬ít. Better price point than Dreadnaught; just can¬ít decide if it¬ís better. I guess it¬íll take another night of "research" to come to a conclusion :)

Update: After a head to head comparison the next day, this beer edges Dreadnaught. And for the value, it blows it out of the water.

I had this on tap at The Alchemist last summer.The color is a hazy honey with a thick off white head. The aroma is an overpowering of hops and more hops what a pleasure with citrus fruits mostly grapefruit. The taste all of the above plus that great bitterness.The aftertaste is long lasting wich is again great. This was just so wonderfull.

Seriously citrusy on the nose.  Even though Alchemist recommends drinking this from the can I had to see the first one I¬íve had the chance to try, sue me there¬ís 23 more in the case to drink "properly"...  Anyway, it pours a hazy straw with an off white head.  Tastes as delicious as it looks.  Big bad hops that don¬ít over power the taste buds.  This one has some serious drinkability.  Finishes dry and clean and leaves you reaching for another.
Really hoppy, bitter, malty filling. Pale, sweet, like a light American barley wine, the malt backbone really stands out.

Tall can shared by HH brother Sajaad. Golden pour with thin head. Aroma was full of sweet tropical hops. Very nice hop profile with a touch of sweetness and just the right amount of bitterness if you will. Reminded me of Hill Farmstead but a bit less bitter. Great stuff. Thanks man.

I¬íve had this quite a few times now (on tap, bottle, and can).  Finally getting around to reviewing it.  Currently drinking it from the can.  Waves of earthy, grapefruit-laced, hops on the nose.  Flavor is chewy grapefruit hops with a nice resiny body.  Ideal level of bitterness throughout.  Goes down so easy.  This beer definitely deserves the hype.  Not the best DIPA I¬íve ever had, but still excellent.  So glad they started canning this year round.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2012 "Stopped by the Alchemist cannery the other day on a recent trip to VT and sampled some freshly brewed Heady Topper. All I can say is, WOW! By far, one of the best beers that I¬íve tried to date, regardless of style, and a sure ¬ëmust-try¬í for all who appreciate the finer beers of the world. Hoping that this becomes more available in MA, because as of now, there are only a few places that you can enjoy this ¬ëworld-class¬í brew. I¬íve yet to try Pliny the Elder and/or Younger, but have read that this DIPA rivals both. If you get the opportunity to try this beer, it¬ís a must. Kudos Alchemist, looking forward to other offerings in the near future."

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2012 Smells of pine hops with a bit of honey sweetness and a touch of metallic copper.  Taste is better than the nose - honey caramel malt, danh hoppy bitterness, and a hint of bitterness.  Crisp dry feel.  Not quite as good as the hype built it up to be.

Can. Pour is hazy orange/yellow with a nice white head, excellent retention/lace. Aroma is dank hops, orange, tangerine, grapefruit, light pine/floral notes, light caramel malt. Taste is quite bitter, big tangerine/orange hops with minimal malt sweetness. Palate is drier, very oily, soft, bitter finish. Outstanding - as good as Pliny or Dreadnaught.

Gift from SJ. A very interesting beer. I love the bold floral, hoppy and citrus aroma.

I¬ím also a fan of the full body, earthy/ fruit/orange peel/ grassy and caramel malt flavors. It¬ís a bold beer that delivers much on the senses.
It finishes dry / sharpp and slightly nutty. It¬ís a thumbs up for me.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2012 Count me out on this one, boys.  Weirdly sweet, with a somewhat funky hop bouquet that makes me think of that oniony Summit taste.  Not as bad as Gubna, of course, and for fleeting whiffs I get a nice citrus character that makes me think the hype is justified, but overall this gets a thumb down from me.

e: On retry, an improved if not wonderful experience.  Still a bit on the sweet side for my liking, but not terrible.

Can from sloth... Bright orange in color, nice head. Great nose of citrus, pine and tropical fruits. Taste follows the nose. Very juicy, tropical fruits, pine notes. Good shit. Very hoppy but balanced. No trace of the alcohol. Body is on the lighter side, medium carbonation. Really easy to drink. Overall: This beer rocks! Thans bert!
Right there with Pliney as the best beer I¬íve ever had.  Lives up to the hype.

Can from Ernesto. Pours a murky orange amber with an ivory head. Bold aroma of floral and citrusy hops. Fuller side of medium bodied with perfect carbonation and an earthy mouthfeel. Nice subtle pale malt backdrop with a note of honey, but hops just bombard the palate with grapefruit and tangerine, with a hint of pine. Bitter and dry resiny finish. I mean this is a hop bomb and just smacks you in the face. Addictively great. Probably the best IIPA I have had to date. Pliny, I think it¬ís time to start seeing other people. I found someone else and she¬ís got bigger cans.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2012 16oz can...supposedly canned on Feb 14th 2012, but no date noted on the can.  Served at around 45F.  Big thanks to Ryan for this trade!!!

Pours very hazy if not a bit chunky orange with a one finger off-white head that retains well and leaves some rings of lacing behind.

Aroma is fresh orange, tangerine and grapefruit citrus, pineapple and peaches, some sniffs tend more toward a dank and piney hop profile.  Overall a citrus and fruity hop bomb.  Malt?  Why bother...  Very good to excellent strength.

Flavor is an onslaught of all the things that make a great IPA.  Tons of orange, tangerine and grapefruit citrus, pineapple, some pine, resinous and a little dank, minimal malt backbone, fantastic strong bitterness on the finish and a bit of alcohol.  Super JUICY!

Mouthfeel is medium bodied, oily and sticky with good carbonation.

An incredible, world-class Double IPA that is more than worthy of all the praise it receives.  Very complex for the style, it¬ís got a little of everything a hophead desires.  While I should be going slow and savoring my only can, this is dangerously drinkable and going down pretty fast.  Fantastic!

Delicious IPA out of a Tall boy can.  Pours straw gold with a moderate head that doesn¬ít persist all too long.  Can says to not pour into glass, and it IS good out of a can, hop resins in it they say.  I pour into a glass all the same, I feel like my snifter can bring the nose out more.

Aroma: It reminds me of simcoe and amarillo, though I don¬ít know if either are present.  Huge notes of grapefruit and pine.  Onion and a skunky aroma follow, in a good way of course.  It¬ís dank and citrusy.

Taste: Citrus to start, mostly grapefruit.  A resiny piney finish.  Every sip is a burst of flavor, and there are layers upon layers of hoppy goodness.  As the glass warmed up it only got more intense.  I like intense, but I think I enjoy it most slightly chilled.  Malt isn¬ít really present, nor is alcohol.

Palate: Smooth.  Very smooth.   Perhaps bottle conditioned?  It has this silky texture that is really unique for this style of beer.  I get this sensation with most canned ales, I just need to get used to it(or its in my head, gubna comes to mind..).  I would almost say I¬íd like a bit more carbonation to give it more bite.  Very pleasant all the same.

Overall:  Get it.  It¬ís worth your money, any day.  This isn¬ít a novelty ipa; I could drink it every day and never stop smiling.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2012 (16oz can from beer_no_evil).  Pours a hazy, unfiltered golden color with a sticky white head.  Aroma has some dank hops along with some tropical fruits like papaya and unripened mango.  Taste is sweet malts with a sharp bitterness, almost astringent/band-aid.  Lighter to medium bodied with a slick texture.  I took a sip from the can as instructed from the label.  I think I might prefer it that way, in fact.  Its good, but I¬ím not sure if the hype matches the taste.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2012 Can. 16 oz. Split with Thomas. Pours hazy gold with a massive, bubbly white head. Aroma of pure, fresh pineapple, plain and simple; it¬ís something to behold. Tastes like a hopped out pineapple juice. Jesus, the taste is better than almost every other IPA I¬íve ever tried, double or otherwise. The palate is clean, supple, and a bit tangy. Oh, sweet, sweet Jesus, I would drink this beer every single day for the rest of my life if I could. It is, all around, the best IPA out on the market right now. It¬ís better than Sculpin, it¬ís better than Double Jack, it¬ís better than... Well, okay maybe Ruskie River¬ís Pliny series and Blind Pig give it a run for its money, but really we¬íre talking apples and pineapple at this point. Whatever you have to do to get this beer, do it. Get it fresh, there¬ís no reason not to. John and co. keep this beauty churning nonstop. Thanks, Alchemist. I¬íve enjoyed every single glorius can of this beer. Cheers. I mean it.

16oz tallboy can courtesy of BeerPilgrim11, thanks! bright orange pour from the can, foamy head. HUGE citrus nose, grapeftuit standing out.  piney flavor, very bitter but mellowed out by the malt. this is one big bad DIPA! reminded me of something from the fine folks at Surly...

Can from a trade on BA a while back. Glorious bright orange pour with a slight cloudiness at the core and a massive, silky head. First thought on getting a snort of this beauty was "Pliny East?" But there¬ís something about the huge tropical bouquet and balanced bittering notes is quite distinctive. Slight hop oil in the mouthfeel, which is generally full and buoyant in a way that recalls Alpine. Mango and pineapple everywhere, gently undergirded by malts and pine in the finish. Very, very good.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2016 Fresh can compliments of Vince. Pours a cloudy golden orange color, lacing was webbed and thick, medium head. Aromas of pineapple, guava, white oak, tangerine, dank hoppy resins, juicy cantalope as well as other melons. Taste was about the same with so many tropical fruits presents, candy caramel, pineapple juice, peaches. Light to medium body with a salivating mouth. This reminded me of pliny younger meets a fresh dugana. Aftertaste never leaves the mouth. EPIC. This is based off of 30-40 re rates since this beer was good. It its now a gross grape sugar bomb that has way too many hops and nowhere near as good as the old days. Focal is the new topper but even that its too sweet.

can aquired from trade with shcufj (BA). no freshness info.

pours a golden amber into my snifter capped by small head with good retention. Head reduces to a lacing cap. Aroma is of tropical fruit and light caramel. Pineapple upfront on the palate with tangerine, and canned peaches. Caramel provides the backbone. Mouth is light bodied. excellent.
Not my favorite style. I am not a hop head at all but this is glorious. Soo tasty. Tastes like grapefruit juice.
Tap, pours a ready nice foamy head. The taste and smell are both very citrusy. So much life to this one. It really is very tasty stuff. Bitter and smooth all at the same time. Very pleasant

For me, when I¬ím in the mood for an IPA/DIPA, nothing to date tops this. Stone Ruination or IPA is close, but they both have a harshness (ever so slight) not found in this beer. There is a resin note that hints of a Superfund site that is compellingly good. Yum!

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2013 16oz can from Ernesto, pour is a medium orange with a gigantic citrus nose, taste is bitter and straight hops tastes good to me, delicious.

16oz can from AdamJackson, 5 days from the cannery... nose is crazy good. this would be a 4.5 beer for me now, just a little slick on the palate and slow bitterness
Awesome beer !!! Nice citrus pine balance perfect beer has just the right texture.

22oz bomber poured into snifter. Thanks goes to Alex for this one, you be da man. Been looking forward to this tick for a while. 

A - Pours a reddish/copper color, cream-colored head, lots of lacing and a nice cap on top with bubbles here and there. 

S - Tropical fruits, dankness, grapefruit, bitter/hoppy, some pine. Really excellent nose. Anything with tropical notes, I¬ím a huge fan of. This one fit the bill. 

T - Pretty much right on target with the nose (although the nose is better). Lots if pine, hops/bitterness but yet very smooth, slight malty backbone, nice citrus profile, and a bitter finish. 

M - Light, good carbination, crisp, refreshing, piney finish. 

D - Okay, so this beer has been hyped up and down for a long while. East vs. West, this one stands up to the best DIPA¬ís out there. So easy to drink is ridiculous. World-class, as far as I¬ím concerned.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2017 Pours a very hazy, cloudy orange-yellow, with small head. Aroma is very strong of floral and citrus and hops. Flavor dominated by hop-pine-bitterness with a very healthy helping of citrus. One of the best IPAs I¬íve come across. I do believe this is just about my favorite beer of the moment.**Re-Rating: I still love Heady Topper, but I¬íve found some even better beers since (see: most offerings by Tree House and Trillium)**
Pure hoppy goodness. About as good as beer can get. Take their word for it and drink it out of a can. Worth visiting Vermont for.

16 oz. can.  Poured hazy orange with tons of swirling hop particles despite a slow pour.  Nose is of FRESH cut citrus.  Flavor also of FRESH cut citrus, orange, tangerine, grapefruit all present.  Finished bitter, but surprisingly smooth and drinkable despite the claim of 120+ IBUs.  No alcohol noticeable.  Medium bodied.  Phenomenal stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2013 Amazing.  So much aroma from all the beautiful array of hops in this beast of an IPA.  For being high in alcohol content, it was barely detectable, as it went down easy, all 120 IBU¬ís of it.

*I just decided to change the appearance from a 4 to a 5, because this is exactly how a double IPA should look and this beer is perfect.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2014 Un v√©ritable jus de toundra et de fruits exotiques. Tr√®s collant et sucr√©, se boit comme un jus de fruits. Dot√© d¬íune buvabilit√© raisonnable. Amertume aigu et prolong√© en prime.

Can multiple times.  Pours a slightly hazy golden amber with a medium plus sized white head.  The aroma explodes with tropical fruits, mango, citrus, earthy, and dank hops.  If there are malts, they remain well hidden.  The flavor does have some toasted bread that is dominated b the tropical fruits, citrus, earthy and resiny hops.  Good bitterness and mouth feel.  Even with all of the fruitiness, the finish is on the dry side.  This is a treat from start to finish.

Can that was shared. Pours a mostly opaque golden straw color with chunks of yeast. Nose is citrus, mango and sweet malt notes, firrst sip is great with nice hoppy flavors that dominate. just enough finish is nice lingering bitterness. Great beer.

I popped the top and gave it a good sniff, and even though I couldn¬ít quite put my finger on the aroma, it was very nice. I did the "swoosh and spit" taste test and it was very smooth and not what I expected from a beer with an IBU rating of 120. It had an awesome taste that was not overwhelming at all, smooth & robust with a small bite at the end. With an ABV of 8%, it accented the beer extremely well. The color pours of creamy honey and overall, this beer was quite amazing. It¬ís no wonder people will travel far distances for this brew.

Heady Topper pours a hazy orange color.  Barely any head at all is poured.  Minimal lacing.  While this beer doesn¬ít look that exciting the nose on this beer is.  You want a barrage of hops?  Look no further and I really mean it here.  Full on wall of pine with a mixture of grapefruit, mango, citrus which is hard to explain.  Just straight up hoppy while someone being a tad bit balanced with the smallest amount of grainy malt.

See that picture on the can of the hops exploding out of the guys head as he drinks this beer.  Yeah that¬ís basically how I felt.  Possibly out of every beer I¬íve ever had in my life, this might be the one that they somehow pulled out every bit of juice you can probably get from a hop, I think you get what I mean.  It¬ís just pure hop juice.  But not in a bad bitter way.  Yes it has a bit of bitterness to it, but it¬ís wrangled in.  In the taste more of the grapefruit comes through.  Pine comes in next with the other fruits following.  Just pure lovely hop juice.  But with all this talk of hops, it¬ís hard to believe me that this beer still remains kind of balanced somehow and totally 100% fantastic and drinkable.  Small bit of a malt backbone is present.  Just enough.  A small amount of alcohol is there too.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied.  Slightly carbonated.  Medium amount of bitterness.  Not over the top.

"Purchased on 1-6-11 from The Alchemist Cannery in Waterbury, VT
Brewed on 1-3-11
Opened on 1-6 just hours after purchasing. Served at 50 degrees. I did pour a bit into a snifter just to get the appearance and aroma but not much.
A - Light golden color. I¬íd think it was a Budweiser just by the look of things. The pour was more heavy and syrupy than a bud though. No head was produced but this was a very easy and small pour just to get a glance at appearances.
S - Phenomenally sweet scent arose from the snifter before I even got into the glass with my nose. Smells exactly as a Double IPA should smell. I¬ím getting a hint of glue and mollasses in the smell.
T - It¬ís clearly a double IPA but it¬ís also clear this is like no other IPA I¬íve ever had. The taste difference between snifter and can is terrific and beautiful. Sweeter than most DIPAs and not very bitter at all. These guys produced a very tasty beer!!!
M - Very heavy body on the tongue and on my cheeks. A slight tingle as I swallow and super syrupy after taste almost like apple or cherry cough syrup. The mouth feel is solid and very well balanced with the taste.
O - $12 for 4 is a great price but I¬ím sure that price will start getting higher very soon. It¬ís a great beer. Worth of 100 on Beer Advocate? I don¬ít think so. I¬ím not HUGE on IPAs and this may be the best IPA I¬íve ever had but World Class? Meh.
I do sort of regret buying 16 of these things. Oh well. Beer is beer."
(Can)  Pours a golden amber body with a medium white head. Aroma of dank, earth, herbs, pineapple, and citrus.  Flavor of herbs, grass, orange, and pineapple with a dry, bitter finish.
A truly amazing DIPA that I am lucky to have a decent supply of, thanks to a good friend! Simply one of the best beers I¬íve had, and a beautiful representation of the style.

Beer is yellow to amber with some haziness to it. Head is soft, white, and thin made up of a very small bubbles and some medium ones that stick to the glass leaving a little lacing. Carbonation is moderate to low, it looks good, looks like a hazy IPA.

The aroma is beautiful, absolutely wonderful. No alcohol or heat, minimal malt sweetness, complex mixture of tropical fruits like pineapple and mango, with citrus layers of lime and orange. It smells wonderful.

Beer is light in body and quite carbonated in the mouth. Interesting, probably due to the carbonation, the first thing I notice in this beer is the hop profile. A floral and fruity explosion of hop flavors, again tropical fruits and some citrus that gives way in the late palate to some moderate bitterness. I think they could have gotten away with more bitterness but overall it is a truly amazing IPA. Hard to top.
Can 1 pint.  Forte pr√©sence d¬íhoublon aux saveurs d¬íagrumes (pamplemousse, pomelo) et de conif√®re. Se boit incroyablement bien, c¬íest une des bi√®res que j¬íaimerais toujours avoir en r√©serve.

From a 500ml can... Pours a hazy golden with a big white head that leaves ridiculous lacing... Huge mango grapefruit light pine aroma lightest sweetness... Lively medium body, kinda lightly sweet, big big stone fruit and light citrus flavor with a touch of pine, could be a little livelier ... Nice flavor , lightest creaminess to the body, quite dry finish bitterness hits the tongue pretty hard... Really really worth the hype...

Can from tilson!  Pours a hazy honey color with a huge tan head...outstanding heavy lacing and retention.  Aroma is packed with citrusy grapefruit, some mango, and perfect amounts of grassy and spicy hops...wow.  flavor has stone fruits...peach and mango...followed by spicy grapefruit and grassiness...just enough malt to provide a hint of a biscuity backing to go with some sticky sweetness.  Mouthfeel is medium and oily and the finish is wonderfully hoppy with grapefruit and dry.  Damn near perfection...move over pliny!

Can @ Jews brews bbqs. Hazy dark yellow ochre. Heady hop aroma is full of dense chewiness, pine, swamp, and orange peel. Shit this is a total hop bomb, and yet the nutty malt sweetness is solid and characterful enough. So while it¬ís very bitter it also has depth. Tastes and feels very strong. A good way to get hit over the head with hops. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

in the glass is looks like a heffe with a big rocky ledge on top.  I¬íd like to see the expression on one expecting a wheat beer. How they can pack so much pine and citrus into the nose? There is some sweet amphora like tobacco in the nose as well.  Taste is all about the hops, enough malt to hold things up but not get in the way.  This is the single best iipa I have ever had.  Very dry and lingering hop presence which loves you all night.

I tip my hat to Jim at homebrew club for bringing this beer I thought I¬íd never be able to try. 
Pours a very hazy golden color with a lot of floaties, the head is medium sized, well retained, and leaves a little bit of lace on the glass. 

The aroma is a good balance of fruity and pleasantly oniony hops. The beer is very pungent, very bright, and is loaded with fresh hop character. Somehow a little bit of crackery malt peeks through the big hop burst. 

The beer is indeed bitter but not overbearingly so, the beer has a nice multi-layered snappy hoppiness, a little onion, a good dose of juicy grapefruit, a zippy spiciness. The beer is very well balanced even though it¬ís so hop heavy, and the alcohol is basically unnoticeable.
This seems like the sort of beer I could drink a fair amount of.

Really solid offering that pours a murky honey hue with burnt tangerine at its core.  Fluffy, bright-white head that left a small ring and a little lacing.  Aroma is juicy citrus, candied orange, and lemon-zest.  Flavor shows a little alcohol accompanied by earthy notes, freshly-cut grass, and grapefruit rind.  Citrus sprays the palate like gnawing on tangelos.  Again, a bit hotter than the 8% would indicate.  Not as "bright" as a West Coast IIPA but nicely balanced.

16 ounce bottle

A mysterious can from a unknown brewery with an eyecatching label sat in the fridge for only about a week before I couldn¬ít take it any more. Cracking it open I had one of the best canned beers in a long time. I can only imagine how much better it is fresh from the source. This one should be high on anybody¬ís list who is in the Vermont region.

Aroma / Appearance - A bronze body shimmers with light carbonation. Golden rings curl around the edges like the tint of a warm sunset. Lemongrass, lawn clippings, and pine sol provide immediate evidence that this means business. Resiny holds it together like a pot of glue. 

Flavor / Palate - Sourdough soaked in resin warms the palate almost immediately after the first sip. Refreshing and gentle it eases towards the throat. A great example of the imperial IPA style this is the type of introduction that I wish happened more often with new breweries. Alchemist is definitely a must stop if I ever make it to Vermont.

Thanks to Don for this.  Pours a dark brownish gold with a nice white foam head and great lacing and some sediment in the glass.  Aroma is a pine forest!  Intense pine hops with a stickly sweetness.  Taste is dry, pine hop but is well balanced with malt.  Resinous and syrupy this is a monster of a DIPA.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2013 Finally gave in and bought me a 4 pack on ebay. A: Pours hazy orange maybe copper with a thin white head. S: Guava, papaya, mango, pineapple and some syrup malt. T: Very easy to drink dipa, with grapefruit, papaya, guava and some pine. There is also a honey malt presence but doesnt take away from the hops. Finishes sticky with some bitterness. M: Creamy with lively carbonation, lots of bitterness but as it warms up it taste more sweet. O: A great beer but thats really it, not mind blowing.
poured out of a pint can, copper color with a light white head.  Epic aroma of peaches, great hop flavor.  Tasted just like eating a nugget hop pellet.  Great Beer.

Big boy can poured into glass. Finally got my chance to try this whale and man did it live up to the hype. Great aroma and flavor. Easy to drink. Wish I had more then a 4 pack. Don¬ít want to say it¬ís the "best" DIPA but it¬ís damn close

For some reason unbeknownst to me, certain random beers manage to generate a huge buzz and become the hot beer of the moment. As of this writing, Heady Topper - a double IPA by the Alchemist Pub & Brewery out of Waterbury, Vermont - is the MUST HAVE beer. Those lucky enough to acquire it say it¬ís the East Coast equivalent of Pliny The Elder, or the best IPA they¬íve ever had, or the best beer they¬íve ever had (or all three). A friend of mine actually made the 3-hour drive to pick up a case and gave me a can or two. Only a few sips in I understood why beer nerds are going crazy for it.

Despite the warning (or plea) "Drink From The Can!" I poured a 16oz can into a tulip glass.

Appearance: Orange to dark orange color; extremely cloudy but translucent. Forms a large, yellow, frothy head which retains and laces very well.

Smell: Massive tropical fruit juice aroma with distinct sweetness to the nose. Dank piney resin is also quite prominent.

Taste: The thing about India Pale Ales is that they don¬ít tend to be very complex - just very hoppy and that¬ís about it. But Heady Topper proves you can have genuine complexity even while being a hop monster. As soon as the beer hits the tongue I get intense bitterness - it¬ís slightly dry, but it¬ís impossible to ignore. It¬ís a massive hop bite that wakes your mouth up. It¬ís immediately quenched by a delicious palate of tropical fruit juices. Grapefruit, passion fruit, guava, mango and orange are all individually detectable and make for a very refreshing taste, ironically enough. 

The second half changes on a dime to something much more dank. Intense resin and pine sap emerge to give the palate a whole new type of bitterness. Supposedly the beer is over 120 IBUs and between the sharp tartness of the citrus flavors and the almost burnt rubber-like astringency of the resin I can definitely see that. The aftertaste is slightly sticky - an odd combination of bitter hops and fruit nectar. It never stops being delectable, though.

Mouthfeel: Slightly creamy texture, but otherwise soft and comfortable with noticeable carbonation and a full-bodied palate.

Drinkability: Alchemist Heady Topper is not a difficult beer to drink - it goes down very smooth with a noticeable, but tolerable dry hoppy aftertaste. The 8% ABV is the perfect mass for this beer: heftier than your average IPA, but nothing that only heavyweight drinkers can handle. A great beer to have with a meal or extra sharp cheese, although I think drinking it on its own is much more satisfying so that you can experience and appreciate all the flavor without any distraction.
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2012 CAN at Darkness Day 10/22/2011. Orange pour with notes of pine and citrus. Bitter.
can thanks to bhollas.  murky deep gold color with a light cream head.  nose is tropical fruits, pineapple, resin, dank.  excellent thickness, pine resin, fruits, wet, dank hops.  wow

Can big thanks to mcox90, thanks so much! Pours orange and hazy. Nose is big resinous pines, oranges, grapefruit sweet malts, grasses, and some sweet estery fruits. Flavor is oranges, oily dank hops and sticky malts. Palate is smooth and rich. Dry bitter finish. this is one of the best!

16 oz can - I got this brew in Burlington awhile after the sad news that the Alchemist had been wiped out by flooding. However their recently built cannery survived.  The bar I visited was excited to have just gotten in this beer and the locals were quickly buying them out. Anyway, this brew has a big, piney hop aroma. It has good balance if we can say that about an IIPA. Sure it¬ís very bitter but there¬ís plenty of malt body there too. Citrus and pine notes add to a very pleasing beer experience.

From the Brewery from the tap and can: Pours a hazy orange color with a nice white head. Aroma is a veritable explosion of hops: you get the citrus, the pine, and the flowers all together. Taste is wonderful. Bitterness is present, but it pales in comparison to the aroma. Basically, you get a huge variety of hops and hop flavours. A little bit sweet, but the maltiness is really held in check as compared to other DIPAs. In fact, it would be hard to tell that this is DIPA were it not for the huge amount of flavor. Great aftertaste that lingers and invites additional sips (unlike some hoppy beers that do the very opposite). Body is excellent. Drinkable, sippable, and delicious. Yes. Amongst the best hoppy beers I¬íve ever had.

Can received from Doodler.  Pours hazy and particulate amber with a large, frothy off-white head, medium-long retention with good lacing.  Aroma is biscuit and cereal malt, fragrant floral and citrus hops, and moderate fruity esters.  Flavor is heavy hops, moderate bitterness, sweetened fruity esters, supporting malt backbone, and a dry finish.  Medium body, warmth, and carbonation.

16oz. can, purchased from the new brewery/cannery.  WARNING: Pour with caution!  I did not, the first go-around, and my word, what a chunky beer experience it was.  Downright unnerving, it was.  I haven¬ít seen that much sediment and suspended stuff since my last bottle of Abbaye des Rocs.  My advice is to pour slowly and plan on leaving the last half-ounce or so in the can.  
Aroma is fruity, lightly sweet, then HOPS HOPS HOPS, with massive amounts of citrus, resin, florals, pine, a lighter green vegetative note (scallion?), and some lightly toasted caramel malts in the background.  The nose just has more hops than almost anything I¬íve encountered before.  Hazy light-medium amber color, head is off-white, foamy and lasting.  Flavor profile is skewed towards the hoppy side to an insane degree, this is just rife with sweet citrus, tropical fruit, pine, spice and huge bitterness, fresh and not overly drying or astringent in any way; the sweet, toasty malty backbone is blended in rather nicely and smoothly, particularly about midpoint, since the finish is all about the hops once again, just lip-smackingly resinous.  Palate is active, oily and gently effervescent, body is medium-full.  Shockingly easy to drink and hugely flavorful, this is a hophead¬ís dream.  
Side note, something I find amusing: The label attempts to convince you in various ways to drink from the can, but then on the label art, the guy is drinking from a glass.  I did decant this, by the way, I just don¬ít drink good beer out of a can.  Not my style.

Can courtesy of GandGKevin. Murky amber with a pretty, layered white head. Aroma is big grapefruit and big pine atop chewy malt and a nice caramel backbone. Taste is a hop bomb. Big pine resins, floral hops, citrus oils and grapefruit pulp. More chewy malts and caramel in this as well. Body is medium-full with a creamy carbonation. Finishes with more big hop resins, grapefruit, pine, citrus oils, caramel and chewy malt.

Sampled at a recent RB St. Louis gathering - Pours lightly hazy amber / orange with an off-white head.  The aroma is a thing of beauty.  Tons of hoppiness with notes of orange, funk and green onion standing out.  There is also some caramel malt there for a nice balance.  Medium crisp body with semi-sharp carbonation.  The flavor starts out with funky, piny and grapefruit hop notes and smooth semi-sweet caramel malt for a spot on balance for the assertive hops.  The finish dries out a lot and the hops get more harsh showing earthiness, pine, grapefruit and it is all quite resiny.  Really well made IIPA.

Thanks to Ernesto987 who sent this for SS.
Can.
Pours hazy dark yellow with lots of floaties under a sticky, 3-dimesnsional head of off-white.
Grapefruit hop aroma.
The flavor is pure citrus hops.  Hop-Juice, but very well done hop juice. Enough subtle underlying malt sweetness to carry the hop flavors.
I like this one.

Huge thanks to mar for trading me this can.

The beer pours a dirty yellow color with a white head. The aroma is very heavy on the grapefruit, but I also get a little bit of orange citrus and some biscuit malt notes. 

The flavor is more intense than the aroma. I get some huge grapefruit and orange citrus notes, as well as a little bit of pine and some pineapple. Mixed in with all of the hop notes is a little bit of biscuit malt. The bitterness is low to medium.

Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

Can shared by phaleslu, thanks Peter!  Pour is an unassuming hazy gold with a nice medium snow-white head.  Aroma is out-of-control good.  Loads of crazy huge citrus hop with pineapple and orange notes.  A very understated, but present, lightly sweet malt also detectable.  Flavor is huge citrus hops also with pineapple and grapefruit dominating.  Very very well balanced with the lightly sweet malt balancing out the spice of the hops. This beer is huge on aroma and hops but so well balanced as well. Wow, this is exactly how I like IPA¬ís  This is an incredible IPA! I could drink this everyday, all day.

Can from Shanell - thanks!  Enjoyed via glass and can.  Pours a clear, caramel/amber with a thick and healthy froth of white foam.  Aroma is clean pine, hop bitterness, floral hops, citrus but it¬ís integrated with the malt backbone more than a stand alone element, perhaps some tropical fruit notes, and a very dry and tight malt backbone.  The aroma is a bit more intense from the can than the glass.  Taste is balanced hop bitternes, pine, and a slight bit of malt sweetness and alcohol toward the finish.  Very clean feel in the mouth.  I particularly like that the beer comes in at 8% which allows the hops to shine more, the malt to play a background role, and make the beer all around more drinkable than if it were a higher ABV.  Solid, extremely drinkable IIPA that is worth seeking out.

Appearance: Pours a dull hazy amber gold. Holding it up to the light you will see particulate matter suspended throughout. Atop sits a thin swirly white film.

Aroma: Grapefruit pine ,tropical fruit It¬ís pine dominant.

Taste: Bitter bouquet of piny citrusy hop flavor. Slight toffee and spicy malt. A little fruity with a sturdy bitter finish.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied. Very carbonated.

Overall:  I love this beer.  I tried drinking it from the can, as The Alchemist suggests, but it¬ís just not good for business. While very cloudy, with particulate matter floating around, you get to know the beer way better from different temperatures not to mention it¬ís no fun trying to stick your beak inside of an aluminum can.  As many a fat girl or ugly guy has said ¬ìit¬ís what¬ís on the inside that counts.¬î In the case of Heady Topper, the inside is amazing.

Poured into a snifter despite the can¬ís instructions. I love the "Don¬ít be a D-bag, recycle this can!" on the back.

3.5 A: Lightly hazed dark orange color. Small particulates throughout. Two and a half fingers of white frothy/creamy hybrid head. Retention is good and some lacing is left.

4.5 S: Nice nose on this. Incredibly floral with orange and mango citrus. Can¬ít really pick up in terms of malts other than a light neutral sweetness and a touch of breadiness.

4.0 T: Surprisingly sweet and bitter at the same time. Pithy grapefruit with orange, papaya, and mango citrus. Malts and yeast give a hearty dose of breadiness and graham cracker.

4.0 M: Medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Reasonably creamy with a light bitter aftertaste.

4.0 D: Solid brew, though I¬ím not huge on bready DIPAs. Still, I¬íd have no problem putting down a few of these.

Serving type: can

Reviewed on: 10-20-2011 23:01:01

Two 16-ounce cans were sent last week by lushawn to be opened at the STL RB Gathering he couldn¬ít attend, and we did just that, one for the guests who had to leave early, and one for the night owls. Some of us hit it twice. Thanks, Shawn! Pours a semi-cloudy yellow gold color with a small white head. The aroma absolutely explodes out of the can upon the first snap. Massive fresh herbal, citrusy hops, tropical fruits, earth, pepper, sweet and caramel malts, and floral notes. Holy moly. The flavor is outstanding, too, but nothing could follow that nose. Oily, citrusy, floral hops, sweet and caramel malt backbone throughout, tropical fruits, and pine resin. Medium-bodied, with a smooth mouthfeel that is juicy, oily, and malty all at once in incredible balance. I finished my rating in my notepad with "wow, wow, wow" and I¬ím sticking with that. I didn¬ít buy the hype leading up to this one but now I¬ím right at the forefront of it. This beer is amazing. Wow, wow, wow.

Fresh can provided by jedwards - best bonus ever. Enjoyed in my Hill Farmstead stem glass. The pour yields a very hop hazy amber with half a finger of white head, dissipating rather fast.
