The aroma is intensely piney, and very simcoe forward. Also oranges, passion fruit, rather resinous. Notes of green apples a very fresh and zesty citrus component. A very crisp malt profile with crispy bread crust and a hint of caramel and honey. Lovely! The taste also plays on the piney and resinous side of the hop spectrum, but also has a very fresh passion fruit and unripe pineapple fruitiness up front. The bitterness is insisting and almost stinging, but is backed up by some sweetness on the malty side - bread crust and caramel. The malts seem to provide just the right balance to allow the hops to still play the big part. As you drink it, the hops just open up with new fruity impression by every sip - first you get all kinds of citrus fruits - the other sip it¬ís pineapple, passion fruit and oranges - the next sip it¬ís intensely piney and resinous. Outstanding! The palate ends with a lovely and very unique citrus tart-ish bitterness that I haven¬ít picked up in any DIPA before. The hop profile is very impressive and actually very complex, but the malt profile as well, is right where it should be, all together it adds up to one of the finiest DIPA¬ís I¬íve had thus far. Jumpin¬í  on the hype train on this one.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2014 Sampled from a can (that¬ís right) at the Saint Louis Ratebeer Gathering in a tulip glass. Appearance and grainbill were typical of Imperial IPAs, but it¬ís the crazy cool aromas and flavors that set this beer apart. Massive herbal, spicy, grassy, perfumey, earthy, woodsy, citrusy (and not just grapefruit, mind you) hops that reveal themselves layer after endless layer. What did Vermont residents do to deserve this and Magic Hat and Hill Farmstead? Not fair!

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  It poured a hazy amber color with a big white head. The aroma was of citrus and grapefruit hops.  The taste was citrus hops with a nice malt balance and a nice bitter hop finish.  A very good IPA.

Sampled at the st. Louis ratebeer gathering.  This is hazy golden.  Little head.  A sweet hop nose but the flavor is big and bitter.  Lots of citrus.  Some bread and caramel.  The bitterness smoothed out and nuances came through.  Good!

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2011 Super fresh 16 oz. can.  Poured into my glass, it yields a cloudy, stratified, dusky burnt amber to light sienna body with a beautifully thick, spongy head of lasting cream colored froth.  Hard, dense, patchy swaths of lacing coat the glass from top to bottom.  Good looking brew here.  The nose is dank, dank, DANK.  Simcoe was clearly used generously.  I get notes of cannabis, wet grass, and hay, with a secondary wave of pithy, peppery white grapefruit and maybe some distant pine resin.  Though it is clearly a hop bomb, there is a really nice underlying honeyed, bready malt character that lends a chewy balance to the aroma.  It somehow manages to avoid the savory, meaty notes and cat pee essence that some Simcoe-based IPAs inherently contain (*cough*cough* GUBNA *cough*cough).  The taste is very hop-centric, showing more resin than before, cannabis kind of fading away.  I get more bitter citrus pith and grass, followed by notes of oily, fruity citrus peel and sticky pine resin.  The malt character is pretty much the perfect counterpoint, formidable enough to slightly damper the onslaught of hop bitterness, yet not so overbearing as to take over or lend excessive sweetness.  In fact, the malts are downright tasty in their own right, touching on baking bread and honey-kissed toast.  Yummy, yummy brew.  The palate is medium-full in stature, super-smooth up front, with what seems like the perfect amount of soft yet persistent carbonation.  Alcoholic warmth is almost nil, which is a feat for an 8% brew, yet it does finish excessively sugary and sticky.  Hell, my lips were nearly glued together after drinking this can!  On the whole, you can color me impressed.  I generally hate Simcoe hops, and the hype train really had my guard up, but this brew is different.  They somehow captured that sweet spot between malt and hop that so few IIPAs do, and it shows off the very best characteristics of Simcoe without any of the typical off scents or flavors.  Damn fine beer.  This is what GUBNA wishes it was.

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured clear copper color with an average frothy white head that lasted with excellent lacing. Moderate to heavyrthy hoppy aroma. Moderate to heavy bitter flavor with a moderate to heavy bitter finish of moderate to long duration. Medium to full body with a slick texture and soft carbonation. Moderate alcohol bite at the finish. Very good brew.

Finally get to try this, even got the first pour .. . Pours a deep yellow gold .. great foam, medium sticky lacing .. . lots of pine, sap, flowers, and hop syrup .. . great pure hop mouth, not to sweet- just perfect .. . A hell of an IIPA, very happy i got to try it and see now why people talk about it. .. . no dogs allowed!

The Can. Hell Yeah (thanks jeff) - "Drink From the Can", Fine! I poured a bit into a taster to get the color and appearance, though.  Which is , frankly, a fairly clear honey gold with an average off white head, I suppose. Back to the can. The nose is tangerine, caramel, honey, and grassy hops, really. The citrus notes though are pretty fantastic. I suppose out of the gate; I¬ím surprised at the bitterness level in this beer - 120 IBU¬ís - well. When I say surprised, I mean I¬ím not necessarily pulling an extreme bitterness from this beer. The sweetness from the caramel/honey notes mesh wonderfully with the tangerine/apricot citrus notes, fused with the grassy/piney hop profile. But this feels odd, drinking from the can. The mouthfeel is thick and chunky, relative to the swigs I¬ím taking. And to be honest, there is a hint of metallics present here. But who am I to argue with the alchemist?

Huge thanks to mkabull and AutumnBeerLove for sending me fresh cans(on the same day)! 

Pours a hazy golden orange with tangerine hues and a 1.5 finger white foam head that slowly settles into a lasting ring. 

Dank, uber-fresh hop aroma with lots of resinous hop oils and grassy pine along with a ton of citrus and tropical fruit character. Spicy with hints of pine needle, orange peel, grapefruit, mango and pineapple as well as a subtle biscuity malt presence. 

Chewy fully body with a blast on dry, oily hops that linger over the sweeter fruit notes and subtle malt backbone into a nice dry finish. The hop profile is pretty complex with dry, earthy pine needle flavor countered by sweet citrus and tropical fruit notes. Hints of papaya, mango, pineapple, grapefruit and orange peel give this beer some nice sweetness and great balance without overpowering the bitterness. In fact, these two flavors continuously bounce off of each other back and forth throughout. In addition, there is a faint malt presence which gives the beer a good backbone, again without taking anything away from the hops. Toward the finish there is slight boozy heat but overall the ABV is very well masked and this beer is dangerously quaffable. 

This beer is legit, living up to the hype I wish that I had easier access so I could add it to my regular rotation.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2013 fresh can.    pours a hazy orange amber with a small offwhite head. when cold and fresh,  aroma of big juicy tropical fruits, pungent grapefruit bitterness, touch of sweet candied apple, caramel, and melons.   some light booze as well, that becomes more apparent as it warms.   would have preferred a 6 percent version of this, as the booze is a tad distracting, but could be enjoyable if in the mood for that sort of thang.  defintiely hoppy, red grapefruit and tangerines shine.  a touch resiny.  enough bitterness to balance.  too much boost offered.  Lot of can to can variation as well.   Some with more doughy melon drank than others.

Drank this from the can, as intended, so the raing for appearance is kind of on faith. The aroma on this is so deep and hoppy, it¬ís just a shame you can¬ít stick your whole nose in. Taste is a touch too bitter, but still solid. Overall, a very strong IPA.
16oz can shared by jsprime with me and joe. hazy light orange with a white head. hugehop nose. lean malt body and a massive amount of hop flavour. stunningly good IIPA.

16oz can.  This is a pretty badass DIPA.  Thick light honey colored pour with not much head.  Nose of a ton of hops but actually some malty, and fruity notes.  Taste is great with a real hop train ride.  Bitter upfront, a different kind of bitter in the middle and great back end bitterness. Each taste can be enjoyed for 15-20 seconds.  I¬ím not a big hop guy so the reported 120 ibus I figured would just suck but certainly not the case.

Can shared by Paul at tasting at my house. Pours cloudy apricot with off white head. Nose/taste of mango, citrus, hops, tropical fruits and freshly cut grass. Tons of mango and tropical fruit in the nose. Finishes slightly dry. Bottle on the lighter side. Overall, this one definitely lives up to the hype.

All I can say is WOW and from a can. This is how you brew a double IPA ..Very drinkable and a mixture of hops that blend together for a pleasurable you just right level of Hoppiness. Pours a proper golden wheat hue , cloudy yes I poured it into a glass! And from the very first sip i was convinced this was one of the better double IPA¬ís i¬íve ever had the pleasure of tasting. If you¬íre looking for THE best brew from Vermont look no further than a fresh can of this beer. Highly recommend and without a doubt a beer that puts CRAFT into the term CRAFT BEER! Hat¬ís off to the Alchemist...

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2013 Pours a hazy golden with a small, white head.  The nose on this beer is fantastic.  Waves of cat piss and pine and even an odd marijuana scent.  Flavor is also very good.  Primarily piny with some lemon.  It¬ís a really great beer.  I¬ím drinking this next to one of my favorite IIPAs, Founder¬ís Double Trouble, and I¬ím fairly confident I prefer the Heady Topper.  Great beer.

Can. Oh my good lord this is an awesome beer. Pours orange with a white head. Big and bright piney and citrus aroma, with tropical fruits and spicy hoppy notes. The flavor has just incredibly fresh and full of flavorful hoppy goodness, with pine, tropical fruits, flowers, and citrus. This beer is like Christmas. Very well balanced, with some lightly sweet malts backing the big hop profile. An easy top 10 beer in my book.
Pounder can.  Can¬ít believe how strong this one is.  Very refreshing and smooth.  Citrusy and well made.

Tasted on 11/11/11 from a can shared by ryan585, thanks Ryan.  Pours murky orange with a very thin white head that leaves a thin collar of lace, with some chunky sediment.  The nose is intense orange peel citrus, resin bitterness, chewable kids vitamins, caramel malt, and a touch of earthy yeast.  The flavor is orange and grapefruit peel, bitter resin, chewable kids vitamins, the same earthy yeast, and just enough caramel malt to keep everything in balance.  The body is medium with an oily texture, lighter than average carbonation, and a very long resin and citrus peel bitter finish.

Can. Foamy white head with good retention on a murky amber orange brown. Very resinous and grassy hop aromas that dominate, with some slight malty sweetness.  Herbs, garlic, resin, grass, and a slight bit of fruit tinge...hugely bitter.  Medium body with softer carbonation. Whoa, resin bomb.  Nice

Can from Dr Greg - grazie amigo! Shared with buds. Poured a cloudy orange with a decent white head  Nose is lemon / grapefruit citrusy and huge on the hops. Taste is slippery sweet and well integrated among the hop resins and citrus / fruit flavors. Finished off with a nice bitterness and soft bite. The lasting finish is well balanced. Loved this one.

Aroma:Sweet orange and grapefruit, peaches, cotton candy. Smells delightful.

Appearance:I¬ím drinking it from the can, so it looks great.

Taste:The foretaste is nicely hoppy with grapefruit, and peaches. It¬ís pretty sweet, which holds up well to the hoppyness. The fruit and hop flavors fade slowly, until there is a nice nuttyness in the aftertaste.

Palate:Medium body, good carbonation. Feels a little sticky as I drink it.

Overall:This is one of the best DIPAs that I have had. It has a great complexity of delicious flavors.

Aroma: Earthy, grassy aromas with hints of grapefruit and orange. Very little malt in the smell, other than a light sweetness.
Appearance: A fairly clear yellow-orange, with a thin white head. Yeasty flecks fly around the place.
Taste: Citrusy hops with a big blast of bitterness reminiscent of grapefruit rind. The malt backbone isn¬ít anything unique, but it is a solid pale malt flavor. Holy crap though, this grapefruit is just blowing my top off.
Palate: Medium body and carbonation, and it really coats the mouth. There is a slight boozy feeling on the tongue, but it isn¬ít present in the taste.
Overall: I like this beer. I¬íll probably have to buy some more. It¬ís hugely hoppy, a little funky, and definitely powerful. I can understand the hype.

Can, thanks to gn0sis! Tried both straight from the can as recommended and poured in to a glass, can¬ít say either way was better. Pours hazy orange with some hop residue, dirty off-white head. 
Hugh piney aroma, citrus, peaches, bit of caramel and cookies in the background. Balanced taste, pine, resin, citrus, peach, mango. Really smooth, medium bitterness, long, rich finish. Ends with just a tad of alcohol, nothing disturbing though. A great beer. I would drink a ton of this if it was availible here. Possibly the best canned beer I¬íve had.

Ar- Aromatically this is a very pleasing beer. A citrus and tropical fruit explosion. Lots of grapefruit, bitter orange and zest, loads of pineapple, mango bit of pepperyness finally yielding to pine cones. 

Ap- Dam this beer is ugly! The  body is amber and has a hell of a lot of particles. Think pulpy orange juice. The head is white and has a bit of staying power. Perhaps my mustache killed it?

T- The flavor is a nearly perfect delivery of the aroma. A flash of sweetness goes down into a satisfying bitterness.

P- Medium bodied well carbonated. Nice refreshing bitter finish. Well done.

O- This is truly a fantastic beer. It looks terrible in my glass but dam does it smell and taste great. A very fine refreshing beer.

16oz can from Blind Tiger w Andy, James, Streets. Pours a light caramel color with little to medium head (white). Intensely piney aroma - like a Christmas tree. So great. Burnt yule log and holiday. Palate is light pine hops and a perfect blend of citrus and bitterness. Hop-forward but not in-your-face. It¬ís like your tongue is being massaged with beer.

Thanks to Deuane for giving me one of his cans so I can finally taste the heady. Can poured into a standard pint.
A - Pours slightly hazed amber orange with a small half finger tall white head leaving small wisps of lace down the glass. It does have a little sediment floating around in there.
S - Smells of pungent grassy hops, rich tropical fruits; mostly mango and grapefruit; and some lightly toasted caramel malt. Still quite floral.
T - The taste is fairly similar to the nose. It starts off with a big dose of grassy hops quickly giving way to a mix of tropical fruits and sweet caramel malts. Fairly tropical flavor that is very easy to drink. The finish is a mix of light dryness and hop bitterness, lingering on the pallet for a short period of time.
M - Medium body and flavor with moderately low carbonation. Smooth, hoopy, feel with plenty of hop bitterness lingering through the finish.
O - Very nice IPA. I had no problem finishing my glass and I was left wanting more. The balance of juicy fruit and grassy hops to the slightly sweet malt is very nice. I hope to try this one on-tap some day soon.

UPDATED: JUL 19, 2016 Can with Andrew at blind tiger for the support alchemist event. God damn this beer makes me miss alchemist. Went to the brewpub two years back and it was a great experience.  Pours a rich, hazy amber orange pulpy body with thin off white lacing.  Aroma is super fresh pine, citrus pulp and grass hops. Mouthfeel is perfect with notes of fresh citrus, pine and grass. Wonderfully intense flavors of passionfruit and mango followed by a light citrus bitterness. Thank Christ this comes in 1pint cans, because 12 oz is simply not enough. Amazing and truly one of the greatest IPAs ever brewed.
16oz can.  Rich grapefruit tangerine and flavor.  Ultra fresh and tangy ipa.. Happy to have the opportunity to try another alchemist since being at the brewery in late 2009.

Canned sample via Fred82. Pale orange in colour with medium carbonation. Aroma is of mild green onion, tropical and sweet citrus fruits, and cut grass. More sweet citrus and cut grass in the mouth too, along with a solid pale malt presence. Solid bitterness. Sweet without being malty or cloying. A west coast hop profile with a mid-west malt bill (from an east coast brewery). Tasty stuff.

16 oz can; 1/2 from the can and 1/2 from a small snifter; despite the heady silver can, I¬íll give appearance edge to the glass; dense orange and mostly clear with a suspended haze; thick, eggy white head oozing with orange, mango, pine and white sugar mix; strong, sweet and a dose of booze; surprisingly light mouthfeel that is creamy and smooth without defaulting to over aggressive resins or bitterness; deceptive at 8% IMO; texture a little better from the can, but I¬ím getting buzzed so who knows; yummy, sweet and with a killer nose; this one is heady like that tweezer from 1994; yea, you know the one! heady grilled cheese for all :)

[Can]
Complex hops aroma. Good mix of citrus and pine and something sweet--caramel. Hazy very dark yellow under a lasting white cover. Salty hops up front that are loaded with hops--pine and bitter Orange peel along with nice caramel, maybe even some dactyl. Medium body, medium carbonation, tingly sweet bitter finish.

Can shared by inspectorBob at BA gathering. Pours out a cloudy orange color with a very small white head. Aroma is citrus hops, tropical fruits, some nice light malts and a touch of alcohol. Taste is juicy, citrusy hops, tropical fruit, resin, light malty balance with a nice bitter finish...with a slight touch of alcohol. Really tasty.

Pour is hazy orange with white head big thanks to Scott, aroma has notes of big fruity orange, lemon and grapefruit, some nice toffee, caramel, biscuit notes as well, really nice and balanced.  Taste is really nice and balanced with notes of toffee, biscuit, some nice fruity orange and grapefruit, hints of lemon in there as well, finishes very well balanced and nicely bitter.  Very, very nice stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2012 Can @ Dan¬ís house, courtesy of doodler. Huge thanks! Cloudy, yellow orange appearance with an orange tinged off white head. Slightly resiny, piney, organic hoppy, citrusy aroma. Very nice, piney, somewhat resiny, hoppy, tasty citrusy flavor. Awesome! Update: This is my third time drinking this beer (courtesy of Glouglouburp. Thanks Dany!) It has an even more intense piney, resiny aroma with a slightly dull citrus element than I remember. Huge fucking resiny, grapefruity, sticky hoppy flavor. Sure this fucker is a little over the top, but it¬ís fun. My next trip to Vermont I will be getting blasted on this shit. Another update: This one comes from nightrider, a friendly trader in California that has gotten me my freshest can yet! This can has traveled 5,000 miles and it¬ís the freshest one I¬íve had, go figure.Super resiny, piney, grapefruity hoppy aroma. More potent that I remember. Soft mouth feel. Very sappy, resiny, richly piney, grapefruit citrusy, floral hoppy flavor. Very fresh hops. Nice as always.

I want to dedicate my 1000th rating to the The Alchemist Pub & Brewery ,which most of you know by now, was destroyed in the floods caused by Hurricane Irene. Godspeed in their rebuilding efforts. Fortunately the brand new cannery was not affected. So here we go. 16 oz can, purchased at the cannery and poured into a snifter.  Pours a hazy orange with a 2 finger fluffy white head. Head recedes leaving rings of thick lacing. HUGE citrus hop aroma. I mean it smacks you in the face the second you pop the can. Some secondary malt aroma too. Flavor, as you would expect is dominated by bitter citrus hops. Lush fruity flavors back up the bitterness. Some minor malty bread notes too. A little bit boozy. Full bodied palate with average, at best, carbonation.Needless to say, a bitter finish. A must have if you find youself anywhere near Waterbury Vt.

Can. Poured a slightly hazy yellowish-orange color. The head was a few fingers high and off white. Caramel, cotton candy, pine, apricot, and grapefruit in the nose. Medium bodied and delicately sweet with mild to moderate bitterness. Grapefruit and pine dominated the flavor, but there was also a bit of caramel.
wow what a great beer loved the hop residue floating in the beer. very clean and crisp. nice grapefruit hoppy flavor.

Intensiv fruchtiger und grasiger Geruch. Im Antrunk findet sich das wenig bittere und dumpf grasige wieder, s√º√ülich. Vollmundig hopfig, √§u√üerst gelungen. Bitter-lemon, im Abgang vielleicht etwas zu s√º√ü. Dann auch in Teilen klebrig. 12/12/12/11/9/12

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2013 Date: October 22, 2011 Mode: Bottle Source: Darkness Day. Full description not available as I sampled way too many beers during Darkness Day!

Had again at Bryce¬ís on June 23, 2013. Nicely balanced piney and grapefruit bitterness. No change to ratings.

Can, shared by Sander & Rick of the Beer Temple, cheers guys. Hazy golden yellow color, white head. Strong aroma¬ís of hops, resin, a bit grainy and a hint of malty sweetness. Flavor is bitter with some sweetness and slight acidity. Medium body. Long bitter finish. Good.

Hazy burnt orange pour, white head.  The aroma you can smell from 5 feet away! Tons of grapefuit peel, some sticky caramel, light grassy notes.  Flavor is loaded with citrus peel, grass, citrus, caramel, and goddamn this shit is badass. Thanks gn0sis!

16 oz can courtesy of Kan. Thanks, buddy! Taken home and enjoyed on a nice Thursday evening. Pours a golwing dulled golden orange hue, a healthy haze throughout with a decent sized frothy whitish head that dies to a decent layer, laces ok. Aromas are a vibrant in-your-face hopping of lemon and grapefruit bombarding the senses. Florals, grass, oranges, tropical fruit. A melange moving into some touches of pale malts, but this ends abruptly, with an assault of hops on the nose. Grapefruit bomb, essentially, with a lot of supporting flavors. Initial is lighter end of medium bodied offering a powerful hop feel up front. Lots of grapefruit and lemon meet florals and grass, a strong bitterness rolls into a middle that gets a bit sweeter. Touches of gumball, tropical fruit, and some cotton candy. Pale malts, moving back into fruit. Finish is a moderate bitterness, preaching some good citrus and florals, earthy hops. Overall aroma is knock you down, finish is solid, middle shows a bit of sweetness. If this could dry up more overall, it would be a world beater. Farther in, as the palate adjusts to that sweetness, it does really move towards the front of the pack, remaining a grapefruit bomb with lots of hop flavor. Could use a touch more bitterness for me, but it¬ís very well done, perhaps a touch sweet, but the insane amount of hops and flavor from them really sets the pace. Quality.

Can shared during the 2011 BA South Jersey gathering. Poured a hazy orange body with a smaller bubbly off white head. Aroma was very similar to Ephraim, loads of citrus lots of tangerine and grapefruit hint of cat piss and pine. The body on this is perfect, medium to fuller with with perfect carbonation and a long lingering fiinish. Flavor is awesome with tons going on, citrus rind, tropical fruits, mango, tangerine, grainy bread and crusts with yeast. This is awesome, I need to move to VT.
Can thanks to Ernesto987. Wow. Big hop aroma and presence. Pine and grapefruit. Super cloudy for an IPA/Double. Citrus, sweetness,and fruit. One of the best I¬íve had. Fantastic.

Pours copper with a 2 finger white head. Big aroma of grapefruit and pine. Flavor is WONDERFUL sweet orange along with a huge hop load floating along on a slick well carbonated body. I want more of this soon.

Can courtesy of baconsausage. Thanks Tucker. Hazy golden orange with a moderate amount of white head.Aroma. ..Wow; fruit filled with lemon, grapefruit, orange., and a bit of hop ganja. Mouthfeel is full and slippery with hop resinous qualities. lavors follow suit with the tropical fruit and then a big blast of  dank hop bitterness and  bite. The lasting finish is long, hoppy and balanced. Alcohol very well in the back. Loved this bitter bomb.
UPDATED: NOV 25, 2015 Can. Orange pour with a soapy white head. Pine and citrus aroma and taste. Quite bitter. Very good.

Can via the other site, thanks Zane.  Pours a golden orange with frothy white head.  Aroma is pine, resin and some citrus.  Taste is bitter with a nice tiny malt finish but doesn¬ít have a lot of fruit in the flavor.  No real fruit coming out here.  Overall, a great DIPA but was hoping for more via the hype. Solid.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Can courtesy of Fred82. Hazy amber with a generous creamy bubbly head that leaves nice lacing down the glass. Great hop aroma just pouring it into the glass. Fresh pine and resin, milder citrus (grapefruit) and a bit of alcohol. Great mouthfeel, mildly sweet to start, full bodied, medium carbonation - becomes quite frothy and coats the teeth and palate, bitternes grows gradually to a nice dry and well balanced bitter and full bodied finish. Definitely worth trying and I imagine the fresher the better.

Can¬Ö Hazy golden ale with a small, creamy, white head. Swirling retention. The uber hoppy nose furnishes tropical fruit, leather and a not-entirely-unpleasant suggestion of funky socks. Medium to full-bodied with a milky mouthfeel and tingly carbonation. The flavor is silly fruity and crazy bitter. Lengthy, bittersweet finish... then the bitterness just clings to my tongue and lingers on and on and on and¬Ö Can courtesy of landhoney!

Thin tan head with fair retention and minimal lace. Hazy copper/gold hued ale, some chunkiness. big nose of juicey hops, fruity, citrusy and catty with lightly sweet malts pingin about. Body is med.full. Oily on the palate, lightly resiny, mouthwatering hop goodness. Lotsa citrusy, piney hop flavors, some pineapple and oranges. Malts are lightly sweet and tame, playing along in the background. Finish is fairly dry and fruity. Bitterness is surprisingly subdued but ample. I could of used a bit more bite. Can bonused from jleblanc. Thanks much Jeff!

Fresh can. Thanks a lot to iowaherkeye for giving me this one! Poured a hazy deep orange copper with plenty of sediment. The sediment was surprising as I know this is less than a month old. The head was off white and persistent. The nose has all kinds of fresh citrus goodness as well as some wood. There is also a little bit of French toast goodness. A rich smelling brew indeed. The taste is massive bread crust and grapefruit. The finish is grapefruit rind with a little bit of green wood. There is also a little bit of black pepper in the aftertaste. This is solid and tasty. Thanks again, Joey!

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 This beer stands toe-to-toe with some of the best of the West Coast Double IPA¬ís. The aroma is full of hop resin notes without much malt in the nose. The appearance is a golden color with a orange hue that fills in the middle of the glass. The taste is this beers strong point. It is full of hop bitterness and that carries through to the the finish which consists of the resin notes trailing of and the small malt backbone shining through. Great beer.

Pint can poured into a bubble pint. Pours a murky orange/rust colour with a dense frothy head that clings to the glass, leaving concentric rings of foamy lace with each sip. Large flecks of sediment immediately sink to the bottom. The nose packs an incredible amount of fresh hoppy volatiles. Grapefruit aroma is overwhelming with some zesty, citrus rind and pine as well. Even some passion fruit notes are perceivable. Nuclear hop bomb! Velvety texture in the mouthfeel up front, followed by a highly attenuated, thinner finish, allowing the hop zest, spice and citrus acidity to shine without too much malt interfering. The flavour brings out more of the tropical citrus aromatic qualities, along with some light maltiness that is not overly sweet, which tends to be a problem with many double IPA¬ís out there. Bitter, resinous finish gives you the desired hop hop assault without astringency. The finish is not terribly long, but it is tasty and drying, making this a highly poundable brewski. Could possibly use more carbonation, but if you take the suggestion written on the top of the can, which is to "DRINK FROM THE CAN!", then it¬ís possible that it may not have needed more carbonation given that method of serving. This was truly a pleasure. So dank, so fresh!

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2013 Tall boy can at a recent BA/RB tasting...  A really balanced and drinkable DIPA with some nice hop bitterness and floral spice.  Citrus, pineapple, sweet grains, and a lingering hop finish.

Pint-size can.  Poured slightly hazy medium orange with a tall, creamy, well-retained off-white head.  The aroma picked up juicy pineapple, pine, and grapefruit hoppage over a pale and bready base.. fresh and lovely.  The flavor found bready and biscuity maltage surrounded by very bitter pineapple and grapefruit notes.. some residual pine and citrus bitterness on the long finish.. tasty stuff, but not quite as enjoyable as the nose.  Medium-bodied and very bitter on the palate.. grainy and resiny.. overall a very good beer, and I wish I had more.

Can, I had to pour into a snifter, but I will try it from the can and re-rate if needed.  Peach/ golden color with floaties.  Killer aroma of tropical fruits, mixed citrus zest, really great weed and evergreen forests.  Taste is bitter balanced with tropical fruit flavor.  The hop flavor is out of control.  Medium body with perfect carbonation.  No noticeable booze.  This was dangerously drinkable.  If you like hops, you will need to try this.  I would drink this daily if I had the opportunity. Excellent!

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2011 Can.  Pours a cloudy brown orange with a thin rim of white head.  Aroma of piney hops, pot, grassy hops, rich caramel malt, and a hint of tropical fruits.  Flavor of plenty of caramel malt, some iced tea, and tons of bitter hops, with tropical fruits in the finish.  Tasty IIPA, plenty hoppy and not too sweet.  I could drink this stuff on a regular basis...
8/4/8/4/16 [4.0/5]
Update 11/26/11: On my second can of this delicious nectar, I get a lot more grapefruit and other fruity notes. But mostly super grapefruit. Of course the hop resins and bitter hops are there as well. A superiorly crafted ipa, I really love this stuff. Bumping up my rating...
9/4/9/5/17 (4.4/5)

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2012 Hazy amber pour with a small white head. Tons of dank herbal marijuana notes with a great background of citrus peel, grassy resin, and doughy malts. Soft sourdough in the flavor with huge citrus and caramel notes, finishing off with epic herbals. Medium body with caressing frothy effervescence.

This poured a bright lighter orange color with an off white head. Aroma was of lots of citrusy hops, light herbal and pine notes too. Light caramel malt present as well. Flavor was nicely balanced between fruity hops, bittness, and enough malt to keep it from being a tongue bruiser. Really nice IIPA and worth the hype.

Can from Ernesto987.  Because I don¬ít listen very well I poured this into a glass.  Caramel in color with a medium sized frothy, white head.  Lots of particulates in this which downgrades how it looks.  Pine and juniper dominate the aroma.  Pretty fucking nice smelling.  Taste contain, some caramel, and finishes with some juniper.  Slight bitterness.  I really enjoyed this, but the flavor just didn¬ít live up to the bright hop aroma.  Thanks for the hook up!

16oz can, super fresh, courtesy of a generous BA trader. pours a hazy, golden orange with a thick, creamy, white head with great retention that leaves, dripping sheets of lace on the glass. aroma is wonderful, super dank, with huge notes of dry buds, pine esters, and sticky, wet grass backed by grapefruit rinds, lemon zest, and a touch of tangerine with notes of spiced, bready malts, pinecones, and white pepper as it opens up. flavor is absolutely fantastic as well with huge notes of pink grapefruit, blood orange, and tropical tangerine coming to the forefront ahead of rich, resinous pine and spruce needles, herbal grass, and a touch of vanilla backed by dry malts, caramel, and sweet floral oils. palate is medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a long dry, herbal, resinous, spicy finish. overall, a world class dipa.

From ~16oz can. Poured a moderately hazy amber/orange color. Aroma had a very "weed"-like character, which I particularly don¬ít enjoy that aroma much, the beer still had a pleasant one. Flavor has a touch of biscuit yeast notes. Alcohol is hidden extremely well within this brew.

Can, thanks Joey!  Big floral hop aroma, lots of pine sap/resin, grapefruit, peach, orange, slight sweet note and faint light malt.  Pours a hazy golden color, one finger of white head, fairly good retention.  Great hop flavor; lots of grapefruit, sticky resin, oranges, toasty malt, moderate bitterness but not distracting from the hop flavor, no astringent bitter aftertaste.  Medium body and carbonation, slightly creamy mouthfeel.  A very solid DIPA.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2011 1st October 2011Bottle shared at the Kernel Brewery. Thanks to Mike (tendermorsel) - Cheers mate! Cloudy amber beer, tiny pale cream head. Light crisp palate. Nice fruity hops with semi dry and lacto sweetish malt underneath. A sweetish IPA overall - nice! Finishes with grapefruit, orange, mango and peach dancing around and mild seltzer like minerals. Semi dry finale. Nice! Very nice!

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2013 Hazy amber pour. Nose is absolutely rife with pot and pink grapefruit. The flavor brings an awesome sourdough yeast component that mixes beautifully with the earthy and spicy hop presence. Also huge notes of pine bough and spruce. Very very tasty.

UPDATED: APR 7, 2014 473ml can.

The pour is a nice hazy amber with a foamy white head that leaves a good amount of lacing. Sure, not the prettiest brew but good enough that the Brewers shouldn¬ít be ashamed of it leaving the can.

The smell is awesome when you pour it out, better than sniffing it form the can. It has a great deal of tropical mango and cane sugar. Very resiny. Kind of one-dimensional but in a way that I love.

The flavor is really nice. It has a mellow front end with sugar and melon being the main flavors. There is a bit of pale graininess in the beginning that is that sweet biscuity type which is awesome. The finish is bitter with some nice pine. It is pretty balanced with sweetness all the way through and a nice bitterness at the end. It prob could have had a pinch more bitterness to make it absolutely perfect.

Glad I got to try this, I am often let down by hype, but this one is delicious and worth tracking down.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2014 on tap at hill farmstead harvest festival + from the can in the glass + really from the can (!). golden, orange tint, with a nice white head, good retention and lacing. nose is loads of grapefruit, tropical fruits, juicy fruitiness, pine, honeyed maltiness, hint of vanilla. soft carbonation, medium body, medium long grapefruit finish. great balance. very tasty and aromatic.

Can, with MASSIVE thanks to Fred82 for hooking me up. Pours deep amber/orange, thick off-white head, stunning lacing. So far, so good. Dear God! The nose is like sticking your head in a bag of hop pellets. I honestly have never had a beer that smelled this strongly of straight hops.  Nose is grapefruit, spicy pine, gorgeous resiny, resiny pine. Flavours of spice, rich hop cone, resiny grapefuit. Words utterly fail me, this is possibly the greatest IPA of any description to ever pass my lips. A stunning effort.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2014 A big, big THANKS to Damico for this can share.  Pours a cloudy orange amber color with a nice white foam head.  Aroma of grapefruit and earthiness, with some caramel mixed in.  Has a sweet caramel taste with ridiculously perfect dank hop resiny hit.  Smooth as can be.  The harsh hop hit does not outlast the finish, leaving you with delicate grapefruit notes at the end of this perfection.  Not overhyped.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2015 Can at Kernel Brewery tasting. It pours hazy orange, with a thin foamy white head. The nose is pine, orange sherbet, orange squash, varnish, peach and grapefruit. The taste is orange, tangy marmalade, mango, tangerine, peach, grapefruit, pine, resin, big hop bite and some metal, with bitter citric finish. Good balance, medium body and average carbonation. Update: I have had this plenty of times since my first rating and it never ceases to amaze me just how tasty and crushable this stuff is. Consistently great.

They shoulda called it "Teddy Hopper" (duh).
By far one of the best beers ever to be put in an aluminum canister, you betcha.  Get you some, soon...... something this great cant last very long, right??

UPDATED: APR 20, 2012 16oz can. Thanks for sharing Sean! Dank papaya aroma. Cloudy dark amber with whitish rim aroma. 

Slippery, but decent hop flavor profile. Tangy and sharp. I¬ím 

not digging this somehow. Sharply bitter in the finish. I want 

more pungency and cleanliness. Too much cloud. Bummer, not that great.
Extremely hoppy aromas of cat pee, cut grass, grapefruit.  Flavors mirror the the aromas.  This is an absolutely fantastic IPA

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2012 Thanks Spence.  Pint Can. Super haxzy orange ameber with a medium sized white head.  Nose is full of hop resin, some sweetness, citrus.  Flavor is similarly super resinous, sweet, mild bitterness.  Pretty tasty, alcohol slightly noticeable.   

Rerate:  Had a fresh 8 pack of this from the brewery and it changed my tune a bit.  Fucking great beer.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2012 Absolute hop masterpiece here.  If you like hops and lots of em find this beer.  The flavor is citrus, pine, grass, and herbal spicy notes.  Every type of hop flavor is huge and not subtle.  You can see chunks of hops floating in it but dont be scared theyre delicious.  Loved it.

Can:  The aroma consists of tropical fruits, citrus, a touch of pineapple, and grapefruit.  It pours a transparent amber with a minimal white head.  The flavor starts with moderate tropical fruits and pineapple.  The finish has some orange and light-moderate grapefruit.  Light bodied with mild carbonation.

Can, thanks Seth!  Hazy burnt orange pour with an off white head.  Pine and citrus aromas.  Outstanding balance, with smooth pine and resiny hop notes off set by a sturdy caramel malt backbone.  Light citrus and floral undercurrents.  Just a great freakin¬í DIPA, and from a can.  Kudos to the Alchemist Pub and Brewery.......

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2012 Wow, best piney ops aroma. Smells like a pine forest in the morning while camping. Pour is murky dark orange. Pine body, light bitterness in the flavor that ramps up into finish for a long stone like finish length. Superb.

16 oz. can courtesy of Forgetfu (Big thanks Bill!) poured a hazy tarnished gold with a small lasting creamy ivory head. Aromas of biscuit, grapefruit, tangerine, pine,light tropical fruit and ligh grassiness. Palate was mediumto full bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of biscuit, grapefruit, tangerine, pine and tropical fruit with a smoth dry bitter lingering citrus finish. One of the better DIPAs I¬íve had in a long time!

16oz can provided by MrBarleywine, thanks for hooking me up Mike! 
Pours a slightly cloudy deep golden color with a stingy white head that dissipates quickly. Smells of pine, resin, and a slight bit of citrus and dankness. If there¬ís any malt in here I can¬ít find it, but I really don¬ít miss it because I could smell this all night. Taste is mildly sweet bready biscuity malt being assassinated by an onslaught of hops. Resinous dank pine hops barely let any malt come through, but some do find their way in. Medium to thin body and level of carbonation, resinous bitter mouthfeel. This one is all about the hops, no shit right its a DIPA. There is a bitterness here, but its pleasant, aromatic and not harsh. This is a damn fine beer!

Enjoyed at Mug¬ís Ale House after sneaking in a car after receiving in a trade (thanks mltobin).

This is one of the few beers to live up to the almost insane hype around it. The appearance in pretty much exactly what you would exepect from a good DIPA, hazy orange with an off white head. Despite the cans suggestion to drink out of it, I went ahead and poured it into a pint glass to get a good idea of the smell and it is a fantastic piney resin with citrus notes. The first sip just blew me away. As the can says it¬ís not the most bitter, but man it has the most flavor. Sweet malt base, with not overly bitter hops. Perfectly balanced. I can only knock the mouthfeel. It leaves a less than pleasant coating in the mouth.

Overall. Amazing. One of the best DIPAs out there.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 Bottle consumed a few months back.

A: Golden orange body with a pillowy off-white head that sticks around for a bit before leaving solid lacing down the sides of the glass.

S: Beautifully bitter grapefruit, orange, pine, and resinous oil. Thick and layered. Easily could get lost for minutes just exploring the aroma.

T: Ever so slightly a fall off from the nose. The Hops didn¬ít quite "pop" with the same intensity as in the aroma. Still, the was quite complex, delicious, and top notch.

M: Creamy smoothness. Medium bodied with appropriate carbonation. One of the really nice things was with all of the bitterness, it managed to not be prickly or raw.

O: A very nice dIPA that deserves to be up with the big boys. I¬íd imagine super-fresh on tap would take this a notch higher.

Drank on tap (12 oz) at the brewpub, on August first, 2011. Honey blonde a little hazy, medium head. Juicy citrus hop aroma and slightly acidic, some herbal notes. Extreme nuclear hop flavor (not a hop by the way), many herbs sweet, good bitterness. This is a f***ing great IIPA!

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2012 Damn, this is hoppy. That¬ís about my first impression immediately upon popping the cap off of this. With that, I should say huge, huge thanks to rpstevens and kingcrowing for sending me bottles of this, the latter of which was a complete surprise. One bottle to be consumed tonight, the other to be shared with friends this weekend.

This bottle is shared with Amyliz4 and poured into two of our larger, unbranded tulips. The pour yields a slightly-hazed bright peach body with a two-finger head. Pretty good retention and plenty of spotty lacing as it makes its way down to a bit of rocky foam sitting atop the brew. A fairly-thick collar remains on the brew throughout as more spots settle on the sides of the glass.

As previously stated, the aroma on this is damn near epic and remains amazing throughout. The initial whiff slammed my nostrils with dominant notes of tropical fruit, citrus rind, and a bit of pine. Each swirl kicks up another bit of aroma with some mango skin and passion fruit taking hold at first. Behind that is a flock of citrus and an overload of ripe peaches. Following behind all this when you sniff really hard is a nice finish of some piney resin.

The flavor picks up where the nose left off, though doesn¬ít quite dominate my senses like the nose did. With that said, this is some really, really incredible stuff. I¬íll start off with one of my only complaints, which is that the hop flavor isn¬ít quite as pungent as the aroma is. Still, there is some fairly-radical hop flavor to balance the hop bitterness. Did you hear that many makers of East Coast IPAs? Malt sweetness doesn¬ít provide balance to bitterness in a fantastic double IPA, lovely and luscious fruit flavors do.

Mango, passion fruit, and guava make their way into the mix. The strong, strong bitterness levels really elevate the citrus presence and make me think of some good grapefruit rind. The body on this does an absolutely remarkable job accentuating the hops. There¬ís not an ounce of sweetness, but there¬ís enough body to really pull everything together. The bitterness in the finish is uber-high and leaves my mouth quite dry. There¬ís certainly a solution for that--have some more.

I¬íve been waiting a long, long time to finally try this one. Unlike an unfortunately-large percentage of other beers with so much hype, I have enjoyed this immensely. Huge, huge thanks again to Ryan and Nick for the chance to finally try this. Cheers to both of you.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-09-2010

Draft @ Blind Tiger. Almost a ruby pour with some white head. Although i feel sorry since this beer was up against Lawsons Double Sunshine... Grassy and earthy aroma.  Flavor dominated by grapefruit  and pine resins. Nice dipa.

Bottle into my Narke tulip...Medium copper, not bright or sparkly enough for me. Tope head pretty good, looks good, nice retention and lacing...Aroma is really malty, lots of caramel, great to balance out the hops and alcohol. Hop presence is huge though, really good...The taste is also really malty, very different and unique for a dipa, but great to mask the hops and make it drinkable. Hops are more there in the feel.

Draft.  Pours a hazy amber body with a thin off white head that quickly diminishes.  Big bag of bitter grass tones, weed y with a very resinous notes.  Very bitter dry with a huge pot like bitter hoppiness.  Pure hop resins and a slick apricot and citrus sweetness.

Bottle 650 ml  
Aroma ultra-aromatic, plenty of hops , resinous, peppery spicy aroma.7+
 Appearance  visible turbidity on amber colour , creamy medium top ,laced.
Flavor and Palate : Medium bodied , smooth and clean. Drinkable is this ultra-hopped ale. Plenty of resinous feel. Clean perfectly presented hop profile without any harshness. Perfect example of hop expose. Simply splendid.

Appearance
Hazy, some floaties in it, not too fond of that.

Smells super danky, grass, weed, onion, garlic, some citrus and spicy notes.

tastes like Dank weed and grapefruit, thank god less garlic and onion, but still there a bit. A hint of sweetness in the background to help give it just a hint of balance but really, not much at all.

mouthfeel was just a plier pulling the tongue bitterness, not thin or dry, good for style. The alcohol doesn¬ít come out at all.

I would say this was pretty dissapointing for all the crazy hype...

From tap at the brewpub. Pours hazy orange with a small with a small white head. Aroma is grapefruity and dense peachy. Peachy, citrusy and grapefruity. Bitter and citrusy dry finish. Bitter and slight herbal finish. Lasting grapefruity note.
Tap at Blind Tiger - Lots of fruity hop notes and evergreen herbaceous. Caramel malts, smooth bodied and brightly carbonated.

Very impressive DIPA.  The hop aromas, very C-hop, are very satisfying and very fresh as if I am at the brewery now , as if hand bottled.  Great lacing and head. Unfiltered look and taste, a full mouthfull.  A little astringent. Grea carbonation.  Bottle from Fred.
Stupid hoppy aroma and flavor.  Spruce boughs and dried mango stuffed into your face.  Nice and dry for a double IPA, but not astringent or grating.  Just superb.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2013 Original rating: 2/4/2011: 7/4/7/4/18 4.0: Bottle in trade with Glouglouburp. Thanks!  Pours a hazy amber color with a big white head and nice lacing.  Aroma is citrus, grapefruit hops.  Medium on the palate with average carbonation.  Excellent citrus hop flavor with a nice malt balance and a nice bitter hop finish.  Very similar to some west coast DIPAs I have had the pleasure to try.  A very good beer.  Updated rating: fresh can 10/11/2013

22oz bottle split with McBerko (thanks!). Pours a slightly hazy mahogany with receeding off white head. Uh-oh! Aroma seems slightly askew. Faded hops fight for air with some breaded malt notes, caramel and a slight off-putting funkiness...not enough to suggest the bottle is off, just not at its prime (?). Flavour has some hops but for my money the malt works to suppress them rather than counter balance them. The finish is just fairly ordinary though the alcohol is again quite well worked in. I would have suspected that this had been sitting around for too long had I not been told it was a very fresh bottle. Shame, I was led to expect bigger things.

HUGE thanks to Brian for sending this my way!

A-Body is a nearly transparent light amber hue. Bubbles can be seen all over the place. Pours with a perfect two finger or so foamy white head with perfect retention. Lacing left all the way down the glass.

S- Nose is awesome. Perfect. Citrus hops and white grapefruit everywhere. A faint sweet malt backbone can be detected as well. Very rich and citrusy.

T- Complex for an IPA and different hop impressions emerge with each sip. Citrus initially, then a touch of herbal and grassy, then a touch of pine and spicy at the end. The citrus is very bright initially then fades off the grassy and herbal remain contantly in the background. The pine is very mild and much more resiny than bright. A really big hop bitterness lingers on and on-citrus and pine resin with a big spicy hop overlay.

M-Medium to high carbonation and a slightly smooth and oily light to medium weight body.

D- Fantastic DIPA overall-complex and certainly in my top five-its a bit to bitter to take the #1 spot for me. Its certainly a hop bomb. Reminds me of my experience with PtY-although that was almsot 2 yrs ago. I hope the Alchemist keeps releasing this because it is a must try DIPA!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 12-19-2010 22:03:55
bottled a few weeks ago and shared by kan. pours heady hazy white head nose is very pungent green grapefruit Clementine flavors grapefruit pungent peach fuzz bitter, killer hoppy goodness.

Bottle shared by my buddy Matt.  Pours a hazy golden orange with a ton of hop sediment.  Nose exploded with tons of citrus hops and tropical fruits, also a bit resiny.  Nice and citrusy on the palate with out being overly bitter.  A damn fine double IPA.

Mike Jones! Sorry fuckers, but I was worried about the freshness quotient of this here bad boy so I figured I¬íd have to take one for the team and drink it by myself. I might get another one some time, but I will make it up with my winnings from being awesome at fantasy football. Fuck those other fags I got my auction game on lock. Tim Tebow is my new favorite player, he¬ís a god damn winner. So the nose on this one is nice, its tropical and piney. Notes of peach, apricots, lots of pine and dank, and nice citrus notes too such as grapefruit and other various citruses. pours hazy orange amber not amazing looking by any means but it looks like an ipa. great lace fuck punctuation and capitals and shits. A great rap song is Fat Pat "Heart of a Hustla". White people listen to this. Tropical fruit hop flavor, hoes and sluts, dental dams, jet skis, cocaine, halucinogens. YES! This is a nice fruity hoppy beer! Not like a Mavericks or some other great beer using hops, but its nice, fresh fruity and danky. Heat of a hustler mind of a g, player hating ninjas cant fuck with me. Its nice. Danky resiny finish, nice flavor, great drinabiltity. Fcuking shit. I will get another to share. This shit was real good fuckers

22oz bottle. Short rating (¬ícuz I¬ím at work). Bottom of the bottle pour. Very murky with lots of suspended particulate. Dark, dark orange/copper with a lasting, frothy, thin white head. Fairly resinous aroma. Plenty of pine, biscuit and honey. A hint of ginger as well as some mint and cilantro. Flavor shows almost as much resin as the aroma, but somehow I was looking for just a bit more. Very dry on the tongue. Plenty hoppy, but not overly bitter. Cut green grass with some floral and perfume notes. Herbaceous with a hint of mint. Medium bodied. Firm on the tongue. Moderate to low carbonation. Fairly bitter and astringent on the finish, but ends rather abruptly. An immensely drinkable, East Coast IPA. Thanks for the treat Dany!

UPDATED: APR 1, 2013 22 oz. bottle, sent from Glouglouburp, split with manuchampions, pours murky orangey brown with a small white head. Unusual aroma for an IPA of dark butterscotch, burnt caramel, with the hops a secondary feature - quite complex nose. The flavour doesn¬ít match up to the aroma¬ís complexity - earthy hops, muted malt backing, slight fruitiness, and a little caramel. Good, though I don¬ít see how this is worth the hype. 8 3 7 4 14  3.6 / 5

2nd try: This time, from a 500mL can courtesy of adamjackson (thanks a lot, Adam). Pours a vibrant golden orange with a big off-white head and ridiculous amounts of sediment floating about, that finally settles in the bottom. Awesome aromatics, full of resinous hops, tropical fruits and a big caramel malt backing - a bit of butterscotch as noticed in the first sampling but no where near as pronounced. Flavour brings out beautiful notes of resinous hops, a little butterscotch and a big juicy caramel malt backing. Very juicy and "big" feeling, without being a palate scorcher - though this is not shy of hops by any means. Excellent stuff.
8 3 9 4 17  4.1 / 5

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 Bottle. Pours a light amber yellow color with a slight white head. Some sediment floating around. Danky type aroma of citrus and some pine type notes, some onion as well. Some lace. Medium mouthfeel. Slighlty sweet taste with a strong hop bitter flavor. Lingering bitterness. Does it live up to the hype? Sure, it¬ís pretty tasty!

Can: Pours a cloudy amber orange color with a lot of sediment in it. Light tan head. Again, same as the bottle, the can has a nice danky citrus type aroma that is pretty nice. Nice lacing as I drink this down. Nicely balanced between citrus sweet and tind bitterness. A tasty brew that I could drink all the time. ABV does not show.

22oz bottle pours a hazy orange with a thin, cloudy white head.  Nose is awesome, stanky hops, oily, resinous, pine tar, pineapple, grapefruit.  Flavor is sweet, malty, grapefruit, lemon, pine.  It¬ís not soapy at all, which is really nice.  Lightly herbal.  Full bodied, bitter finish.  The finish is very bright.  Really solid.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2013 Thanks to Josh for sharing. Pours a hazy golden orange with a medium white head.  Aroma of this great American hop mix, citrus, floral and tropical fruits along with a pie crust maltiness.  Flavor of the same great floral, pine and citrusy hops.  Smooth hop bitterness. Well done DIPA, one of the best I have ever had!

Many thanks to a very generous BA for the opportunity to try this one, 22oz bomber.

Pours a bright, clear amber with a big pillowy white head with a rocky bottom fed by a steady stream of bubbles   Retention is good and leaves a soapy collection of big bubbles on top with good lacing.

Aroma is wonderful and typical of a top-tier west coast DIPA.  Tons of juicy citrus with oranges and pineapples mixed with a thick resinous pine aroma.  Bit of biscuity malt in the background.

Flavor is just as good with an initial astringent citrus bitterness, pithy grapefruit, that flows into a more juicy citrus backbone with the oranges and pineapples coming back in.  The finish is bitter and resinous, sticky with pine hops.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied and well carbonated with a wonderful stickiness clinging to the palate after each sip.

One of the best DIPAs I¬íve had in recent memory and possibly the best east coast DIPA I¬íve ever tasted.  Super drinkable but with tons of hop character and bitterness.  Really superb beer.

Fiery orange with a frothy white head, diminishes quickly. Lightly creamy, fruity nose, pineapple, hop pellets, bit cheesy. Flavor  similar, some caramel dominated by resinous heavy pine bitterness and light citrus. Thin, oily body. Meh. Is every near-fresh DIPA a 99%?

bottle courtesy of hopsnhappiness, 22oz to my dome. pours a very hazy yellowish amber, beautiful body on it, the head is stark white and pretty fluffy, so-so retention, but keeps a white skim on the surface the whole way down. the smell is lightly soapy and astringent, with subtle hints of fruits and flowers underneath it. seems sort of subdued compared to the taste. the taste is similar, but honestly i feel like this is a pretty balanced iipa. there is a lot of bitterness and dryness, and i get a good amount of syrupy sweetness in the finish and especially the aftertaste that balances it out. its like a sour or bitter candy. thei is def now a west coast style iipa, but i really enjoyed it and can see why there has been a fus over it. its very drinkable, and honestly i keep comparing it to tap pliny with the bitterness levels and balance. there is a nice piney ness in the aftertaste, and all the astringency goes away, only a touch or dryness and still a moderate amount of bitterness remain, which is balanced with the butter-cookie like malts, making you want more. i drank this bottle rather quickly and enjoyed it a ton.

22oz courtesy of ygtbsm94. Pour is a clear, light amber orange with a thin, white head. Aroma is massive fruity hops, big fresh Centennial and Cascade pellets, fresh grapefruit, pineapple, fresh pine, caramel. Really just a super dank hop nose. Taste is astringent, dry, resinous, loads of nutty bitterness piling on. Dry, bitter palate.

22oz bottle, thanks ygtbsm94.  Small off-white head with hazy amber body.  Aroma is moderately sweet, grapefruit, pineapple, some orange.  Taste is medium sweet, grapefruit, some orange, pineapple.  Resiny medium-full body.

Fruity, floral nose, lots of citrus, some light vinous notes and just a touch of phenolic yeast. Taste is lightly sweet, moderately bitter, lots of citrus and floral hops, a bit astringent. The malt is dry, but it¬ís thin and bland.
750 ml bottle courtesy of brad, thanks!  Bright gold, edge head.  Massive grass and Christmas tree aroma.  Very bitter, lots of pine resin.  Nice.

22oz bottle. much thanks to a man named M... pours a muddled and hazy apricot brown pour, showing some effervescence even long after the pour.  a thin to medium creamy white head crowns it while not having the patience to stick around.... aroma is bright juicy hops with a mango papaya core that pervades with its arms wide open.  not much detection of any malts as this is a tropical fruit explosion with bits of sweetness tossed in for good measure... flavors are not much of a letdown from where the journey began.  abundance of a juicy and assertive hop profile takes precedence and never ceases to let go.  semi-sweet from the onset and then bittering towards the finish with a citrus rind extenuation on the tongue.  carbonation level gives a lot of life and body is just right. this one surely exercises and almost abuses the palate in the best of ways.  vermont, oh how much i¬íve been loving you lately.  first hill farmstead, then lawson¬ís finest, and now this....are you kidding me?

22oz bottle, huge thanks to nathanjohnson on BA.  Pours clear copper with a two-finger white head and excellent lacing.  The aroma is really awesome.  Huge floral and citrusy hop punch with sweet caramel malt.  Clean and intense.  The flavor is deinitely east coast style, but probably the best in that style I¬íve had.  Sweet caramel malt balanced by a huge flavorful and bitter hop burst.  Floral notes, grapefruit, and orange.  Tasty as hell.  The mouthfeel is nice, medium-bodied with big hop resins and a long enamel-ripping finish.  Nice beer overall.  Awesome for an east coast style DIPA.

A: The pour is a cloudy dark orange with a finger¬ís worth of white head.

S: The nose is intensely perfumey with lots of grapefruit, mango, pine, and lemon zest. There¬ís a pretty nice pine aroma, and just an overall fruitiness to it.

T: Mango, pineapple, grapefruit, and lemon zest give this a big fruitiness. Though it does have a lot of fruit notes, it¬ís also pretty intensely bitter and piney, which is very nice.

M: The body is medium with a pretty lively carbonation and a dry, bitter finish.

D: Certainly a very, very good IPA. Actually reminded me a lot of Sculpin, but more bitter. Would definitely like to have this one again.

Thanks to Murchmac.  Bottle.  Enjoyable beer but lacking any real bitter bite and not quite as loaded down with hops as I prefer.  The beer pours a cloudy, tawny orange-amber with a white head.  A very nice sweet citrus and tropical fruit tone dominates the aroma.  It¬ís almost entirely tangerine rind, mangoes and guava.  There¬ís a hint of pine lurking in the background.  However, it¬ís not quite as pungent as the best of the style.  Surprisingly, the taste lacks nearly any assertive bitterness.  There¬ís a bit of grapefruit pith in the finish, but this is one of the least bitter DIPAs that I¬íve ever tasted.  That said, it¬ís also not overly malty or particularly sweet.  It just sorta lacks a strong taste note.  The thin body and utter lack of hop oiliness in the mouthfeel emphasized this problem for me.  It does have a nice hoppy aftertaste.  It was an enjoyable beer to drink, but, ultimately, I found the beer rather disappointing.  The taste fails to deliver on the promise of the smell.  I¬ím happy to have tried it, but I don¬ít really understand the hype.

Unbelievable aroma of grapefruit, sweet floral citrus. Its like drinking grapefruit juice! The only other beer to make me say that was a fresb hopslam! I cant get my nose out of the glass, its intoxicating! So sweet and juicy, the finish is a wicked pithy bitterness just like if you bit into a grapefruit! The citric aftertaste last forever. For hop addicts like myself, you must seek out this beer! I have no choice...... I have to give this  a 5!

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2012 It smells so pleasant with a nice blend of citrus hop notes. The can sits in front of you and the beautiful scent of marijuanaesque hops wafts to the nose in an awesome way.  It pours cloudy golden with an orange hue. Some of the cans have more prevalent hop sediment than others. Both bottles I tried had generous amounts for sure. The full juicy body goes down so smooth and the hop flavors reflect the aroma perfectly. There is no bite at all, the juicy citrus hops make it right to the cusp better never go over!!!! Perfect. Best IPA ever.

On tap at the Alchemist on my way to Hill Farmstead for BWBDV.  Pours a  hazy gold amber with a medium to large sized white head. Huge citrus and pine aromas.  Big juicy hops, sticky malt and caramel with a touch of alcohol.  Finishes long and slow , thick with grapefruit and big quinine flavors.  So good.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2013 Verre de 12 oz, au pub. Ar√¥mes tr√®s intenses de houblon am√©ricain, tr√®s r√©sineux et fruit√© (agrumes). Robe p√™che et trouble, l√©g√®re mousse et effervescence moyenne. En bouche, le houblon aromatique domine, tr√®s r√©sineux et fruit√©, l√©g√®rement astringent. Le malt joue un r√¥le de soutient. Finale tr√®s am√®re et s√®che. Tr√®s intense, une bonne dose de houblon !

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2015 Amber color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of pine, floral hops, citrus, honey, and alcohol  Taste of sticky pine sap, citrus, resiny hops, grass, grapefruit, and some alcohol in the finish.

I have to reserve a perfect 5 for "the beer out there" I have yet to try, but let me tell you, this one made it very difficult to deduct a tenth of a point. If you are one who adores hopes, you won¬ít be let down. Many IPAs claim to be hoppy, this one simply delivers. Drive to Waterbury, VT and enjoy!

On tap at The Alchemist on April 24th 2010
Appearance : Clear yellow with small head. Extensive lacing.

Aroma : Leafy hops with passion fruits. Very leafy and fresh. Wow this is an awesome nose. I can hardly believe it.

Taste : Hoppy with some alcohol. Dry finish and very hoppy. Notes of mango. Same leafy and crisp hoppy profile.

Overall : Wow this is a good beer. It would have to be tasted side by side with Hopslam and PtE but to me it felt like this one was up to the challenge. I have to have this again !!!

Tap @ Blind Tiger.  I am very impressed with this beer.  Poured a slightly hazed orange-copper color with a small white head.  A strong but very nice hop forward aroma.  Citrus and pine.  There was some sweet malt underneath but it does not distract from the hops :)  The beer had a large hop flavor with citrus and pine mixed together.  Mild to moderate sweetness with a hint of malt.  Moderate bitterness on the finish helps give it a stiff backbone and balance.  Semi-dry with a meidum body.  Very nice.

Tap at BT.  Hazy orange pour with a thin soapy, white head.  CItrus and apricot in the aroma - pleasant wildflower type hoppiness.  Stronger piney/grassy component than I expected in the flavor.  Nice green finish and the alcohol is well hidden.  Great beer overall.

Tap at Bling Tiger. Big hoppy aroma and fierce oregano and basil. I seem to be the only one that tasted those, but taste them I did. Even more in the flavor, especially the Oregano, like walking into a pizza parlor. Works as a very nice compliment to the  hops. Palate is thick and really not that bitter considering the IBUs. Enjoyable.

UPDATED: MAY 5, 2008 Draft at BlindtigerOne of the best double ipas I¬íve ever had. 
The flavour was unbelievable, big juicy flowery hops, well balanced with a good dosage of malts. the hop character is absolutely genius. citrus, flower grass, pine, none to overpowering. and such good mouthfeel really juicy hop flavour.

Draft at the Blind Tiger.  Nice orange pour, with a thin white film on top.  Aroma is pine hops, lemon rind, and citrusy hop oils.  The flavor is the same, oily and resiny mouthfeel and good bitterness.  There is a lot of citrus in the end, and good malt throughout.
Draft at Blind Tiger. Apricot color with a small head. Flavor is C hops with some peach. Decent IIPA with a nice, dry finish.

on tap-pours a retaining big foamy/creamy light tan head and hazy amber color.  Aroma is cascade hops-citrus.  Taste is cascade hops-citrus, uber dry, bitter, raw.  An I2PA less the slick mouth feel.  OK carbonation.

Sampled at vt brewfest 07. Pours a dark golden amber with a off white head.Aroma of citrus, simcoe hops, grapefruit and pine. Flavor is hoppy with biscuity malt, spicy pine and grapefruit with a strong lasting bitter finish.

Vermont Brewers Fest ¬í07.  Fruity hoppy aroma.  Pale golden.  The aroma is quite fruity with notes of peach, apricot, and pear.  Earthy with light orange peel and pine.  Fresh, light pale malt.  Quite light and easy to drink, defying its ABV.  A berryish yeast gives this brew some interest.  Sweetish from both the hops and the pale malt.  A really nice brew.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2011 Partly cloudy dark yellow body topped by small white head.  Conventionally malted body with a malt sweetness residing somewhere between honey and caramel.  The beer balance is towards the hops.   Generous amount of many types of hops with a resulting hop flavour being 75% citrus-fruits and 25% resinous coniferous.  Very nice.  Bitterness of medium intensity and finish of medium length.  Very good although side-by-side I preferred their regular IPA (Holy Cow).  But besides the Holy Cow, few beer can Topper.

En f√ªt. Verre d√©gust√© √† la brasserie. Ar√¥me: Odeur d¬íagrumes et de pin. Apparence: La couleur est blonde voil√©e. Pr√©sence d¬íun mince col mousseux et d¬íune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Go√ªt d¬íagrumes et de pin. Dur√©e moyenne de l¬íarri√®re go√ªt. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture l√©g√®rement huileuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. (Rating #979)

on tap at the blind tiger grand opening night.  dark golden amber color.  off white head.  aroma is resiny pine, cat piss, wet eucalyptus trees, and a little hemp.  flavor is dry and sweet hop, bitter.  a little pithy like grapefruit, but there still was a thin caramel malt backbone to tug the other side of the scale.  finsih is bitter and warm/faintly hot.

Pint on tap at Blind Tiger.  Probably should have been a tulip pour. haha.  Pours aslightly hazy deep gold, light copper with a small initial head but fades to almost nothing.  That was the only bad part though.  Aroma was intense with amarillo and simcoe hops- maybe some summit?  Catpiss, mango, and grapefruit all all pretty dominant, some citrus, orange rind, and light pine resin along with a somewhat sticky sweet malt backbone, but obviously skewed heavily in NW hops.  Flavor is sticky, tangy and resinous, with tons of amarillo and simcoe hops, catty, mango, citrus, some grapefruit puckering bitterness, and a  somewhat tacky bitterness.  Smooth mouthfeel and easy to down a pint of this which could be dangerous.  Damn fine DIPA esp from an east-coast brewer.  Top notch.

On tap at the Blind Tiger Ale House.  Light amber in color with a small off white head.  Aroma iis pretty complex and very hoppy- apricot, pineapple, grapefruit, and pine.  Taste is also very fruity and hoppy, medium bodied, with a lasting firm bitter finish.  enjoyed this alot.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2007 Tap at Blind Tiger: Pours a slightly hazy deep golden with hardly any head. (Disappointing, considering this brews name) Very fruity hoppy aroma. Lemony, sherbet like, apricots, perfumy and piney. Flavor is hop juice. This is one of those IIPAs without that extremely malty sweetness, which sometimes makes these style brews syrupy. So if you like assertive hops, this is an IIPA for you. The malts offer just enough back for the hops packed into this brew. It gives it a slightly almond-like background. Very bitter, cascade, with lemony citrus, grapefruit rind, and a long resiny bitter finish. An aggressively hoppy Ale.

On tap at Blind Tiger. Copper in color with a nice fluffy white head. Citrusy flowery aroma. Piney, grassy notes. Hoppy and malty flavor. Earthy citrusy notes. Nice bitter finish. Sweet.  Full bodied. Crisp and refreshing. Very nice beer.
On draught at Alchemist.  Pours copper with a thin white head.  Smells of citrus ad perfume.  Taste is hoppy with more hops on the finish.  An unexpected hop bomb.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2012 Draught pint @ Redbones 5/6/06. Pours a golden copper color with a white foamy head. Nose is floral and grapefruit hop notes with some light malt notes. Flavor is hoppy and simple. Lots of very nice hop notes but the malt side is lacking in complexity and strength. Finishes with a standard bitterness. Very crisp and refreshing. 

16oz can 1/26/12 pours a bright orange color with a big white head. Nose is very floral and wonderful with light pine notes. Palate is crisp and fizzy with a light syrup feeling. Flavors of floral hops, syrupy biscuit and toast malt notes, honey comb, hop cone, wonderfulness. Numbers reflect updated rating.
En f√ªt-Odeur de citron et de houblon, jaune troubl√©, sal√© vers l¬íarri√®re de la bouche.-Draft--Lemony and hoppy aromas, yellow cloudy, salty in the second half of the mouth.

On cask at the pub.
Creamy, satiny smooth and lushious orange, with a burly head.  It really was a heady topper!  Hop damn!  Resinous, gooey cascade, piney, patchouli, weed and citrus rounded off the aroma. 
Wicked bitter, but feels almost milky in the gullet (thank you mister cask!).  An all-out hop attack, the malt can¬ít do anything but surrender to this unstoppable force.  The hops were so intense that I actually had my fill of it, and spent the rest of my weekend drinking lambics and other low-alpha acid brews.  I loved it and will have it again, but not 2-3 pints in one session.

Pours a cloudy golden color with a thin white head. Amazing aroma of resinous and citrusy hops. Amazing flavor of resinous and citrusy hops with a strong backbone of biscuity malt. Strong and very long lasting bitter finish. The body is medium with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. I love this beer.

Aroma:big big hopy nose.....
Appearance:Gold with a good white head...
Flavor:God grapefruit hops,light sugar malt...
UPDATED: JUL 19, 2005 Had this on tap at the Alchemist pub in waterbury, VT. Great, thick creamy double IPA, wish I lived closer, so I could get this all the time.

Sampled at the 2005 EBF: Pours a clear bronze color with a lacy white head.  Intense fresh bold green hoppy aroma.  Body is mildly sweet and well hopped but thin.  Has a good resiny hop profile and a crisp clean pine finish, but could use a little more malty sweetness to be true to style.  Still a nice beer though.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2005 Draft, EBF: Clear orange, light white head. Strong orange aroma, woody creamed grapefruit, lots of pineapple. Very intense vegetal hops though the malt backbone is present, if not up to the typical imperial IPA level. Floral and citrusy bitterness. Well made in the style, but too aggressive citric bitterness for nothing to my tastes. Oily medium body, light carbonation. One more, one less¬Ö / Re-rate from a pint at the brewpub: Extremely aromatic, zesty orange hops with a nice supporting biscuity maltiness that smoothens the upcoming hops onslaught, bitter yet tactful and sensitive. Better than the 3.3 I had initially gave it.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2016 The Lure:Gorgeous marijuana and oranges make the mouth water, while slim malts contribute a lightly biscuity character to the prevalent dank perfume. Great lacing around an obviously unfiltered authenticity.

The Festivities:Addictive citrus fruit and dank hop resins cooperate marvelously in this well-brewed and almost quaffable hophead¬ís dream. Mildly honeyed malts support the hop panorama. Superbly dank coniferous hop bitterness follows the multi-faceted hop flavors, and lingers ad vitam eternam. This is as good a Double IPA there is in the US of A.

Transcendence:Millions of sunrays uplift the spirit.

XBF05:  Clear dark orangy yellow, with a large white rocky head that leaves good lacing.  Huge spicy pine, citrus, resin aroma, full bodied with lively carbonation starts and ends heavily bitter with a touch of acidity at the end.  An excellent example of an IIPA.

Sampled at Etreme Beer Fest 05, Good nose, citrusy, grapefruit/orange. Maybe a little pineapple. Toffee/carmel.  Tad hazy orangy yellow color. Bitter flavors. Grapefruit mainly, little metallic, little plasticy. Lite creamy mouthfeel, thinner bodied, bitter dry finish. Good brew, though I was expecting more by what I¬íd read about it.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 22, 2005 Original Rating (8-3-8-5-17=4.1): Extremely fruity aroma - orange and grapefruit hops nose battles with yeasty esters. Clear, light amber coloured with decent off-white head that lasts nicely. Bitterness is masked by the opening sweet fruitiness but creeps up from the sides of the tongue. Citrus y hop flavours mingle wonderfully with sweet malts and yeasty esters. Alcohol is not at all apparent in the flavour although it is gently warming. Medium body and smooth creamy mouthfeel. A pleasure on the tongue. More please. On tap at the Vermont Brewers Festival.Rerate (7-4-8-4-14=3.7): Orange, grapefruit-citrus, resinous hop nose.  Opaque yellow-tan coloured body is topped with a low, fine bubbled, white head that recedes to a partial cover and rings with lace down the sides of the glass.  Very strong hop bitterness and assertive, tart, citrus character - this one is all about the hops although sweet malt character is evidenced underneath.  Medium body with moderate carbonation.  Sampled on tap at the brewpub with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Rastacouere and Yowie.

On tap at Vermont Brewers Fest.  3 oz sample.  Citrus grapefruit aroma with some C-hop notes.  Maybe a touch of sourness in there as well.  Transparent copper with an off-white head.  I like my IIPAs a little darker.  Start is slightly sweert leading to hops in the middle and a slight alcohol burn to go with it.  Finish is extremely smooth and a pleasant slightly sweet.  Very drinkable and somewhat balanced.  Enjoyable.

Sampled at the VT brewers fest.  I think I smell hops.  Cascade, and something a little funky...I can¬ít quite put my finger on it.  Kinda musty.  Advertised at 120 IBUs this is not as hoppy as I expected.  Average at best because of this funkiness.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2011 Draft, from can - Pours a darkish orange-amber in color with a very small white head that fades quickly.  Low carbonation.  Aroma is piney with some citrus and also some malty sweetness.  Flavor is a "heady" mix of sweet malts along with medium bitter citrus and pine hops.  Palate is quite thick and almost slightly oily.  Finish is medium bitter and lingering along with the intense hop flavors.  I absolutely LOVE this beer... whether from their cans or at the brewpub (my local favorite)!!

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2006 March 2004:  Draught at the brewpub.  Very light golden appearance, almost no head.  Fruit, fruit, fruit in the nose -- oranges, grapefruit, apples.  Very aromatic indeed.  Very sweet, soft at first, with many fruits, brown sugar and a hint of cinnamon, but a massive hop-whallop (120 IBUs) takes over shortly.  Smooth and creamy throughout, low carbonation.  Not at the top for the style, but quite tasty and dangerously drinkable. 8/3/8/4 16 3.9

September 2006:  This year¬ís edition definitely shows more malt presence in the body,  and the aroma is if anything even more fragrant, fruity and floral with some light touches of berry.  Really coming along, approaching mastery...
